You might also be considering: Audi A4, Cadillac ATS, Volvo S60

How do you subtract two, add one, and come up with a larger number than you started with? Here’s how Acura did it: For 2015, the TL and TSX models were shelved and replaced with the TLX. Results? For the first two months of 2015, comparing year-over-year sales, the TLX outsold the other two models combined.

Of course, it helps that the TLX has a lot to recommend it. Positioned between the entry ILX and the flagship RLX, the TLX delivers a mix of sportiness and luxury. There are two available powertrains, a four-cylinder with an eight-speed automatic transmission and a V-6 with a nine-speed auto. All-wheel steering is standard with front-wheel drive models, and all-wheel drive is optional with the V-6 engine. The base TLX comes well equipped, with heated seats and side mirrors, a power moonroof, satellite radio, and LED head- and taillights. For even more features, such as navigation with 3D view and HD Radio, you can upgrade to the Technology and Advance packages

Slightly smaller than the TL, the TLX is built on an all-new platform, and the body is made of rigid, lightweight materials that emphasize driving dynamics and collision safety. In addition, wind, road, and engine noise have been reduced compared with the TL, thanks to triple door seals and extra body sealing and sound-absorbing materials. All TLXs also feature Acura’s Integrated Dynamics System (IDS), which offers four modes – Econ, Normal, Sport, and Sport+ — for drivers to adjust steering firmness, throttle response, and shifting patterns.

New for 2015

The TLX is an all-new model for 2015.

Acura’s RDX crossover had its best sales year ever in 2014 and looks to continue that trend for 2015. A 3.5-liter V-6 mated to a six-speed automatic transmission is the only powertrain offered, and it is a good one. At 273 horspower, it offers more than enough oomph to get you going, and the power comes on seamlessly. Lots of the RDX’s competitors offer turbocharged four-cylinder engines that in theory offer better fuel economy, but this V-6 returns a very competitive 23 mpg in combined city/freeway driving.

As with any crossover, the RDX offers a high seating position and gives the driver a good view of the road. It also has a very usable 26.1 cubic feet of storage space behind the second row, which can be folded to expand the cargo area expands to 63.1 cubic feet. The second row also has a 60/40 split, which enables you to carry long objects and retain three seating positions.

The RDX is available in two trim levels—base and Technology—and with either front- or all-wheel drive. Lots of standard features are available, including a rearview camera, heated seats and mirrors, and dual-zone automatic climate control. The Technology Package adds navigation and a premium audio system.

The two most popular vehicles from Honda’s upscale division are SUV/crossovers, which might seem surprising until you spend some time in the RDX (and the MDX), which are very good examples of how to blend comfort, performance and utility into a vehicle that will fill the needs of almost any driver.

New for 2015

The RDX carries over unchanged from 2014. A face lift is scheduled for 2016.

Notable options on this model: Adaptive cruise control with low-speed follow, fourteen-speaker Krell audio system, heated rear seats
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Cadillac CTS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Acura’s top-of-the-line sedan has never been a big seller against such powerhouses as the BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz E-Class, and Audi A6. However, that hasn’t discouraged Honda’s upscale division, which continues to add features to the RLX to elevate its level of technology and sophistication. There are four trim levels/packages—Navigation, Technology, Advance, and Krell Audio—and one powertrain, a 310-horsepower V-6 mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. There is also a Sport Hybrid version, but it is not technically a 2015 model. It continues to be sold in dealerships, but since it came out late in the 2014 model year, it continues with that designation. The hybrid powertrain produces 377 horsepower and gets 30 mpg in combined city/highway driving. A redesigned Sport Hybrid with all-wheel drive is scheduled to go on sale for 2016.

The RLX doesn’t carry the prestige of its European competitors, nor does it have their wider selection of powertrains. Driving the RLX is not a revelation, either, but its V-6 engine powerful enough, and it delivers a smooth ride. Where the RLX excels is with its spacious interior, which has generous legroom for back-seat passengers and features a wide array of high-tech features. Forward-collision and lane-departure warning systems and a multi-view rear camera are standard, and a collision mitigation braking system and lane-keeping assist are available. Also available with the Advance package is an adaptive cruise control system with low-speed follow, which automatically slows the car without any input from the driver when traffic necessitates braking. The RLX is being updated for 2016, so you can probably negotiate a good deal on a 2015 model.

New for 2015

There is no 2015 RLX Hybrid, although the 2014 Hybrid, which came out late in the model year, will continue to be sold.

Acura’s entry-level model was redesigned a couple of years ago and carries over mostly unchanged for 2015—which isn’t a bad thing. The ILX shares its underpinnings with the Honda Civic but has a character of its own, with unique sheetmetal and a cabin that is in keeping with its luxury aspirations. It also feels different to drive than the Civic, with a suspension that is tuned to give it a better ride over rough road surfaces.

There are three trim levels and two different powertrain options. The base ILX comes with a 150-horsepower, 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that is mated to a five-speed automatic transmission. The base model is well equipped, with a multi-view rear camera to help in tight parking spaces, cruise control, heated side mirrors, heated leather-trimmed front seats, pushbutton start, and Bluetooth among its many amenities. There is also a Premium model, which adds satellite radio, an automatically dimming rear-view mirror, high-intensity discharge headlights, and fog lights. The Technology model gets all of the above, plus navigation, GPS-linked climate control, and a premium sound system.

The Technology model is also the only ILX that can be had with the 201-horsepower, 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine and a six-speed manual transmission for an extra dash of sportiness. With prices starting at less than $30,000, the ILX is aimed at young drivers who aspire to an uplevel marque, and if offers the sorts of features that younger buyers—and those who are looking for an entry-luxury bargain—might find intriguing.

New for 2015

Minor changes in feature content. The Hybrid model has been discontinued.

It’s no wonder that the seven-passenger MDX is Acura’s bestselling vehicle, as it offers the comfort, performance, style, and practicality that buyers want in a sport-utility vehicle. With three rows of seating, the MDX can carry up to seven passengers. Access to the rearmost row is made easier by a low step-in height and a second row that that moves forward at the touch of a button. When both rows are folded, the cargo compartment expands to 90.0 cubic feet—plenty of room for anything you might purchase at Ikea.

The cabin is well appointed, with leather trim, an ergonomically friendly center console with two display screens, and easy-to-read gauges. The optional navigation system is also user-friendly, although the graphics and technology are starting to look a little outdated.

Standard features include push-button start, LED headlamps, a rearview camera with multiple viewing angles, Bluetooth, satellite radio, three-zone automatic climate control, a power moonroof, and heated front seats. There are lots of high-tech optional features when you order the Technology, Advance, and Entertainment packages, including a rear-seat entertainment system, a premium audio system, forward collision warning, lane-departure warning, and a collision mitigation system.

There is only one powertrain option: a very capable 290-horsepower, 3.5-liter V-6 and a six-speed automatic transmission. Front-wheel drive is standard, but Acura’s all-wheel-drive system is worth a look if you live in an area with inclement weather and/or challenging road conditions.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vintage photo by Dennis Dunleavy, Ypsilanti Press
Modern photo by Molly Jean, JeanKnowsCars.com

An amazing thing happened to me thirty-one years ago. A friend of mine who was in charge of Dodge racing asked me if I wanted to ride in a desert race with the king of off-road racing, Walker Evans. I’d never heard of him. "Sure," I said. He, in turn, agreed, thinking that Jean Lindamood from Car and Driver magazine was Gene Lindamood, a man.
I showed up at Walker's shop in Riverside, California. Once he got over the shock and fury, he sputtered, “If you throw up or pee your pants, I ain’t stopping!”

“Neither one of those things will happen,” I assured him. And then I brushed off my rusty welding skills from the Chrysler Proving Grounds, fabricated a bracket to hold his crew’s radio in the support vehicle, and wormed my way immediately into his heart.
The race was the 1984 Frontier 250. We won. Then I wore a neck brace for a week.

A month later, I got an offer to do the very first One Lap of America, a seven-day road rally around the rough perimeter of the United States totaling nearly 9,000 miles. There would be one overnight stop, at the Portofino Hotel in Redondo Beach, California. I called Walker and suggested he bring his buddy Parnelli Jones. Theirs has been a lifelong friendship and badass competition.

“You’re a wimp,” I suggested.
“We’ll do it,” he replied.

“That’s the craziest thing I ever heard of, Lindamood. You can’t take someone like me or Parnelli out of civilization for a whole week.”
“You’re a wimp,” I suggested.
“We’ll do it,” he replied.
Telling the true and complete story of what happened in that van over the course of that epic week with those two guys will take a book. I'll write it someday. Meanwhile, here are some highlights.

I arrived at the starting ramp to find Walker and Parnelli with two small trash cans. They explained that one could be for trash, and the other they could line with a trash bag so I could pee in it. They would then tie it up and throw it out the window. Seriously. I had to explain that I could hold on for at least twenty-four hours if necessary, that I would never be peeing in a trash can in a van in front of them, and that they should feel bad about the guy walking down the road who finds a bag of pee.

Diana Ross and René Dreyfus flagged us off from the Lock, Stock, and Barrel—which had been the traditional start of the Cannonball Baker Sea-to-Shining-Sea Trophy Dash, invented by Car and Driver columnist Brock Yates. You could call One Lap his attempt to keep the epic road trip idea going with less liability and more income.

As we left the ramp at the start of the herd, Brock handed us an envelope with one sheet of instructions: “Go to Boston.
“Turn left.
“Go to Seattle.
“Turn left.
“Go to Miami.
“Turn left.
“Return to Darien.”

It was supposed to be a rally, but there were plenty of lunatics and plenty of arrests. Twenty-five of our cohort were picked off in one half-mile stretch of I-5. Once each day, a Porsche 930 Turbo would roar past us at warp speed, much to Parnelli’s and Walker’s amusement. “Betcha he’s got on those perforated driving gloves and they’re choking off the blood to his brain,” mused Walker.

They never let me drive. Parnelli explained it to one interviewer: "I drive twelve hours and Walker sleeps. Then Walker drives twelve hours and I sleep. She"—he jerked a thumb in my direction—"just stays up."

He wasn’t lying. "Why would you want to drive when you’ve got two perfectly good drivers with you?" asked Parnelli. There were three exceptions. They let me drive out of a quick stop in Ann Arbor when my mom and dad were in the crowd. For thirty miles. They let me drive on I-94 across the Great Plains until I slowed down for a missing section of roadway. Then a long dry spell until after we’d dropped Walker off at the Miami airport so he could fly home for a truck race and Parnelli and I were facing the long drive back to Darien, Connecticut.

By North Carolina, I noticed that Parnelli had been edgy and withdrawn ever since Miami. I finally figured it out. He was suffering from severe Walker withdrawal. The Siamese-twin-separation syndrome. It was a big moment when he finally asked, “Hey you wanna drive?” with a big crazy grin.
It was like getting driving lessons from, well, Parnelli Jones and my mother rolled into one. It was another big moment for both of us when I gave him back the van.

During the next 350 miles, he clenched and unclenched his fists continually, wiped sweaty palms on his pants legs, stomped on the floor where no brake pedal existed, jumped on my case for lurching away from tollbooths, and chastised me for making sloppy lane changes. It was like getting driving lessons from, well, Parnelli Jones and my mother rolled into one. It was another big moment for both of us when I gave him back the van.

We came in eighteenth place, or so we thought. Thirteen years later, at my wedding, a very drunken Range Rover PR guy who was helping Brock Yates with the One Lap lost track of his toast to me. He ended up blurting out that Walker, Parnelli, and I had actually won that first One Lap, but that he and Yates decided we didn’t need to win it. So they had given the win to three nice boys from Warren, Vermont, that called themselves the Mad River Valley Holstein Team.
I called Walker immediately. “SON OF A BITCH!” he shouted. He called Parnelli. “SON OF A BITCH!” Parnelli shouted. Just in case you thought this wasn’t important to them.
We’ve grown older, the snowmobiles are getting too big and heavy for for them to race, and I don’t see them as much as I used to.

But Walker is being inducted into the Motorsports Hall of Fame of America tonight, presented by Parnelli, and I wouldn’t miss it for anything. We had a very uproarious reunion yesterday at a luncheon for the honorees. (That's Parnelli at left, Walker at right in the photo.) So I can be on my very best tonight, not "Kanye" the presentation, no photo bombs, and just applaud and whistle longer and louder than anyone in the audience. You know I will.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text: If you're shopping for a new car, you are probably all over the Internet looking for information. Thanks for stopping off here, by the way. We're here to help. And that's why we are calling to your attention the latest of the many studies and reports you'll find about customer satisfaction and vehicle quality. It's one of the biggies, the 2015 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study, or IQS.

This survey ranks automotive brands and individual models, according to how many problems were reported by new-car buyers in their first ninety days of owning or leasing. This well-established survey is now in its twenty-ninth year.

The study surveys some 84,000 purchasers, with results covering February through May of this year. That seems like a lot, but keep in mind that the IQS is highly subjective. The person answering the survey gets to declare what they consider a problem, and you might be surprised at what these problems entail.

We're not talking a bunch of transmission failures here (although there were surely some serious issues). The biggest source of complaints is actually infotainment: especially problems pairing phone to car using Bluetooth, and getting the car to recognize your voice. (I can identify, as someone who uses voice recognition on my phone and has been frustrated by Siri’s crazy misinterpretations.) Those things are irritating, but I wouldn’t want to decide what car to buy based on whether the infotainment system knows what I’m saying every time. Neither should you.

What can you learn from the IQS? Since infotainment is causing so much distress among new-car buyers, make sure you fully understand the information and entertainment technology in any car you’re planning to buy or lease. Make the salesperson go over it with you in exhaustive detail before you drive off. Play around with the navigation, voice recognition, Bluetooth phone pairing, and other complicated stuff so you don’t have to go back in your first ninety days of ownership to get help with it.

Of course, it still can be useful to know which vehicle had the fewest problems reported in the category you're looking at. It can also be helpful to look at which auto company ranks highest and which lowest. This year, the big news is that the Korean automakers Kia and Hyundai did much better, while Japanese automakers dropped below the industry average for the first time, putting them on par with U.S. automakers and below the European average. Overall, J.D. Power notes, initial quality went up three percent last year, so that's good news for consumers. Now, suppose you need to make a short list of potential new cars to buy. You might want to pay attention to where your preferred brand came out in the IQS.

The average among automakers was 112 problems reported per 100 vehicles in the first ninety days of ownership. The top-ranked automaker was Porsche, with only 80 problems reported per 100 vehicles. Kia was second, with 86, and Jaguar third, with 93. Hyundai placed fourth, with 95 problems per 100 vehicles, and the number-five spot was claimed by Infiniti, with 97. BMW placed sixth, well ahead of average with 99 problems per 100 vehicles. BMW of North America's president and CEO, Ludwig Willisch, said the IQS shows “how well our dealers are doing in demonstrating the functions of the new vehicle,” but he added that "the clear challenge [is] to improve and simplify technology.”

Here is the 2015 IQS detailed breakdown by brand.
Down at the bottom, Fiat was last among thirty-three brands, with 161 problems reported per 100 vehicles. We asked Berj Alexanian of Fiat Chrysler how Fiat is responding to that last-place finish.

He told JKC that Fiat's poor showing was in part because of "a bit of a disconnect" because the Fiat lineup was designed “specifically for global markets. We’re still bringing them into line with American priorities,” he said. Specifically? "There will be changes to our infotainment systems between 2015 and 2016 model years," he said.

Michael McHale, Subaru director of corporate communications, commented on his brand's rating of 142 problems per 100 vehicles, fourth from the bottom. He said that IQS problems reported in Subarus, "as for many makes," were largely about "connectivity and voice recognition. This is new technology and we are continually improving our offerings and expect our new product scores to improve next year."
Should you just go buy the product of whatever company had the fewest reported problems? A smarter move would be to consider this study as one of several tools.
The IQS also ranks vehicles by category. Here were the cars and SUVs at the top of each category.

City Car: Chevrolet Spark
Small Car: Hyundai Accent
Small Premium Car: BMW 2 Series
Compact Car: Nissan Sentra
Compact Sporty Car: Mazda MX-5 Miata
Compact Premium Car: BMW 4 Series
Compact Premium Sporty Car: Porsche Boxster
Mid-size Car: Chevrolet Malibu
Mid-size Sporty Car: Dodge Challenger
Mid-size Premium Car: BMW 5 Series
Mid-size Premium Sporty Car: Porsche 911
Large Car: Chrysler 300
Large Premium Car: Lexus LS
You also shouldn’t rely on a single source of information, obviously, nor take your inspiration from what people thought only for the first three months of ownership. Here are some other resources:

Owner Satisfaction. Consumer Reports takes a much bigger survey of new-vehicle owners with its annual Owner Satisfaction study. Pro: It covers more people and a longer term of ownership, surveying 350,000 vehicles from one to three years old. Con: The respondents are all CR subscribers, not a cross-section of the general population.

Vehicle Dependability. J.D. Power also does a Vehicle Dependability Study that comes out in February. That one reports problems experienced in the past year with three-year-old vehicles. J.D. Power says that reliability complaints again lean heavily toward infotainment systems and technology.
Visit the survey specialist's website to see all the J.D. Power automotive surveys and rankings.

pageElements.text: If you’ve seen Subaru's dog-themed commercials, you know that the company loves our pets almost as much as we do. This summer, Subaru is continuing its partnership with the nonprofit Center for Pet Safety to do safety testing on equipment you use with your pet in the car. This time, the project is to crash test pet crates and carriers. In 2013, the Center for Pet Safety tested pet harnesses, and after finding surprising flaws with some products, they established official safety standards and compiled a list of certified harnesses. Now Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety aim to do the same with crates.

While I was happy to hear about Subaru’s new efforts to protect pets, I also felt something else: guilt. I realized I have not given my dog’s safety in the car the proper attention. After watching the crash test videos and seeing the statistics on vehicle crashes caused by unrestrained animals, I’m convinced I need to be more careful.

Here is an example of my (previous) bad behavior. On some evenings I crave ice cream, and what’s a girl to do other than load her eight-year-old black Lab into the back seat of her car and head to the nearest Baskin-Robbins? My dog, Clem, immediately thrusts his head out the open window and lets his big pink tongue hang out while the wind pushes his floppy ears back. When we arrive at the drive-through, I order and pull forward to greet the friendly cashier, who happens to have a soft spot for Clem. Okay, maybe he loves all dogs, but I prefer to think Clem is special. The cashier hands me my strawberry ice cream and, because, the Baskin-Robbins is connected to a Dunkin' Donuts, he also feeds a leftover doughnut hole to Clem. At this point, my dog has half his body out of the car window. We love this ritual and drive away happy as clams, but I haven't really thought about any safety implications for my pup. Heck, if I had a dime for every time Clem or our other six-month-old black Lab, Brick, jumped into my lap, crawled over a seat, or unknowingly tried to climb out the window while I was driving, I’d be a wealthy woman.

I Thought My Dog Crate Was Crash Tested?

Pet crate manufacturers have increasingly labeled their products as “crash tested,” but what does that really mean? According to Lindsey Wolko, founder and CEO of the Center for Pet Safety, it doesn’t mean much. “Just because a product has been crash tested, without a formal test protocol and ratings guidelines, there is nothing to use to measure a ‘pass,’” Wolko says. “It’s simply more market hype.” The fact is that pet safety equipment has not been tested using rigorous safety standards, and that's exactly what this Subaru/Center for Pet Safety effort is trying to change.
“We want to make pet parents aware of safety measures they can take to help protect their pets,” says Subaru's Michael McHale. Test results are expected in late summer.

Through studying and testing a variety of carriers and crates in crash scenarios, the two groups hope to establish performance standards for similar pet safety products. “We want to make pet parents aware of proper safety measures they can take to help protect their pets,” says Michael McHale, Subaru’s director of corporate communications. Test results can be expected late this summer.

Why Subaru Cares, and Why You Should, Too

With all seven of its 2015 models earning Top Safety Pick or Top Safety Pick Plus ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, Subaru clearly makes safety a priority. However, more than 69 percent of Subaru drivers own at least one dog, so protecting pups in the car is also of the utmost importance to the company. Ad campaigns like “Dog tested, dog approved” and “Once you sit in a Subaru, you’ll stay” give away Subaru’s fondness for our furriest family members.

So it makes sense that Subaru would want to participate in this study, but is it worth your attention? According to Subaru, 56 percent of American pet owners, myself included, travel with their pets, and 20 percent do so with a pet in their lap. Paws to Click, an organization that promotes safer pet travel, says up to 98 percent of dogs travel unrestrained in cars, and there are 30,000 driving accidents per year as a result.

During Subaru’s 2013 study with the Center for Pet Safety, pet harnesses were put to the test, revealing some critical flaws. Many of the products’ failures could prove dangerous to you and your four-legged friend, meaning even if you do take steps to secure your pet, safety is not guaranteed. Thanks to the study, though, dog lovers have access to a more reliable source of safety advice. “Pet owners can now look to the CPS website and identify the top-performing products on the market,” says Wolko.

Awareness of pet safety in the vehicle does not mean the end of all fun when it comes to traveling with pets. Clem can still enjoy his doughnut hole from inside a crate or with a harness securely holding him in place, and that's what we'll be doing from now on.

In some ways, the BMW i8 is two cars in one. Its futuristic styling suggests a whiplash-inducing luxury performance coupe that bolts off the line, hugging the road as it careens around the track. And with a 0-to-60-mph sprint completed in only 4.2 seconds, that would be a correct assumption. But it’s still a plug-in hybrid, which means that at the push of a button, it can operate on electric-only mode and responsibly motor around town emitting nary a tailpipe emission. With the gasoline engine disengaged, the i8 offers a pure EV range of approximately 22 miles and a top speed of 75 mph, but when making full use of its electric motors and its three-cylinder, 1.5-liter gasoline engine, the coupe produces an output of 357 horsepower and maxes out at an electronically controlled top speed of 155 mph while still getting an average combined fuel economy of 76 mpg. If you’ve drained the lithium-ion battery, you can expect an estimated 29 mpg when using only the gasoline engine. There are four different trim packages—the limited-edition Pure Impulse World is the most expensive at $10,800—each with its own interior trim options. As you might expect in a $140,000 vehicle, the standard features list is comprehensive. In fact, the only available options are turbine-style 20-inch alloy wheels and a swanky Louis Vuitton luggage set.

Comfort Access is now standard.

BMW has given the performance coupe its own model and series, betting that serious drivers who aren’t concerned with rear-seat egress want a more aggressively styled car. To that end, the 4-series fits the bill. Its sportiness is emphasized with an elongated, athletic exterior and a more rigid chassis than the 3-series. Mucking up the formula a bit is the recently introduced 4-Series Gran Coupe, which gets four doors but retains the fastback styling of the coupe. Although the 4-series and 3-series models share the same turbocharged 2.0-liter in-line-four and turbocharged 3.0-liter in-line-six engines, the 4-series wheelbase is bit longer, its body wider, and roof lower than its compact sedan sibling, which results in a more dynamic driving machine that feels firmly connected to the road. Rounding out the different driving characteristics is the standard speed-sensitive steering— variable-assist sport steering and adaptive suspension are available as part of the optional dynamic handling package. Optional technology is available on every aspect of the 4-series, from the Comfort Access that opens the trunk with a small foot movement under the center of the rear bumper, to the pedestrian detection, speed limit sign detection, collision avoidance, head-up display, and Google search-based points-of-interest for the navigation system. Rear seats in the Gran Coupe hatchback have a 40/20/40 split help make the most of cargo capacity.

Revised package features, new leather and material options, Comfort Access now includes the hands-free trunk closing function, and the Gran Coupe and M4 models are all new.

Part of luxury is the option to choose, and buyers of BMW’s biggest luxury sedan have plenty of options to choose from. The 7-series is available with six engine choices, including the standard turbocharged in-line six, a massively powerful V-12, and the more frugal diesel or hybrid powertrains. What remains consistent throughout this model line is the profoundly quiet and smooth ride thanks to the enhanced cabin soundproofing, self-leveling air suspension, and dynamic damping control. As you would expect from a top-of-the-line luxury sedan, the interior is well-appointed and beautifully crafted, and includes four-zone climate control, navigation system, touchpad, 12-speaker audio, park assist technology, and dynamic cruise control among many other features. If you can get past the odd design of the BMW i3, there is a lot to love in this compact electric car. Engineering nerds will wax poetic about at the aluminum body and carbon fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP) that makes vehicle’s frame lightweight yet as strong as steel, and appreciate the two propulsion options to suit their lifestyle and driving needs. All i3s are equipped with a 22kWh lithium-ion battery pack that produces 170 horsepower and 184 lb-ft of torque, and can propel the compact four-seater more than 80 miles on a single charge and up to speeds of 93 mph. It may seem counter-intuitive to build an even smaller crossover than the already compact X3, but the BMW X1 is finding its niche in the market. Sized more like a beefy hatchback than a crossover, it’s tempting empty nesters to downsize their vehicles without giving up the commanding view to which they’ve become accustomed, and it’s offering young families and city dwellers decent cargo capacity without suburban proportions. The X1’s equipment is straightforward but generous, with a 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine that produces 240 horsepower mated to an 8-speed automatic transmission, and it’s available with either standard rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. The interior retains that clean, Bavarian styling synonymous with the BMW brand, and its driving dynamics reflects the sportiness of its new, self-described “sport activity vehicle” classification. The mid-size sedan segment is the most competitive in the market, and for many years the Chrysler 200 was an also-ran in the crowded field. Chrysler redesigned the 200 for 2015 with an eye toward making it a real competitor. To that end, it has some segment-exclusive features, such as a nine-speed transmission that shifts almost imperceptibly as it transfers the power from the engine to the wheels. There are two available engines, a perfectly adequate if not exactly inspiring four-cylinder and a 295-horsepower V-6 that produces more power than is found in any other family sedan. The 200 is also one of the few vehicles in the segment that offers all-wheel drive (along with the Ford Fusion and the Subaru Legacy).

The exterior styling of the new 200 is much sleeker than the previous generation, and the interior is more modern and inviting—the rotary gearshift knob might even remind you of being in a Jaguar. The vehicle information display on the dash in front of the driver can be configured to your preferences, and Chrysler’s Uconnect is a touchscreen media center that is among the tops in the industry. It is very intuitive and easy to use, and the optional 8.4-inch screen is the largest of any mid-size car. There’s even a mobile phone app that allows you to start your car remotely, as well as lock or unlock it.

Best of all, the 200 starts at less than $23,000, and even a fully optioned 200C with the all-wheel-drive option goes for not more than $30,000.

When the Chrysler 300 debuted back in 2005, its Bentley-like styling made it a big hit for Chrysler. By the time the second-generation car was introduced in 2011, the 300 had lost some of its novelty, but it is still the epitome of the large, rear-wheel-drive American sedan. For 2015, the 300 has a new front fascia with a larger grille, along with new taillamps and an interior that features upgraded materials and styling, including a rotary gear selector similar to the one used by Jaguar.

There are two available engines, a V-6 and a V-8, and all-wheel drive is a $2500 option on V-6 300s ($4195 on 300 Limited). Chrysler boasts that the V-6, at 31 mpg on the highway, makes the 300 the fuel-economy leader in the full-size sedan class. Also best in class is the 363 horsepower of the available Hemi V-8. This year, for the first time, both engines are available with the super-smooth eight-speed automatic transmission. There are four trim levels to choose from: the well-equipped Limited, the sporty 300S, the uplevel 300C, and the luxury 300C Platinum.

The Chrysler 300 is a big car, but you can dial up the sportiness by pressing the Sport button on the dashboard, which reduces shift times, firms up the steering, and increases engine responsiveness. In addition the 300 has a host of available safety features, such as forward collision warning, lane-departure warning, adaptive cruise control, and a 911 button you can push in case of an emergency.

Notable standard features on this model: Four full-size seats, engine stop-start, dual-zone climate control, three-stage heated and ventilated front seats, multifunction steering wheel, 6.5-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, iPhone and iPad compatability
Notable options on this model: Passenger-side dashboard “emotion display,” USB connection, rear-seat infotainment system with integrated front-seatback displays, ultra-premium audio system
You might also be considering: Bentley Continental GT, Porsche Panamera

It’s unusual to see a car with a rear hatchback opening and twin-outlet dual exhausts. But the Ferrari FF is unusual in many ways. It claims to be the first V-12-powered car to have an electronically governed rear-axle differential and the first with a 7-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. The design allows the 6.3-liter V-12—and that’s a big chunk of aluminum—to sit behind the front axle, a layout that keeps the car from being nose-heavy and pushy in the turns. Ferrari’s clever, patented all-wheel-drive system is biased toward rear-drive until traction is compromised; then it dispenses torque to the front wheels.

With its station wagon-like shape, the FF seemed a weird departure when it was first presented in 2011, but now that Bentley is building an SUV and other high-end automakers are showing their expressions of utility, we understand the FF was ahead of the game. With all four seats in place, the 15.9-cubic-foot trunk holds four suitcases, two golf bags, or two strollers. But fold the rear seats fold flat, and this is a Ferrari that wants to go for landscaping supplies. An independently opening middle section enables the insertion of skis or a single golf bag with the seats in place. Persons as tall as 6 feet 1 inch will find the rear comfortable. There’s also abundant cabin storage for miscellaneous items. We would say “stuff,” but Ferrari owners don’t have stuff, they have items.

The elongated hood, muscular lines and low, athletic stance are the hallmarks of the 2015 BMW Z4. The engine options for this roadster include a 240-horsepower, 2.0-liter in-line four-cylinder engine and a 300-horsepower, 3.0-liter in-line-six, turbo and twin-turbo, respectively. contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Buick Regal GS AWD

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive sedan
Base price: $40,735 (including destination charge)
This car: $44,670 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 259 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Models available: Regal, Regal GS, Regal with eAssist
My favorite standard feature: Intellilink infotainment system (radio, navigation, Bluetooth streaming, CD player)
Notable standard features on this model: Stability and traction control, rearview camera, heated front seats with lumbar support, heated steering wheel and outside mirrors, 4G LTE wireless hot spot (requires subscription after trial period), OnStar and SiriusXM satellite radio (both require subscription after trial period)
Notable options on this model: Forward collision, rear cross-traffic, and side blind zone/lane change alert systems; lane departure warning, and following-distance sensor (included in Driver Confidence package #1, $1,040); adaptive cruise control, automatic collision preparation (included in Driver Confidence package #2, $1,195); power moonroof ($1,000); 20-inch aluminum wheels with summer tires ($700)
You might also be considering: 2015 Acura TLX SH-AWD with Technology package ($42,495), 2015 Cadillac ATS 2.0 Turbo AWD ($38,240), 2016 Nissan Maxima SR ($38,495) (all prices include destination charges)
Fun-o-Meter: 7

I was driving the back roads in the middle of Nowhere, Michigan, a few years ago and stopped at a corner gas station to get my dog Lou some water. As she and I were hanging out, a line of five or six Buick sedans with manufacturer license plates rolled in, and a bunch of obvious engineers climbed out.
“Hello, boys!” I greeted them. The driver’s window of the third car, a Regal GS, rolled down and there was Mark Reuss, then GM’s president of North America.
“Hello, boys!” I greeted them. The driver’s window of the third car, a Regal GS, rolled down and there was Mark Reuss, then GM’s president of North America.
“No way! What the hell are you doing here?!?” he asked me. I still treasure the look on his face.

So they were out running prototypes with Reuss, the head of the engineering food chain, a guy steeped in performance background, a rabid racing fan, son of Buick’s former chief engineer (1975-78) who became general manager in the 1980s, the time of development of the turbo V-6 and Grand National and the ultimate Regal—the 1987 GNX (shown here). That day at the gas station, I could feel it: Buick was in good hands.

But let’s just say the excitement has not followed an unbroken line for Buick. The name Buick is old. The name Regal is old. Somewhere between that GNX and the last Lucerne lay the horse latitudes, the ho-hum years when driving Buicks made me feel like a grandma with a gray hair bun and a step-in apron.

That memory is now gone with the wind. This is a brand that is now sitting in the #1 spot for customer satisfaction among mass-market brands in J.D. Power’s Customer Service Index. The turbo Regal is a recommended buy from Consumer Reports, and this year Buick became the first domestic to break into the top ten on Consumer Reports' annual Brand Report Cards.

When GM set about divesting itself of Hummer, Pontiac, Saab, Oldsmobile, and Saturn during the dark years from 2004 to 2010, it was astonishing that it kept Buick. But only if you didn’t realize that Buick was and still is a smash hit in China. So thank you, China, for motivating General Motors to hang on to the brand.
It feels closer to its European roots—which makes sense, considering its platform is by  Opel—and it looks more stunning than anything else in Buick's lineup.

And now, a few years later, look what we get: the Buick Regal GS, the sportiest version of the mid-size sedan.  It feels closer to its European roots—which makes sense, considering its platform is by GM’s European division Opel—and it looks more stunning than anything else in Buick’s lineup.

As the commercials indicate, this is not your grandma’s Buick. First, the Buick GS is a real looker, with sinuous body complimented by its Copper Red Metallic paint, aggressive front end, and striking 20-inch chrome wheels. These wheels are a tad controversial (and cost $700, which means they’re an option I believe I could live without). But I really began to appreciate how far this brand has come after a close look at the rest of the exterior: the understated doors, the nicely detailed grille, and the judicious use of brightwork that in no way could be described as overdone, unless you count the faux Buick signature vents on the hood. Those are a design nod to hot Buicks of the past. Any extra shine is saved for the front end.

The GS is also a goer, though not nearly as hot under the hot as the wayback 1987 Grand National Experimental (GNX), a limited-production Regal of 547 copies made near the end of the ten-year run of the Regal’s second generation. It was ahead of its time by a wide margin, the only U.S production car with a turbocharger at a time when only Porsche, Saab, and, Mercedes-Benz had turbos here in the States.

The 2015 GS we tested has a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 259 horsepower. You can also get a Regal with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder making 182 horsepower, teamed with a lithium-ion battery for what GM calls eAssist to aid in regenerative braking, helping a bit with fuel economy. With the four-cylinder, you’re promised 25 mpg in the city and 36 mpg on the highway, up from the turbo’s 19/27 mpg. A six-speed automatic transmission is standard, but you can get a six-speed manual on the GS as a no-cost option, provided you get a front-wheel-drive GS rather than one with all-wheel drive. A Buick with a manual!

The engine is the new “performance lite” type that’s proliferating across the industry: a 2.0-liter four-cylinder with decent (not blistering) horsepower and pretty good torque to help you get away from the stop sign. Just when you think the engine has hit the wall, the turbocharger kicks in to pick up the slack. The GS not only includes turbocharging, the one we tested also has all-wheel drive to help put power down to the pavement through all four wheels.

The Regal GS is super confident on the road and pleasant to drive. It more than holds its own on twisty roads, which surprised me so much that I decided to skip my usual four-hour Interstate snooze-athon route to northern Michigan and take back roads two-thirds of the way. I’m not sure what was more of a pleasant surprise: how happy the Regal GS was hammering away past fields of knee-high corn and maturing oats, or that the route—M-52 straight out of Chelsea, Michigan—had so many curves, kinks, and high-speed bends. It is also heavily patrolled, but I got my money’s worth in the twisties and kept closer to the speed limit sailing along on the long straights.

As you’d expect from a Buick, the GS has extremely comfortable seats. I happily drove those for four full hours without a break on the fat cushions with their robust stitching, excellent lumbar support, and leather trim. There’s also nicely padded leather trim on the three-spoke steering wheel and the door panels.

Having said that, it’s a little narrow inside. The center front console is cut out to fit around two cupholders. Everything is located a bit far rearward for comfort. You’ll be doing a little bit of gymnastics to fold your chicken wing back to fetch the coffee. God forbid it should be a flimsy Starbucks Save the Earth cup that threatens to pop its lid and dump scalding coffee over your hand. The center console itself is only good for your elbow. All this to accommodate the automatic transmission selector shift, a little coin box, and the electric parking lever.

As with so many cars these days, quality is supposedly emphasized by the use of a completely black interior. I don’t get that. I find a two-tone interior so much more luxurious. But maybe that’s a girl thing. Or just a somebody-with-taste thing. The dash adds a little excitement with teal and white digital lighting (and a speedometer that goes to 180 mph).

Speaking of the interior, perhaps the best thing GM is doing these days is its extremely intuitive, easy-to-use Intellilink infotainment system. I was a little taken aback by the 94-page instruction manual, but I found Intellilink very easy to use. Navigation, for instance, lets you read out the address all at once, and it spits back the directions. None of the annoying hunting and pecking of some systems.

One of the most mentioned detriments to the all-important J.D. Power Customer Service Index (CSI) rating is how fast a car’s Bluetooth can pair a phone and if the genie in the voice recognition program, well, recognizes your voice. That may seem like a small thing, but when you ask your car to call your boyfriend and it calls an ex-employee’s brother instead, you will not be satisfied. (Unless that’s whom you’re currently dating.)

How did the Regal do? Pretty damn good: It paired my phone during a traffic light between red and green lights. Voice control improved when I worked harder at controlling my atrocious Michigan accent. Or it got used to me.

Plus, there’s an actual CD player in the dash, something you see less and less these days. More modern than that is GM’s OnStar with a 4G LTE wireless hot spot—the big news for this 2015 model—letting your passengers operate up to seven devices. It’s free for the first three months or 3GB of data. After that, you’ll pay somewhere between $5 and $50 a month, depending on whether you’re also subscribing to OnStar and how much data you want to use.

The Buick Selective Ride Control system lets you choose Standard, the default setting, for a smooth, quiet ride; Sport (stiffer shocks for a more controlled ride); or the sportiest GS setting (even stiffer shocks, quicker engine response when you ask for power, and less power steering assistance for more direct response to your inputs). The only problem I actually had was that it took me three days to spot the GS button and two more to find the fingernail-sized Sport button, located as far from the driver as it could possibly be, last in a row of four fingernail-sized buttons.

Option packages on the Regal GS I tested added almost $4,000 to the final price. A tiny power moonroof is priced at a big $1,000. A $1,195 Driver Confidence package adds adaptive cruise control and automatic collision preparation. A second package ($1,040) includes forward collision and rear cross-traffic alert, blind spot alert, and lane departure warning, plus memory settings for the front seats and mirrors. Then there were the $700 aluminum wheels: an acquired taste, as I mentioned earlier.

This is not a comparison test. And yet. It’s one thing to compare the Regal to Regals of the past, it’s one thing to compare it to other American cars, and it’s quite another thing to compare it to a competitor such as the new 2016 Nissan Maxima, which at a couple thousand bucks less is a car that right now stands very close to the head of the mid-size sedan class in terms of pure sex appeal and content.

I just stepped into a fully loaded 2016 Maxima SR, the sport model, which is a one-price car at $38,495. It’s New Age beautiful; if you squint, it looks like a baby Jaguar. When you step on the gas, it’s fabulous. When you compare the prices, even considering that the front-wheel-drive Maxima has no all-wheel-drive option like the Regal’s, there’s an uncomfortable gulf between the no-options Maxima’s price and the highly optioned Regal’s.

Yes, Buick has become a shining star in terms of customer satisfaction and reliability. They work very hard on that, and that counts for a whole lot in the mid-size sedan category, which is cutthroat. But with many attractive choices out there, that starting price at the $40,000 mark has to give you pause. Of course, that’s for the all-wheel-drive GS sport model with the turbocharged engine. If price is a deal breaker, the base model starts at $27,990 for the bare-bones front-wheel-drive version with the 2.4-liter “mild hybrid” four-cylinder. You won’t feel like a grandma either way.

pageElements.text:
Ford is taking a page from Apple’s innovation book by expanding its MyFord Mobile app extension to smartwatches. For owners of the Ford C-Max Energi (shown here) and Fusion Energi plug-in hybrids and the Focus Electric, this adds more fun and convenience to the ownership experience. And let's face it, it's not just environmentalism that makes a person buy an alternative-fuel vehicle: there's an early adopter excitement to it, a sense of adventure and play.

Ford announced this at a presentation of several new-tech initiatives in Palo Alto, where the automaker has its Research and Innovation Center. Joining several of the world's auto companies that are going all in on autonomous driving, Ford has named a new self-driving-car czar, Randy Visintainer (whose title is Director of Autonomous Vehicle Development), which should intensify the Ford Smart Mobility program to bring more driver assistance technology to Fords across the lineup. That's all good news for anyone who wants a safer car.

But back to the smartwatch. Yes, pretty soon you'll be able to check your hybrid or plus-in electric vehicle’s battery charge status and driving range from a quick glance at your wrist, assuming you have an Apple Watch or Android Wear smartphone on that wrist. The watches will get it "soon," Ford said. Ford's Said Deep tweeted a photo of a "research" version of the app on an Apple Watch a few weeks ago.
Just from your smartwatch, you can also use this app to find a nearby charging station and even remotely start your car. The MyFord Mobile app is already on iOS and Android smartphones.
Expanding apps from the smartphone to the smartwatch looks a little geeky at the moment, but you can bet things are just going to get smaller and more mobile

Want to try this out? You can go to the My Ford Mobile website and sign in as a Guest, at which point you will become a fictional San Francisco resident named Dylan. That will let you try out the technology even if you don’t own one of the Fords it works for. And even if you don't, you can be you will be using ever smaller and more portable technology to help you with the car you do own, within a matter of a few years from now.

The second-generation X6 is carving a niche in the not well understood luxury coupe-shaped-crossover market. The all-new 2015 BMW X6 retains the same 6-Series-inspired styling cues as the outgoing model, such as the fastback roofline and shorter rear doors, but the interior redesign fixes some of the vehicle’s earlier shortcomings. One of the most noticeable changes is that the X6 has increased its seating capacity from four to five. The first-generation vehicle sat only two in the rear, and the second row now can seat three across. Front and rear passengers will enjoy a bit more headroom, and while legroom is unchanged for the front row, the rear passengers will have two inches more to stretch their legs. But that extra legroom comes at a cost: namely, cargo capacity. The 2015 X6’s cargo capacity is down five cubic feet from the previous generation—now 20.5 cubic feet—and is less than that of the X1. But buyers tend to shop the X6 more for its advantageous forward view and agile performance than its practicality, which is reflected in the new rear-wheel-drive sDrive35i.

New for 2015

The X6 is all new for 2015.

With three powerful engine options in the X5 (four if you count the M series), most buyers will be picking this mid-size SUV for its performance on the road rather than off. The diesel engine, which puts out 255 horsepower and 413 pound-feet of torque with the fuel economy of a mid-size sedan, will appeal to drivers who have towing in mind, but the gasoline engines, with a range of 300 to 567 horsepower are still crowd pleasers. All engine options are paired with the eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, a handy feature in the event you really do need to hold a gear for steep mountain climbs. The interior is well equipped, including standard navigation with touchpad and a large, 10.2-inch high-definition display. But you’ll pay extra for the surround-view camera system, and most of the latest safety features, such as lane departure warning, active pedestrian and collision warning systems, and adaptive cruise control. The second row is fairly roomy and comes standard with a 40/20/40 split to customize the SUV’s 23-cubic-foot cargo area. An optional third row hidden in the cargo floor is available for the occasional additional passenger or two, making the X5 a solid, yet hefty, investment for growing families.

New for 2015

Recalibrated eight-speed automatic transmission resulting in better efficiency and faster acceleration; and the sport leather steering wheel is now standard.

The BMW X4 is for the unique buyer who likes the fastback look of a coupe—and is willing to sacrifice cargo capacity to get it—and yet doesn’t want to give up driving around on an elevated platform. Shorter and longer than the X3, the X4 offers the same engine options: either a turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder engine with an output of 300 horsepower or a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder that produces 240 horsepower. Both are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, and its only available with all-wheel drive. One of the ways that the X4 differentiates itself from the X3 is decidedly reduced cargo capacity and complete disregard for rear passenger comfort. Behind the rear seats it offers only 17.7 cubic feet of cargo space and up to almost 50 cubic feet with the seats folded flat, compared to the 27.6/63.3 cubic feet in the X3. Passengers may feel a bit snug with only 34.8 cubic inches of legroom and 37.4 cubic inches of headroom in the rear, but that’s part of the tradeoff with a coupe-like vehicle, even in a so-called “Sport Activity Vehicle.”

New for 2015

The X4 is an all-new model for 2015.

With the addition of a new turbo-diesel engine, BMW has figured out a way to give car shoppers the roominess and cargo capacity of a crossover with the performance and fuel economy of a sedan. The 2.0-liter 4-cylinder diesel engine produces 180 horsepower and 280 lb-ft of torque and it more than adequately powers this compact “Sports Activity Vehicle.” But if diesel isn’t your thing, the other available powerplants are a 240-horsepower, 2.0-liter 4-cylinder and a V-6 that produces 300 horsepower, but expect far lower fuel economy. All engine options are paired with the standard 8-speed automatic transmission. On the interior, the X3 has a few standard technology features, such as the iDrive infotainment system and Bluetooth audio, but most of the advanced safety features like the head-up display, adaptive cruise control, lane-departure warning, and collision avoidance systems cost extra. Rear seat passengers can stretch out a bit more than most compact or midsize sedans, with 36.5 cubic inches of legroom at their disposal. As the BMW 3 Series continues its growth spurt, the 2 Series has become the new entry-level model if your heart is set on a BMW but you don’t want to wait a few more years until your wallet catches up with your wish list. This rear-wheel-drive subcompact is available as a coupe or convertible, and it delivers excellent driving dynamics, performance, fuel economy, and technology in a smaller package than its 3 Series sibling. On the downside, it seats only four. But buyers are more likely buying this car for its engineering than its people shuttling and cargo capacity (which at almost 14 cubic feet is quite good), and they’ll be pleased with its standard turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that produces a more than ample 240 horsepower. It’s also one of the dwindling stock of rear-wheel-drive vehicles available with a six-speed manual transmission, and yet for the winter-weather dwellers, it’s also offered with xDrive. The interior is high end, but you’ll pay extra for most bells and whistles. Dual-zone climate control and a 6.5-inch LCD screen are standard, but navigation, a rearview camera, park assist, a cruise control system with braking function, and phone and app integration are all extra. Performance-minded buyers can bump up to the M—also still available with a manual transmission—and get the turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder engine that produces 320 horsepower and 330 pound-feet of torque, producing an impressive power-to-weight ratio. M-specific braking, exhaust, suspension, and chassis tuning complete this tight little package.

BMW’s intelligent all-wheel-drive system available on the 228i xDrive Coupe and the M235i xDrive models; newly available Track Handling package.

The BMW 3 Series is the quintessential German performance sedan. It has earned its place on nearly every top-ten or best-in-class list in the past two decades, and if there was an award for winning awards, the BMW 3 Series would probably take that title home, too. All this is to say that with its much-lauded dynamics, comfort, and performance, BMW has set the benchmark for performance sedans, and every manufacturer has it in its crosshairs. But beating BMW at its own game will be tough, since buyers can basically configure their 3 Series any way they like it. Shoppers can choose the sedan, wagon, or long wheel base hatchback, select either the standard rear-wheel drive or xDrive, choose a manual or automatic transmission, and pick from six engine options including a diesel and a hybrid, or go with the M3. You will pay dearly for all of these models, and that’s before you add your driver assistance and comfort packages, like navigation, a color head-up display, app integration, heated front and rear seats and steering wheel, a rearview camera, or adaptive headlights. But with its premium price come premium finishes. The interior is decidedly refined and spacious; the Luxury, Sport, and M Sport trim lines set different style tones; and a host of optional packages can make it one of the most technically advanced sedans out there. But any way it’s kitted out, it remains an attainable daily driver that has the versatility to switch instantly to a track car with a few setting changes.

New for 2015

Revised package features, new leather and material options, Comfort Access now includes the hands-free trunk closing function, and the M3 model is all new.

Based on the legendary 5 Series sedan is the more stylish and low-slung 6 Series. Available as a coupe, convertible, and four-door Gran Coupe, the recently refreshed 6 Series received a refresh for 2015. The Alpina B6 Gran Coupe is all new for 2015.

The BMW 5 Series is the 3 Series all grown up: bigger, roomier, faster, and better equipped, as well as with a higher price. Like the 3 Series, you can get it almost any way you want it, except instead of a wagon, you have a Gran Turismo model with an elongated body and a hands-free hatch door that increases the trunk cargo capacity. Old-school driving enthusiasts will appreciate that this mid-size sedan is still available with a six-speed manual—on the M5 only—as well as an eight-speed automatic transmission, and there are nearly as many engine options as body styles, including a recently added diesel, an updated V-8, and a hybrid. As you would expect from a sophisticated performance sedan, the list of standard features is extensive, including the iDrive infotainment system with voice-activated functions, navigation, a high-resolution display, and a three-year subscription to BMW Online, BMW Apps, and Advanced Real Time Traffic. On the downside, most of the safety technology, like the crash avoidance systems, adaptive cruise control, night vision with pedestrian detection, and head-up display, are options that add thousands to the already steep base price.

Expanded standard features, changes to optional packages and interior trim materials.

pageElements.text: I looked at a lot of new technologies during Ford's Further with Ford event in Palo Alto, California, this week, and what I liked about most of them is that they solve a problem and help the driver. One of the most miraculous was Ford's Pro Trailer Backup Assist, which will be an option for the 2016 Ford F-150 pickup that goes on sale near the end of the year.

If you’ve ever done it, or even watched someone else do it, you know that backing up a trailer is like trying to tie a bow tie while looking in a mirror. It’s not a natural or intuitive thing. You have to constantly countersteer the vehicle you're driving to maneuver the trailer into place. And you frequently look like a moron while you're trying.

The most embarrassing thing for a girl like me to do is to pull up to a boat ramp and not be able to back the trailer up, and have to give up and let my husband do it. I can only imagine how much worse it is for a man not to be able to back that trailer down a boat ramp. Everybody's seen it happen.

If you don't get it right (always when there are lots of people watching you, of course), the trailer suddenly locks up, and it's at a complete 90-degree angle to the vehicle you're driving, and you can't go backward anymore. Then you have to pull out and try again, pull out and try again. It’s just embarrassing. I have seen both men and women have this problem. And that’s what makes Ford’s new trailer assist so brilliant.

How It Works

Pro Trailer Backup Assist works very similarly to active park assist, also available on many Fords. And, even more than the park assist, it is a miracle.

There is a knob on the dash, to the right of the steering wheel, that you operate to steer the trailer. Your hands are off the steering wheel when it happens. It's awesome. You use the rearview camera and the mirrors to help. You steer the trailer, and the car reads those directions and countersteers itself.

You only control the gas and the brakes, while the truck steers itself and puts the trailer exactly where you want it to go. To get the trailer to move to the right, you turn the knob right, or clockwise. To get it to turn to the left, you turn it to the left, or counterclockwise. Simple, right? It only took me a minute to figure it out. Then I wanted to cry, I was so happy.

<iframe src="https://media.ford.com/content/fordmedia/fna/us/en/asset.embedded.html/content/dam/fordmedia/North America/US/2015/05/21/F150-Trailer-Backup-Final.mp4.html" height="340" width="500" ></iframe>

My co-tester was a woman under five feet tall. She didn’t want to try the Pro Trailer Backup Assist for herself, but I told her she had to. Well, she got into that big F-150 and backed that sucker up in one move. I said, “Now, aren’t you glad?”

The last time a manufacturer introduced a feature to help park or move large trucks was when General Motors introduced its four-wheel assist, called Quadrasteer, in the early 2000s. Being the owner of three full-size pickups, I absolutely loved it, but the price was so high that virtually no one bought it, and eventually they dropped it.

The key to the popularity of this as an option for Ford will depend heavily on the price. How many people who regularly tow trailers or boats really can't manage the trailer and will pay whatever it costs for their truck to manage the trailer for them? Ford spokesman Mike Levine told us it will be an option for every F-150 model (XL, XLT, Lariat, King Ranch, and Platinum), as an added-cost option for F-150s equipped with the Trailer Tow package. Pricing won't be announced until later this summer. The Trailer Tow package costs $695 on the 2015 F-150.

In my mind, this cool feature is for someone who has an occasional need to tow a trailer or a boat or a mobile home and feels uncomfortable with the somewhat complicated task of backing up a large vehicle that is attached to another large vehicle.  I don't imagine any Bass Pro Tour fishermen feeling they need to buy it, but for the rest of us, this is brilliant.

Notable options on this model: LED foglamps, rearview camera, remote start (part of Driver Convenience package, $1,695); Navigation, HD and SiriusXM radio (part of Uconnect Navigation package, $995)
You might also be considering: 2015 Toyota Avalon, 2015 Chevrolet Impala, 2015 Hyundai Genesis, 2015 Kia Cadenza, 2015 Nissan Maxima (all prices include destination charges)

Postmodern art and minimalist design are all well and good. Comic-book colors and bulbous designs have their place. But there are still people out there who maintain a classic, old-school aesthetic, the kind of people who read Traditional Home and appreciate simple lines and elegance. The Chrysler 300 Limited is for those people. This full-size sedan’s appearance is the very definition of a formal design: upright, gracious, yet indulgent. Like me.
It’s something you don’t see enough of these days, an American rear-wheel-drive full-size sedan. (They’re just more fun to drive, in a Smokey and the Bandit kind of way.)

This is Chrysler’s flagship, slotting in above the new-for-2015 Chrysler 200. It’s something you don’t see enough of these days, an American rear-wheel-drive full-size sedan. (They’re just more fun to drive, in a Smokey and the Bandit kind of way.)

Yes, this car’s overall design is about ten years old, but it’s still head-turning. Chrysler has updated it for 2015 with a larger grille—still nowhere near as extreme as say, a Lexus—and a few other upgrades. But if you like your cars classic and sophisticated, this car will appeal to you as much today as it probably did in 2005.

There’s a range of 300 models to choose from: the 300 and 300 Limited, the luxurious 300C, and the top-end 300C Platinum. Then there’s the 300S, which I walked around with chief designer Ralph Gilles at the Los Angeles Auto Show last fall. “No other car has its profile,” he said, and he’s absolutely right.

The model we tested was the 300 Limited AWD, which as its name suggests had all-wheel drive. It comes with a 292-horsepower 3.6-liter V-6 and an eight-speed automatic transmission, and it was smooth, quiet, comfortable, yet missing very little in the testosterone department.

As for the 300S, it is powered by a 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 making 363 horsepower, and its eight-speed transmission has paddle shifters and a Sport mode. A deck-lid spoiler and blacked-out trim add an extra dab of macho appeal.
It feels almost impudent of me to say I would make a beeline for the Hemi, especially since the V-6-powered model has plenty of power to please just about everybody.

LED lighting is new for 2015, and so is a rotary dial transmission selector. I adjusted quickly to the dial, since it feels different enough from other controls. Shifting into Reverse shouldn’t feel exactly the same as tuning the radio or adjusting the A/C.
The elegance of the interior, all the way down to an analog clock on the dash, was complemented by a huge 8.4-inch touchscreen with Chrysler’s excellent, easy-to-use Uconnect infotainment system.
It comes with a 292-hp 3.6-liter V-6 and an eight-speed automatic transmission. It was smooth, quiet, comfortable, yet missing very little in the testosterone department.
A rearview camera is standard, and the Safetytec package ($1,695) adds blind spot and cross-path detection and a front and rear park assist system.

Other admirable exterior touches include the very cool shark-fin antenna atop the roof and the gleaming nineteen-inch polished aluminum wheels. It’s one of seven new wheel designs for 2015 that range from seventeen to twenty inches in diameter.

The 300 we tested had a classy black-and-linen interior with shiny black olive ash burled wood trim and charcoal metallic accents. Chrysler waxed lyrical with talk of “peaceful Zen” and using Sausalito, California, as the muse for this interior. It’s nice, but it’s a little less Zen and more Ralph Lauren if you ask me.

You can get the 300S with a black-and-blue Nappa leather interior with piano black and matte carbon accents. That one’s supposed to be Detroit inspired, which makes sense: a lot less Zen and a lot more badass. The 300C Platinum, the top-end luxury model, is available with an Indigo/Linen two-tone interior, high-end Italian Poltrona Frau leather trim, and hand-sanded natural-pore wood in a matte mocha finish. It’s a new day for Chrysler interiors.

The Verdict:

If you’re looking for a good old-fashioned big American sedan, but you want 2015 amenities, safety equipment, and fuel economy, the Chrysler 300 merits a serious look. It’s attractive enough that you’ll want to look twice at it anyway.

pageElements.text: It used to be the case that you’d have to wait for fall to go test drive the new models at the car dealership. Not anymore. Some of the earliest 2016 models are just starting to hit dealerships now, giving you an advance look on the safety technology and styling you’ll be seeing on the roads soon.

Interested in shopping for a new car—or just seeing what the automakers have thought of next? Here’s a selection of brand-new models. These are all vehicles you can go see at your local dealership and take a test drive between now and summer.  All prices are for the base model and include destination charge.

1. 2016 Volvo XC90

In dealerships: Spring 2015
Starting price: $49,895

2016 Volvo XC90 T8 Twin Engine Plug-In Hybrid

In dealerships: Viewing and test drives now; on sale in the fall
Starting price: $69,095

There’s no shortage of SUVs on the market, but this one is special, especially to people who are already Volvo fans. The proof? There have been 16,000 orders for Volvo’s all-new seven-passenger luxury SUV before it even hit showrooms. Late last fall, an online-only sale of 1,927 (for Volvo’s founding date) individually numbered First Edition models sold out in 47 hours.

As you’d expect from Volvo, there’s a standard City Safety package, with two world-first features that can help prevent common accidents by warning the driver and applying brakes to avoid a crash, or at least to reduce its severity.

The interior is luxurious beyond any previous Volvo with every version getting standard leather seats, real wood trim, navigation system, panoramic sunroof, and full-size adult seating all the way to the third row.

Even more exciting, Volvo’s bringing a plug-in hybrid version, which it bills as the world’s first seven-passenger entry in that category. The XC90 T8 Twin Engine’s electric-only range is seventeen miles—then it automatically switches to the supercharged and turbocharged 2.0-liter engine, which makes 394 horsepower and can take you from 0 to 60 mph in 5.7 seconds. All that, and a hand-blown Orrefors crystal gearshift knob. Look out, Tesla.

2. 2016 Honda HR-V

In dealerships: May 15
Starting price: $26,720

Sport-utility vehicles started big, but these days, crossover vehicles are getting more compact and citified. Honda is rolling out this brand-new one, smaller than the extremely popular CR-V, to face off against subcompacts like the Buick Encore, Kia Soul, and Nissan Juke. It has a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine making 141 horsepower, teamed with a continuously variable automatic transmission.

The HR-V’s strongest suit is how much stuff you can fit inside it. Fuel economy is admirable at 28 mpg in the city, 35 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive version. You get 32 mpg on the highway even if you choose the all-wheel-drive version. All that, and the clean looks and quality reputation of a Honda.

3. 2016 Scion FR-S

In dealerships: June 11
Starting price: $26,075

Toyota’s youth-oriented division has improved its FR-S sport coupe for 2016 without completely overhauling it. A rearview camera is now standard, and so is a seven-inch infotainment touchscreen with audio and voice recognition. This car is for people who love to drive, so it comes standard with a six-speed manual transmission, but you can get a six-speed automatic with paddle shifters and Dynamic Rev Management for an extra $1,100. Two new colors, Ablaze (red) and Oceanic (blue), update the FR-S for the new model year.

On September 1, you may want to go back to your Scion dealer to see two brand-new models, the 2016 iA sedan--Scion’s first--and iM hatchback. The iA will start around $16,000 and the iM will be priced starting under $20,000.

4. 2016 Fiat 500X

In dealerships: Early summer
Starting price: $20,900

If you think the Fiat 500 is cute but maybe a little too small for your needs, you might be interested in the all-new 500X. This is a front-wheel-drive crossover vehicle that seats up to five and is available with all-wheel drive (a $1,900 option). There are Trekking and Trekking Plus versions that look more like little SUVs, as well as Pop, Easy, and Lounge models that carry the Fiat 500’s Italian city-car styling into the bigger body style. All come with a turbocharged 160-horsepower, 1.4-liter engine with a six-speed manual transmission, or an optional 180-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder teamed with a nine-speed automatic transmission.

There’s a full slate of optional safety features to explore on the 500X, including forward collision warning with full stop, lane departure and blind spot monitoring systems, and rear cross-path detection.

The Dodge Journey is a crossover/sport-utility vehicle that seats five or seven, gets up to 26 mpg, and tows as much as 2,500 pounds. With the available 3.6-liter V-6 making 283 horsepower, it’s more powerful than the competition. But more than anything, it represents a good value. Start with the Journey AVP (American Value Package) for $21,290. The long list of standard convenience features includes keyless entry with push-button start, dual-zone climate control, a USB port, and an auxiliary input jack. Then there are the abundant driver assistance and safety features: traction control, brake assist, and active front head restraints among them. The Journey AVP options packages bring more advanced connectivity as well as three-zone climate control and adaptable seating, all without driving the price too high. When compared with the more expensive compact crossovers, though, the Journey is behind the times with the standard powertrain. Not that the 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine isn’t up to snuff, but we look for a six-speed automatic instead of the four-speed automatic found here—especially because this rig weighs in at a thumping 3,818 pounds. (The V-6 with six-speed automatic and all-wheel drive weighs 4,238.) For 2015, the Journey Crossroad, which has a rugged off-road look, is outfitted with black nineteen-inch alloy wheels and leather-trimmed seats with mesh inserts and gray stitching. Exterior accents are platinum chrome, while touches of “liquid graphite” highlights the interior.

New for 2015

The Journey Crossroad has leather seats with sport mesh inserts and unique exterior details and nineteen-inch wheels. Billet Silver Metallic and Blue Streak Pearl are new body colors.
