Nothing else in the marketplace quite compares to the Dodge Charger, a large sedan driven by the rear wheels (all-wheel drive is available) and offering amazing performance. It presents the classic argument against prestige brands costing far more. With its supercharged 6.2-liter V-8 generating an almost inconceivable 707 horsepower, the new Charger SRT Hellcat will reach 204 mph. Dodge says it’s the world’s quickest, fastest, most powerful sedan. Even lesser models like the SRT 392 and R/T Scat Pack boast 485 horsepower from their 6.4-liter V-8.

Meanwhile, the list of improvements throughout the lineup shows the Dodge brand’s increasing sophistication. Designers have streamlined the Charger and added LED lighting front and rear, and inside the cabin, the instrument panel now has a seven-inch TFT information display. All models come with an eight-speed automatic transmission, which is operated by an electronic shifter (paddle shifters in top performance models). Electrically assisted power steering offers Normal, Comfort, and Sport modes, as conditions warrant. Buying an SRT model makes you eligible for the SRT Track Experience to explore your car’s potential. A suite of driver assistance and safety features is available. Heated front seats are standard on most models. The optional ten-speaker audio system yields in SRT models to the nineteen-speaker Harman Kardon orchestra. Given the performance potential and value equation, it’s hard to think of a direct competitor for the Charger, and owners can always brag about their edge over much more expensive cars.

The 707-horsepower, Charger SRT Hellcat, 485-horsepower SRT 392, R/T Scat Pack, eight-speed automatic transmission standard on all models, new wheels on all models.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The 2016 Chevrolet Cruze will not be in showrooms until early 2016, but, like the plethora of presidential candidates we're already seeing, it has hit the campaign trail a little bit early. That gives General Motors plenty of time to trumpet the attributes of its number-one-selling vehicle worldwide. It is especially important to hit the ground running, since a new Honda Civic is making its debut later this year.
GM is touting 40 mpg highway, which beats the current segment leaders, the Toyota Corolla and the Honda Civic, and the manual will most likely get even better numbers.

The all-new Cruze is downright handsome. It is longer, lighter, and lower than its predecessor. Dropping 250 pounds and gaining 2.7 inches in length from the previous generation created a sportier, more aerodynamic silhouette. There will be four trim levels, including the top-of-the-line Premier. Two of the new inches are given to rear-seat legroom. Thank you, Chevrolet, because I found the back seat in the 2015 model unbearable for an adult passenger.

Speaking of the interior, it is not only roomy; it is good-looking, and the two-tone Premier package is near perfect, further proof that Chevrolet has cleaned up its interiors. The Cruze follows the same design direction of dual cockpits, clean dash, and upgraded materials that the Camaro, Spark, Volt, and Malibu ushered in earlier this year.

The all-new 1.4-liter Ecotec turbocharged engine, paired with a six-speed manual transmission, is standard. However, most buyers will opt for the six-speed automatic transmission. Stop/start technology will be standard. This fuel-efficient feature allows the engine to shut down when the car is at rest (such as at a stoplight) and magically start again when the accelerator is pressed. GM is touting 40 mpg highway, which beats the current segment leaders, the Toyota Corolla and the Honda Civic, and the manual will most likely get even better numbers. Diesel fans will have to wait until 2017, in the U.S. at least, when GM says it's bringing out a new clean diesel. Meanwhile, the 2015 Cruze does still come as a diesel.

Tech geeks will appreciate the new MyLink display. The standard 7.0-inch touchscreen will work with both Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, and there will be an optional eight-inch display available. Both systems work seamlessly to allow approved apps to display on the touchscreen. The apps are selected by the individual systems with an eye toward discouraging distracted driving.  Many Apple owners I know will now demand this on any car they will consider. Every Cruze will have 4G LTE Wi-Fi, becoming very common on GM products, which allows subscribers to connect up to seven wireless devices to the Internet while the car is on the road. This should be adequate for a five-passenger compact car!
There will also be an option for wireless charging. Now that is progress.
Since 34 percent of Cruze buyers are under thirty-five, GM understands that smartphone integration is essential. There will also be an option for wireless charging. Now that is progress.

Continuing the attention to technology, Chevrolet has stuffed optional advanced safety features into the Cruze, such as Side Blind Zone Alert, Rear Cross-Traffic Alert, Lane Keep Assist, and Forward Collision Alert. To attract the buyers in the colder climates, there will be optional front and rear heated seats and one of my favorite features, a heated steering wheel. Just a few years ago these technologies were only available on luxury vehicles, but they are now trickling down to the entry-level models.

The trunk will be huge. It will not only easily swallow up luggage for a family of four but also easily held automotive journalist David Zenlea. I believe he could have invited a friend in for a snuggle, but we were trying to keep it G rated. Now we just have to wait to get behind the wheel to predict whether the Cruze will get our vote.

The Hyundai Genesis is three cars in one: a slinky, sporty, affordable rear-wheel-drive coupe; a near-luxury sedan with available V-8 power; or, in either body shape, a capable all-wheel-drive climate conqueror. The standard engine is a potent, direct-injection 3.8-liter V-6 that produces 348 horsepower. In the agile Genesis Coupe, a 6-speed manual transmission is standard; the Ultimate’s available 8-speed automatic has a performance-oriented rev-matching feature for smooth downshifts. All-wheel drive is an option with the V-6 in either body style. But in the sedan, our experience leads to a preference for the smooth, powerful V-8 in the sedan. In size and level of specification, the Genesis falls just short of the top-of-the-line Hyundai Equus. It’s not quite cavernous inside, like the Equus, but it’s roomier than most of its direct competitors. The interior is gorgeous with available matte wood trim, aluminum accents, and leather upholstery that will continually delight. The Sedan 5.0 has standard heated and cooled front seats. (Heated rear seats are only available in the Sedan 3.8 with all-wheel drive, which also can be ordered with a heated steering wheel.) And of course, there are audio speakers and safety features galore. The Genesis is a very special car, a good value, but just a bit less prestigious than its competitors.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Some people think of mid-size sedans like the 2016 Mazda 6 and its competitors as boring. Maybe it’s just because you see them everywhere. One in every seven new vehicles sold is a mid-size sedan, and there are actually a lot of great choices: the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord, Ford Fusion, Nissan Altima, Chrysler 200, and Chevrolet Malibu, among others. It’s true, they’re not sports cars, and when you grow up, get married, maybe have some children, you might think you have to settle for something a little more….practical.
Or do you?

Into this group slots the Mazda 6, which is one of the best-kept automotive secrets. (Car and Driver even recently named it one of the 10 Best Cars That Nobody Buys.) Introduced as Mazda’s top-level sedan in 2012, the Mazda 6 has been newly updated and restyled for 2016, and it’s a beauty. In fact, I’d go so far as to say that it’s the mid-size sedan to look at first if you want practicality that still sets your heart aflutter.

Because really, just one look at this sedan tells you that it has been unfairly ignored by the buying public. Mazda only sold 53,224 of them in 2014 in the United States. To compare the big sellers of the segment, Toyota Camry sales in the U.S. in 2014 were 404,484, including fleet and individual sales. Honda Accord sales were 360,089 in the same period.

Why is the Mazda 6 not a big seller? It’s not price: the base model, the Sport, starts at $22,315, undercutting many of its rivals by several hundred dollars. Even the top-of-the-line 2016 Mazda 6 Grand Touring starts at a reasonable $31,015. (All prices include destination charge.) The one we tried was the mid-level Touring, which came with only three minor options: the Soul Red paint color ($300), cargo mats ($75), and door-sill trim plates ($125). For its as-tested price just over $25,000, you get such high-end amenities as a seven-inch touchscreen display, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, LED taillights, a rearview camera, blind spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert, all standard.

And then there’s the design. This new model made its debut at the Los Angeles Auto Show last November, showing the latest version of Mazda’s “Kodo: Soul of Motion” design philosophy. Put simply, “Kodo” refers to the moment that energy turns into motion. Look at the sides of the Mazda 6: do you see that dynamic crossing sweep of lines, feeding from the rear haunches into the arching front fenders? Where many other sedans are competent, even attractive, this one has a beautiful, balanced energy.

On a more practical level, the Mazda 6 suffers a little from a lack of power. Carried over from the 2015 model year, its 2.5-liter four-cylinder makes 184 horsepower, decent but not brilliant. Its six-speed automatic transmission is a carry-over, too. But our test car’s six-speed manual allowed us to get the most excitement from the engine in every gear.
Unlike several competitors (Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Hyundai Sonata, Ford Fusion), Mazda offers no hybrid or plug-in electric version.
Just one look at this sedan tells you that it has been unfairly ignored by the buying public.

What the numbers don’t show is how well Mazda’s Skyactiv technology makes every system in the car work together to get the most out of them all. The result is a wonderful balance that you feel when you drive this car. I drove hundreds of miles in the Mazda 6 in one sitting and could have driven hundreds more.

You feel that great balance when you sit inside, too. Updates to the cabin for 2016 included better sound insulation for a quieter ride, a dashboard that’s totally new and opens up space in the cabin, an electric parking brake to replace the old manual hand brake—a first for a Mazda—and even a new off-white leather option as an alternative to an attractive but more commonplace-looking black interior.
The exterior includes a new grille and a set of nineteen-inch aluminum wheels with a darker high-gloss paint.

Standard safety features are carried over from the 2015 model year. On the 2016 Touring model, these include six airbags, a rearview camera, anti-lock brakes, dynamic stability control, traction control, rear cross-traffic alert, and a blind spot monitoring system. On the Grand Touring model, there’s an optional Technology package ($1,675). It includes Smart Brake Support, which helps to avoid frontal collisions at medium to high speeds, and adaptive headlights. The Technology package also includes fuel-saving i-Eloop regenerative engine braking, which boosts fuel economy to 28 mpg city/40 mpg highway. It’s worthwhile, but it also requires you to select the moonroof/Bose audio/satellite radio package at an added $1,325, taking this car up to a loftier price point.

Infotainment and connectivity are important to anyone buying a new car these days. The ability to use infotainment without distraction is essential, and Mazda Connect offers that. The Mazda 6’s seven-inch touchscreen stands up above the dash, with bright and easy-to-use icons across the bottom of the screen for the passenger (or parked driver) to access. Steering-wheel-mounted controls let you manage the radio, smartphone, and navigation functions while you’re driving. Navigation, though, is standard only on the top Grand Touring model.

But the bottom line is, what are you looking for in a sedan? If you choose one of the really big sellers, nobody would blame you. But if you do that without getting behind the wheel of this one and taking it out for a drive, just to see if it fits you the way it totally fit me, you might end up blaming yourself.

title: 8 Apps to Road-Trip Like a Boss
subTitle: Just about all you need is a smartphone, and you're ready for whatever happens out there.

metaTitle: 8 Apps to Road-Trip Like a Boss - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Just about all you need is a smartphone, and you're ready for whatever happens out there.

pageElements.text: One of the best things about the modern road trip is how much you can do with your smartphone or tablet to make it go more smoothly. All it takes is a few quick downloads from your App Store or Google Play account, and off you go. We’ve chosen eight practical apps that will help make a road trip work for you. While some are well known, there are a few new or unusual apps on this list.

Using them, you can hit the open road, confident that you’ll be able to find a restaurant, hotel, swimming hole, and cheap fuel all along the way. All but one are free of charge, which is even better.

1. Urgent.ly

Available for: iOS 7.0 or later
Android

PRO: This is a kind of Uber for road service, especially a good idea for those in major metropolitan areas.. If you aren’t a person who already has any kind of road service membership (AAA or similar), this could be a lifesaver. This app will get someone to help you with a dead battery, lockout, or empty gas tank, and let your smartphone show you the progress of your savior service vehicle as it makes its way to you, for prices starting at $75.

Bonus for parents: if your teen or college student gets in a jam, he or she can use the app, and the FamilyView feature will alert you, get road service to your kid, and charge your credit card. Then you can observe the rescue from your phone and get a confirmation that service is complete.

CON: Of course, you can also get your kid an Associate Membership through AAA. AAA memberships vary by region, but a basic road service membership is generally under $70 per year, and an associate membership tends to be around an additional $15 per year, with some special promotions available. Check those prices before you download the app.

Click here to find out where service is available.

2. Dark Sky

Available for:
iOS 7.0 or later

PRO: This app leverages the newest iPhone’s barometer function to crowd-source accurate weather information. It’s kind of addictive to open it and get an instant forecast for your exact location, right down to whether rain will be light or heavy and when it will start and end. More traditional forecasts for the coming seven days are also on there, as are weather maps, and you can sign up for instant text alerts about weather problems or daily summaries at 7 a.m. You can also look up weather elsewhere and click on recommendations for things like “interesting storm in Battle Creek, Iowa.”

Most fun of all, you can report your take on the current weather to help improve accuracy for others. On a road trip, this is a fine way to get a read on what the weather is going to do where you are—and of course where you’re headed.

CON: So far, this app is only for Apple products (iPhone and iPad), not Android. It’s also not free, but the $3.99 price is justified on entertainment value alone or if you are any kind of weather buff.

3. GasBuddy

Available for:
iOS 6.0 or later
Android
Windows Phone
BlackBerry

PRO: This is one of the all-time favorite apps drivers use in the car. There’s practically unlimited information about fuel prices, where the gas stations are, and what kind of fuel you can get for what price. You can sort by regular, midgrade, premium, and—brilliant for those who are always looking for a place to buy it—diesel fuel. Plus, you can get this for the dinosaur phone systems, Windows Phone and BlackBerry.

CON: Not the prettiest, cleanest, or most modern interface for your phone; you’ll be wading through extraneous stuff. It has a bit of a carnival/cheap video-game feeling to it, with mixed-in ads and persistent giveaway offers for $100 of free gasoline. There’s a Leaderboard and Challenges where you win points if you report prices wherever you go. If you want to feel festive while you look for gas, this messy app will work for you.

4. Gas Guru

Available for:
iOS 7.0 or later
Android

PRO: Developed by the Yellow Pages people, Gas Guru has been freshly updated for the Apple iOS format, with clean lines and attractive, high-quality graphics. This app will find you the best gas prices wherever you travel, color coded from highest to lowest, in map or list form. It’s basic, simple, and gives you a lot of station choices. You can also search for diesel as well as regular, midgrade, and premium gasoline.

CON: Unlike the more interactive Gas Buddy, you can’t give your own direct commentary about gas prices you’ve found. Then again, this one is very simple to use, a good tradeoff.

5. iExit

Available for:
iOS 6.0 or later
Android

PRO: This app helps you figure out when you’ll next come to a Bob Evans, a veterinarian, a grocery store, or a rest area. It will show you up to 100 exits ahead of you on your route and let you search for deals and promotions on hotels and restaurants—and will let you choose and save your favorites so you don’t miss any Waffle Houses on the horizon. You can plan ahead by searching a highway you’re not currently on. It’s also free, while a competitor, The Next Exit, charges a $14.95 annual subscription fee.

CON: With construction being what it is, it’s hard to keep up with what you might find as you drive America’s highways. Although we didn’t try this app on an extended road trip, and although it was just updated in March, an app with this much information puts you at the risk that some of it might become outdated quickly. So use this not as gospel, but to supplement your eyes and ears—and your vehicle’s navigation system.

6. Waterkeeper Swim Guide

Available for:
iOS 5.0 or later
Android

PRO: If you’re headed for some of the world’s finest beaches and water areas, this is a good dreaming, planning, and navigating guide. It offers information for beaches from Goose Bay, Newfoundland, to Cabo San Lucas, Baja California, along with historical and visitor information. You can click on an “I’m Here” box to post your location on social media. The very best feature is “Current Status,” which tells you whether the water is rated safe for swimming. Information we checked out for the beaches near us had been updated within the past few hours.
CON: Every beach, everywhere, is not on the app, so this should not be your sole guide to places for swimming or boating. Check out your destination before you go to make sure it’s included.

7. Kayak

Available for:
iOS 7.1 or later
Android

PRO: There are many apps to find a hotel or a flight, but this one has been our longtime pick for a clean interface and a comprehensive set of results. You can track a flight, get price alerts, and find hotels, flights, and rental cars just about anywhere. Best of all, you can compare a huge number of choices easily.

CON: If you want a simple app, this isn’t it. This is an app for shopping only. You are routed over to complete a booking through another source such as Priceline.com, Booking.com, Hotels.com, and Hotwire.com. If you have a favorite among those, you might want to start there instead.

8. Hotels.com

Available for:
iOS 7.0 or later
Android
Windows Phone
Amazon Kindle Fire

PRO: Among the many choices for booking a hotel, we’ve found this one is straightforward and easy to use. You can set up your account and credit card details (or PayPal) and book easily from your phone, even for same-day bookings. The app, compared with the website, claims to offer “Your Secret Price” deals. You can also accumulate rewards points for repeated stays using the app. Unlike some other hotel apps with limited selections, this one will give you a true variety of choices from el cheapo to high luxury. It also can be downloaded to a Kindle Fire as well as for Windows Phone.
CON: If you want to find anything besides lodging, this app doesn’t have it; the name says it all.

subTitle: A well-appointed compact SUV.

promoTeaser: A well-appointed compact SUV.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive mid-size sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $24,995–$38,165 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SLE-1, SLE-2, SLT-1, SLT-2, and Denali
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.4-liter, FWD: 23 mpg city/32 mpg highway; 2.4-liter, AWD: 20/29 mpg; 3.6-liter, FWD: 17/24 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 16/23 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hot spot
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Rear-seat entertainment system available in the SLT-2
You might also be considering: Ford Edge, Hyundai Santa Fe Sport, Mitsubishi Outlander

This popular compact SUV is an entry level to what GMC calls its “professional grade design.” The result is a tough-looking vehicle with an oversized grille and squared-off edges. Inside, the Terrain is practical but loaded with available technology like a 7-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, music streaming capability, and Siri Eyes Free. OnStar with 4G LTE and standard built-in Wi-Fi hotspot is standard in 2015. The antenna is built into the Terrain’s body for a better connection than your phone and it can connect up to seven devices in or near the car, making road trip boredom a thing of the past. The Terrain’s Denali edition adds a chrome grille, body-color front fascias, and unique 18-inch wheels. Contrast stitching, a soft-touch instrument panel, and smoked mahogany wood accents dress up the cabin.

The crew will be comfy in the back, too. The MultiFlex rear seat system lets you easily arrange the back to suit your passengers or cargo. It splits 60/40, reclines, and slides almost eight inches, giving rear-seat passengers almost 40 cubic inches of legroom. Dual 8-inch flip-up LCD screens will keep that crew amused—even playing video games if that’s what it takes. Terrain is offered in front-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive models.

New for 2015

OnStar with 4G LTE and a Wi-Fi hotspot. Two new exterior colors: Dark Sapphire Blue Metallic and Cypress Green Metallic.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: For me, last weekend began in Detroit before the weekend even started, and ended in San Francisco a few days after the weekend was over.

First came the Motorsports Hall of Fame, a black-tie event in downtown Detroit. I was a guest of Toyota, which has a rich racing history, the pinnacle of which may not have been inviting me to race in the Pro/Celebrity Race preceding the 1987 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach. Woody Harrelson (shown here) was the most amusing celebrity. He crashed a racing car while learning to drive it at Willow Springs, rolling the car nine times and ending up in the hospital. I had to break him out through the maternity ward and drive him to L.A. with his broken arm and bloody eye to finish that season of Cheers.

Just coincidentally, Parnelli Jones (here in Detroit to usher his old friend Walker Evans into the Hall of Fame) was also in that race. He actually charged up from thirty seconds behind the celebs and crashed into the back of me when I missed a shift in the hairpin while running sixth. He passed but couldn’t catch Jason Bateman, then eighteen years old, who won the race. At the awards ceremony, where I spontaneously roasted every one of them whilst wearing a strapless pink satin minidress, Parnelli announced, “If I'd a known you had them legs, you never would have made it around America.”
Click here to understand that particularly prurient reference.

Back to the Hall of Fame. Walker Evans was there in full force with family, crew, and Sarah Palin. That’s right, Sarah Palin. She was there for Walker. “We hunt and fish together,” he said, introducing her to me. “Sarah, this is Jean Lindamood,” he said. “She’s a real character.” “I can tell by looking at her,” she shot back.
Was it the hat?
Well, I’m here to tell you that Sarah was totally hot, much tinier than Tina Fey, and with even better hair. I felt kind of like a boy next to her. A boy in an orange dress and red hat.

Wearing an orange dress and red hat sort of backfired when I decided to slink out early. Between laudatory comments and amusing anecdotes from the presenters, grateful thanks and amusing anecdotes from the inductees, historic film clips of each inductee, and a few speeches by ancillary racing luminaries, there was no reason to believe my chariot wasn’t going to turn into a pumpkin before I got out of there. The long drive ahead of me won out over my love of all those racing heroes in one place, and not just those being inducted: my race queen heroine Linda Vaughn, Indy driver Lyn St. James, the incomparable Bobby and Donnie Allison, David Hobbs, and more. Deepest apologies.

Saturday was a thrilling day because we bought a new car from our friends at Williams AutoWorld in Lansing, Michigan! I hinted that this would happen when I reviewed the 2015 Volkswagen Golf SportWagen for Jean’s Driveway here. But The Husband perhaps rushed it. Do you think he could have waited a few months so we could bask in the warm glow of NO MONTHLY CAR LOAN?? No, he couldn’t. But I have to say, isn’t this blue pretty?

Tim Jennings’s M.O. is to buy his vehicles with nada, zippo, no options. But you can’t argue the deal here. On its way to replacing the Jetta model with the Golf, Volkswagen made the sheetmetal more expressive, modernized the lamps, added push-button start and remote keyless entry, and added a really crisp rearview camera. I am entranced by it. The big news (next to the rearview camera) is that the turbo-diesel version is $2,000 less than our Jetta cost.
The Bluetooth paired my phone faster, but I swear that the lady inside who’s running voice recognition is slow and kind of stupid.

Although we never buy optional equipment, our new Golf ended up with rubber TDI floor mats ($235) and a roadside assistance kit ($85) which has first aid kit, jumper cables, and other emergency equipment in a zippered bag that Velcros to the cargo area wall.
It also comes with that familiar VW interior smell that never goes away.

I drove it home, added the new car payment back into the monthly budget, and toasted old friend Annie Forgione, who bought our beloved Jetta, exactly the car she wanted, complete with six-speed manual.

Two days later, I was winging my way to San Francisco to spend one very long day being blown away by what is happening at the speed of light within the Ford Motor Company’s Palo Alto research facility. We’ve been rolling out the stories (like this one on the 2016 F-150's Pro Trailer Backup Assist, and this one on the MyFord Mobile app), with more to come, so come on back!

Love,
Jean

title: Cars' Child Safety LATCH: Big Fail
subTitle: They're too hard to use, Insurance Institute test shows. What parents need to know before car shopping.
promoTitle: Cars' Child Safety LATCH: Big Fail
promoTeaserSmall: They're too hard to use, Insurance Institute test shows. What parents need to know before car shopping.
promoTeaser: They're too hard to use, Insurance Institute test shows. What parents need to know before car shopping.
keywords: Cars' Child Safety LATCH: Big Fail
metaTitle: Cars' Child Safety LATCH: Big Fail - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: They're too hard to use, Insurance Institute test shows. What parents need to know before car shopping.

pageElements.text: If you have children using car seats, you are quite familiar with the LATCH system that makes it easy to correctly attach a child safety seat into the back seat of your vehicle. These pieces of hardware have been required in vehicles and on child seats since 2002. You’d think automakers would have perfected them by now.

But you’d be wrong. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety issued the results of its first sweeping test of the LATCH systems in 100 2015 model cars, and the result was a big Fail. Only three vehicles got the top Good rating, and they’re not the ones you might have guessed. The Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class, the BMW 5 Series, and the Volkswagen Passat (pictured here) were the winners, while forty-four vehicles got a lower rating of Acceptable, forty-five were ranked Marginal, and ten were rated as Poor.
IIHS is not claiming that the LATCH hardware is going to break off or fail, just that it could be so frustrating to use that parents won't want to use it properly.

The ratings are based on ease of use for the owner. IIHS is not claiming that all those vehicles have hardware that is going to break off or fail, just that it could be so frustrating to use that parents will be at risk of not installing the seat safely.

Vehicles are required to have at least two rear seats with the full set of LATCH hardware and at least one tether anchor in a third spot. As someone who once had three car seats in her vehicle, I applaud that regulation. And I am well aware that two out of three car seats are not installed correctly, in part because it’s so #)$_*(#$) hard to get those seats in the car nice and tight.

The most commonly cited problem in the IIHS evaluation is that the lower anchors are too deeply embedded in the seat, making it hard to reach and use them. There are lower anchors where the seatback and bottom seat cushion meet. Then there’s a top tether that attaches the top of the car seat to an anchor, which can be on the rear shelf, the seatback, the floor, the cargo space, or even the ceiling of the vehicle.

IIHS marked vehicles down if it took too much force to attach a child seat to the lower anchors, if the anchors were too challenging to reach, work with, and maneuver around. To see how the ratings work, check out the ratings page for the Toyota Sienna—a family-oriented vehicle if there ever was one, and already named a IIHS Top Safety Pick Plus for its crashworthiness.

Inconvenient child seat tethers won’t be a deal breaker for a car shopper, but knowing this information is essential when you’re shopping for a new vehicle, if you plan to use child seats. Here’s a reminder to check IIHS data, but also to take your own child seat to the dealership and try to put it in the car. This report is sure to influence automakers to consider changes to how they fit LATCH hardware into future models, which is good for you, your kids, and your hands that may no longer have to struggle to get the seat installed properly.

title: 2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible
subTitle: How much of a family car can this cute droptop be? I checked that out.
promoTeaserSmall: How much of a family car can this cute droptop be? I checked that out.
promoTeaser: How much of a family car can this cute droptop be? I checked that out.
metaDescription: How much of a family car can this cute droptop be? I checked that out.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text:
2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible 1.8T

Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact convertible
Base price: $26,415 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Models available: 1.8T, 1.8T with Technology, 1.8T with Sound and Navigation, R-Line, Convertible Classic, TDI (diesel)
A convertible is the hallmark of being footloose and fancy free, but can it also be family friendly?

Road noise, perceived rollover risk, smaller trunks and cabins, and let’s face it, sunburn are among the many reasons that a convertible often isn’t a family’s daily driver. But with advancements in cabin acoustics, increased safety regulations and one-touch power opening and closing, it’s never been easier to drop the top of a convertible, and occupants have never been more protected. Is it time for families to take a look at convertibles when shopping for a new car?
Before automatically dismissing this as a pipe dream that only starlets get to live out, consider this: convertibles are among the least expensive vehicles on the market to insure.

Russ Rader, senior vice-president of communications for the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS), explained the reason for the better policy pricing: convertibles tend to have lower incidents of accidents and bodily injury losses than their hard-topped counterparts. That’s in part because they’re often the third or fourth vehicle a family owns, which means they may spend most of the time parked in suburban garages, and they tend to be driven only on nice days. But many models are also fleet vehicles for car rental companies that see more than their fair share of abuse and miles on the road, and yet losses on even the convertible Mustang are lower than those of a two-door Honda Accord, according to IIHS.
There’s this overwhelming belief that they’re just not practical. To find out if this is the case, I spent a week with a silver 2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible.

These lower premiums could help offset the higher price that droptop models fetch compared with their conventional models. But cost isn’t the only factor making car buyers shy away from these vehicles as family cars; there’s this overwhelming belief that they’re just not practical. To find out if this is the case, I spent a week with a silver 2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible.

The VW Beetle Convertible wasn’t even on my radar as a car that I would consider; too frivolous, too compact. But the uber-cute car won me over with its sporting handling and an ample 180 horsepower from the base 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine. The trunk, at 7.1 cubic feet of cargo capacity, was still large and deep enough to fit my stroller even with the soft top tucked away. The vehicle seats only four, which is a drawback, but I can count on one hand the number of times I actually needed and used five seats in the three years I’ve owned my wagon.
With the top down, which lowers in an impressive 9.5 seconds, loading my tot in the car seat was never easier—no bumped heads!

The power one-touch open and close of the cloth droptop increased the compact’s versatility. I could start off a trip with the top down, and if the sun became too much or rain moved in, the top could be closed in just eleven seconds, and even while the vehicle is in motion (up to 31 mph, which I didn’t test). And with the top down, which lowers in an impressive 9.5 seconds, loading my tot in the car seat was never easier—no bumped heads!

But I never shook the discomfort of looking in the rear and noticing that there was no C-pillar to help protect her in side-impact crash or a rollover. Rather, there is an automatic rollover support system that would deploy high-strength steel bars that should protect the heads of all passengers in the event the system detects imminent rollover. There are other structural changes that VW made to the Beetle Convertible to offset its missing hard top, such as an A-pillar interior bar that is 0.5 mm thicker and made from ultra-high-strength hot-formed steel, and additional ultra-high-strength tubing between the B-pillars as well as a stronger heel plate.
Would this be enough to protect my toddler in the event of an accident?

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) gives the 2015 Volkswagen Beetle its top overall five-star safety rating, but the Beetle Convertible hasn’t been tested. Looking at injury losses for convertibles, Rader found that the Beetle Convertible tended to have lower collision losses than the hardtop model, but there isn’t enough data to determine if there are more or less injury losses because it hasn’t been available long enough. Over at the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, only two 2015 model convertibles were subjected to safety testing: the Volkswagen Eos and the Ford Mustang. Both received Good ratings in several areas, although Roof Strength, for obvious reasons, wasn't rated.

VW spokesperson Darryl Harrison pointed out to me that structural reinforcements around the doors improve rigidity of the body structure to compensate for not having a roof, and there’s a system that shuts off the fuel pump, unlocks the doors, and switches on the hazard lights if the car is involved in certain types of collisions. Unfortunately, while the hardtop model offers side airbags for the rear passengers, the convertible model has airbags only in the front. But at least for now my daughter would be protected by her car seat, which was easy to install with the Beetle Convertible's exposed latches, and fit snugly with zero wiggle.
When I think family friendly I imagine ample storage, rear-seat entertainment, cupholders integrated into the rear doors, and power liftgates, none of which this car had.

But is a four-seater convertible truly family friendly? When I think about what this term traditionally means in cars, I imagine ample storage, rear-seat entertainment systems, cupholders integrated into the rear doors so kids have easy access, and power liftgates, none of which this car had. But all the vehicles that had those features tended to be sedate and practical as mom jeans. Isn’t fun part of being family friendly? Isn’t that how good memories are created? If so, then a convertible offers that in spades, and should at least warrant a test drive when shopping for a new car.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: It’s a grim statistic we often read in the news but rarely apply to ourselves. Each year in the U.S., almost 33,000 Americans are killed in motor vehicle crashes, according to the U.S. Department of Transportation. Over this Fourth of July weekend, the National Safety Council estimates, there will be 409 deaths and 49,500 injuries out on the roads, the most since 2008. The bad news is that most crashes (57 percent) don’t even involve another vehicle, so there’s no one to blame but the driver who did it. The good news? The causes of most crashes are the result of personal choice. They’re behaviors that are largely within our control.
So if you’d rather die of natural causes, read up. There’s a lot you can do to avoid dying in a car accident.
Nationwide, almost three-quarters of fatally injured passenger vehicle drivers had a blood alcohol level higher than the legal limit. That’s sobering.

1. Don’t drink and drive.

There’s no doubt about it. A nice glass of pinot noir is a fine, fine thing. But don’t even think about raising a glass if you plan to drive. Even after a single drink, drivers begin to lose their sense of judgment and experience declines in their ability to track a moving object and to multitask. After two drinks, they are often less alert and less inhibited. And once they’ve reached the legal limit, or a blood alcohol content of .08? They’re a wobbly, dangerous mess. Nationwide, almost three-quarters of fatally injured passenger vehicle drivers had a blood alcohol level higher than the legal limit. That’s sobering.

2. Wear a seatbelt—even if you’re an adult sitting in the back seat.

Maybe you have a dog in your lap who is sitting on the seat belt fastener. Or maybe you just don’t want to wrinkle your clothes. But you should buckle up anyway. Victims in more than half of all fatal car accidents were not properly restrained by seatbelts. The National Safety Council says 155 lives will be saved over this Fourth of July weekend based simply on seatbelt use—and 99 more could be saved if every single person in a car had a seatbelt on.

You risk internal injuries when you put the shoulder strap anywhere but diagonally across your chest as intended. You risk sliding out of the belt if the lap belt is not snugly fastened. And don't let kids put the shoulder harness under their arms, which they often try to do. Take the time to adjust their seating positions until they are comfortable, and if you can't get the shoulder harness to fit as well as an adult's, they should still be in a booster.

3. Curb your speed.

Excess speed is a contributing factor in almost one-third of all fatal crashes. And it’s often associated with drinking—yet another reason to lay off the booze before getting behind the wheel. There's a reason safety groups call summer the deadliest 100 days of the year for driving. Slow down.

4. Avoid driving at night.

Driving in the dark is fraught with peril. Not only is it more difficult to see, there are more impaired drivers out on the roads. No wonder vehicle fatalities are three times higher at night than they are during the day, even though fewer drivers are sharing the road. If you absolutely must drive in the dark, be sure all your lights are working properly and increase your following distance behind other cars. And Saturday nights in the summer are the deadliest time of all; keep that in mind when you plan your driving.

5. Don’t text or talk on the phone while driving.

At any given time, 660,000 U.S. drivers are engaging with their cell phones or another electronic device while they are driving (according to NHTSA). About ten percent of motor vehicle fatalities are the result of this sort of distracted driving. Drivers under the age of twenty are especially susceptible, having the largest proportion of fatalities (27 percent) among drivers who were distracted at the time of the crash.

6. Avoid driving in bad weather.

Much like human bodies, weather comes in many forms. Wind, rain, snow, fog, and extreme temperatures all impair drivers’ abilities to maintain control of their vehicles. About a quarter of all traffic crashes in the U.S. are weather related, but rain is the most hazardous. If it’s pouring, and you can avoid it, don’t use your car as an umbrella. Leave it be until the weather clears.

7. Don’t drive drowsy.

Wake up. Almost one-third of drivers in a National Sleep Foundation poll reported having fallen asleep behind the wheel of a car. Many drivers who do so didn’t think they could fall asleep while driving, but if you’re tired and are yawning, blinking more than normal or otherwise having difficulty focusing, those could be signs that you should pull over and get some rest. Not to scare you, but the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety reported 21 percent of fatal accidents involved a drowsy driver--that's 6,400 a year. Don't be one of them.

title: What Are Young Drivers Most Afraid Of?

pageElements.text: Think about this while you're merging onto the freeway: the only thing that terrifies Millennials more than public speaking is seeing you driving next to them. Yes, you read that correctly; Millennials fear other drivers more than ghosts, snakes and even death.

As part of its Further with Ford technology initiative, Ford polled 1,000 members of Generation Z (ages sixteen to twenty-two) and Generation Y (ages twenty-three to thirty-four) this spring. The aim: to find out more about our fears, attitudes towards driving, and outlook on new technology in the car. Millennials’ anxiety towards driving—whether it’s parking, monitoring blind spots, or sharing the road with other drivers—may mean that majority of younger people (like me) will find it easy to get comfortable with driver-assist technologies.

As a nineteen-year-old, I immediately thought there's no way my generation worries this much about driving, but then I remembered I have not parallel parked since my driver’s test three years ago. To remedy my conflicting feelings, I did what any responsible and inquisitive young journalist would do: I asked my friends.

Nothing sends cold sweat down Allison Pfeiffer’s back quite like the on-ramp sign of a highway. At nineteen years old, Allison (pictured at top) has only driven on the highway once. “I have recurring nightmares about merging onto I-75,” Allison said. When I asked her to elaborate, she explained that driving straight into moving traffic unnerves her, and the idea of semi-trucks and larger vehicles cruising at 60 miles per hour in her general vicinity is just too much. Last week she used her GPS to find her way to a friend’s house, but when it suggested she take a highway, she pulled over and called her mom.
“Driving is scarier than spiders or snakes for me because if I get in an accident, it would be my fault,” Allison said.

“Driving is scarier than spiders or snakes for me because if I get in an accident, it would be my fault,” Allison said. All of the other friends I spoke to expressed similar sentiments, and I have to say I think Allison hit the nail on the head. According to Ford, 74 percent of Millennials fear death, 69 percent fear spiders, and 75 percent fear public speaking. In light of Allison’s remark, though, this data makes a bit more sense. If a ghost comes to haunt me or a spider bites me, I become a victim, not a guilty party. However, in the event of an accident, I face whatever physical damage occurs and a big steaming pile of responsibility.

So if fear of responsibility is fueling Millennials’ aversion to anxious-making driving situations, it stands to reason that parking would definitely create Level Ten nervousness. According to Ford, 57 percent worry about finding a parking spot, and 70 percent are concerned about getting into a tight space. To some degree, we all know the ritual that accompanies pulling into a tricky spot: gripping the wheel with white knuckles, inching along, silently praying you don’t hear the sound of side mirror on metal. My friend Katie drives a large SUV, so getting situated safely between those white lines is a major concern for her. “I’ll often park farther away from a restaurant or store if it means avoiding tight spots… or other cars in general,” Katie said.

This is where technology comes in. Ford just announced its decision to migrate the company’s driver-assist technologies across its product lineup over the next five years, which bodes well for the 52 percent of Millennials that would be as comfortable or more comfortable in a self-driving car than driving themselves. This technology would help with parallel parking and detection of objects in blind spots, among other functions.

My friend Gabe certainly doesn’t have a problem with tech in the car. He explained that driving is probably the most unsafe thing we do every day, so he would buy into any type of advances to make it easier and safer. In addition to appeasing these concerns, though, Gabe has even bigger dreams for automobile technology. “I want an Amazon Dash button in my car that knows my Chipotle order, and when I press it they make it at Chipotle, and my robot car drives me there,” Gabe said. He relishes the idea of sitting in the back seat, Driving Miss Daisy style, which makes sense given Gabe’s driving record. He described it as “not good.” In the past two years he has been involved in three accidents, two of which were with stationary objects.
After talking with me, Allison walked to her car. She left me with the following expression of her latest worry: “Let’s just hope I don’t hit a tree on the way home.” Well Allison, you’re not alone.

title: The New Alfa Romeos
subTitle: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one?
promoTeaserSmall: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one?
promoTeaser: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one?
metaDescription: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one? - JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: You wouldn't know it by reading car-enthusiast magazines, but it is actually not front-page headline news that Alfa Romeo is back in the U.S. market. If it’s caught your attention at all, it’s a good bet that it’s close to subliminal. Now that Alfa is bringing a sedan to join the sports-car 4C, maybe that will change.
Unless you're an Italian-car aficionado, you might wonder: What does Alfa Romeo have to do with me?

The answer to that is a function of how you feel about automobiles. Are they simply transportation, packaged in varying levels of utility, comfort, and efficiency? Or do you want a little more? Distinctive style? Passion?
Those are the elements that have been core traits of Alfa Romeos since 1910, when Anonima Lombarda Fabbrica Automobili was established in Milan, Italy.

But while style and passion have been consistent throughout this long history, quality and reliability have not, a weakness that eroded sales and eventually forced Alfa to fold its tent and withdraw from the U.S. market in 1995.
Now Alfa is back, a return that began last year and continues with a trickle of sports cars and anticipation of a new sedan, the Giulietta, that will reach U.S. showrooms in mid-2016.
Are either of these cars right for you? Let’s take a look.

Alfa Romeo Giulia

The name has hallowed roots in Alfa history, and a proper sedan is definitely something the make’s 120 U.S. dealers need to achieve black balance sheets. It’s also a car that will make a lot more sense to a much wider market than the passionate but hard-edged 4C sports car.

This is not to say that sport and passion won’t be part of the Giulia’s pedigree, particularly in the Quadrifoglio version you see here. It’s reflected in the sexy, skintight sheetmetal, the aggressive stance, the fat, low-profile Pirelli tires.
But four doors and a trunk add an element of practicality that’s obviously not part of the deal with the 4C.

Basics: the Giulia is truly all new—a new platform, which will see adaptations in other Alfas; new skin; and a new twin-turbocharged V6 engine, developed with input from Ferrari. Dimensional specifics were basically absent from Alfa’s presentation, held in the company’s superb museum in Milan, but the Giulia is about the size of a BMW 3-Series, a car that’s everyone’s sports sedan target.

With 503 horsepower on tap from the twin-turbo V6, Alfa is forecasting 0-to-62 mph (100 kilometers per hour) in 3.9 seconds, which is brisk, but perhaps conservative. With just 425 hp, the BMW M3 achieves about the same, and given Alfa’s attention to keeping weight as low as possible, the Quadrifoglio may well be quicker.

It’s also reasonable to expect that the Quadrifoglio's athletic credentials will, at a minimum, rival the moves of the M3, since the BMW was the prime development target. And it’s worth noting that fuel economy did not merit a mention in Alfa’s presentation. Nor was there any talk about autonomous operation; Alfas are all about driver gratification.
What about reliability and assembly quality, two elements that damaged Alfa’s appeal in the U.S. market, and ultimately led to its retreat? That’s obviously a wait-and-see, though it’s not unreasonable to assume that Alfa will be taking pains to make sure its new cars are as flawless as possible for U.S. customers.

The Giulia will be on sale in Europe this fall and will begin trickling into U.S. showrooms sometime in 2016, probably as a 2017 model. Pricing was not on the agenda at the Milan program, and with U.S. availability still a year away, we can only guess. Since the Giulia Quadrifoglio is targeted on the BMW M3, and M3 pricing currently starts at about $63,000, we can probably anticipate a base price of about $65,000.

If that sounds a little stiff, or the Quadrifoglio seems a little extreme, or both, there will be less exotic models following the hot rod, one with a non-turbo version of the V-6, another with a turbocharged four-cylinder engine, both with significantly lower prices. All-wheel drive will also be an option.
Looking further down the strada, the new platform that supports the Giulia will become the foundation for a crossover SUV, probably two years from U.S. availability.

Looking further down the strada, the new platform that supports the Giulia will become the foundation for a crossover SUV, probably two years from U.S. availability, and beyond that there will be other Alfas, still shrouded in secrecy. But we can say that Alfa Romeo is a premium brand, and that there won’t be any offerings aimed at competing with mainstream brands.
After all, style and passion have never been everyday commodities. A certain amount of exclusivity makes them more desirable.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cCPYmVZwXc4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Alfa Romeo 4C Coupe and Spider

The classic definition of a sports car is a topless two-seater that can be driven on the street but is also suitable for racing. Among contemporary automobiles, this definition is mitigated by concessions made to comfort, but the 4C makes fewer than most. Fewer, in fact, than any.

To review, the 4C is a carbon-fiber-intensive, rear-wheel-drive two-seater with an exceptionally rigid chassis, stiff suspension tuning, sticky tires, and powerful brakes. It’s propelled by a 1.7-liter engine, its diminutive displacement amplified by turbocharging to 237 horsepower.

That may not sound like much compared to the 275 hp of the basic Porsche Cayman, which is commonly mentioned as an alternative to the little Alfa coupe. But the Alfa weighs in at less than 2,500 pounds, putting the 4C coupe on an equal power-to-weight footing with the 3,000-pound Cayman.

Residing behind the passenger compartment, the little turbo engine sends power to the rear wheels via a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, one of those automated manuals the delivers lightning-fast shifts via steering column paddles. There is no manual transmission option, which has provoked some moaning from the enthusiast publications.
Distinguished by lots of exposed carbon fiber, the interior tends toward spartan and snug, with deeply bolstered seats designed to keep driver and passenger anchored during enthusiastic cornering.
My first look at the Spider was at the Detroit auto show last January, and more recently I logged some California seat time, including an afternoon at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, near Monterey.

Impressions that emerged were identical to an earlier experience with the 4C coupe. The Spider is just as quick—0 to 60 mph in less than 4.5 seconds—and just as nimble. Responses are just as eager, body roll is absent, and the steering—with no power assist—is racing-car quick and laser accurate.
The tires generate leech-like grip, and braking performance is formidable—minimal stopping distances, consistent stop after stop after stop.

The only real distinction between coupe and Spider—its removable roof panel makes it more of a targa than a true convertible—is that with the top open it’s even easier to hear the bark of the engine. Which is a long way of saying the 4C Spider can be even noisier than the coupe.

This brings us back to the issue of sports car purity. Coupe or Spider, the Alfa 4C has it double in spades, a car that’s an extension of the driver’s will and thrives on track days, autocross events, and roads with lots of twists and turns. The relationship between car and driver just doesn’t get any more intense than this.

On the other hand, the 4C’s ride quality is stiff, no one could call it roomy, infotainment is minimal (premium audio would be wasted here), there’s not much luggage space, it’s noisy, and getting in or out, though easier with the top open, requires contortions.

Coupe pricing starts at $55,195, similar to the Porsche Cayman, the Spider at $65,495, considerably more than the Porsche Boxster.
Alfa literature insists that the 4C has no real rival in its price class, and thus can’t really be compared to anything else. Given the car’s capabilities, there’s truth to this—it’s an exceptional hard core sports car, that turns heads wherever it goes.

But hard core can become a little tedious as a day to day driving experience. Anyone aspiring to 4C ownership would be well advised to have another car for everyday use. Also, that aspiration should be tempered with patience. Hand-built in Modena, Italy, the 4C’s production rate is essentially glacial; Alfa admits that assembly of the Spider consumes about six weeks.

Consider the 2015 Mercedes-Benz M-Class the goldilocks SUV of the upwardly mobile set. With this mid-size SUV, you can choose from a range of engine options to suit your needs, including a 3.0-liter V-6 turbo-diesel, a 4.6-liter V-8, or a 5.5-liter V-8. All are paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission. This five-seater is stocked with many premium features, such as the Comand infotainment system, heated front seats, a power liftgate, and crash avoidance technology. Features such as navigation, ventilated seats, park assist, adaptive high beams, and a 360-degree surround-view camera are optional. Its interior is roomy and spacious without overwhelming proportions, and no one in the rear feels cramped with 38.4 cubic inches of legroom and 58.4 cubic inches of shoulder room. The M-Class has ample storage in the cargo area with 38.2 cubic feet of capacity behind the second row. This model isn’t available with a third row like some of its competitors, but that's the only place you'll feel a limitation.

New for 2015

The ML250 BlueTec with a four-cylinder turbo-diesel replaces the ML350 BlueTec; the ML400 with twin-turbo V-6 replaces the ML550 with twin-turbo V-8.

The compact crossover market is facing stiff competition from this newcomer. The 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA is a nicely stocked pint-sized ute that offers many premium features as standard equipment to win buyers over. It’s ably powered by a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine with 208 horsepower and employs an automatic stop/start system to increase fuel economy without sacrificing performance. Legroom in the second row is tight at 33.9 cubic inches, but the tradeoff is more cargo room behind the second row than you’d expect to find in a small crossover: 11.8 cubic feet. And loading the GLA is easy thanks to a low lift-over height and power-operated liftgate—a welcome standard feature in the Mercedes version of an entry-level crossover.

The GLA-class is all new for 2015.

The 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class is proof that utilitarian can also be luxurious. It’s available in a range of engine options to suit your lifestyle, including a relatively economical 240-horsepower, 455 lb-ft turbo-diesel V-6, to a hand built 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 that produces 550 horsepower and 560 lb-ft of torque. Most buyers will probably opt for the more conventional twin-turbo V-6 or 4.7-liter V-8 that occupy the middle of the engine range. Regardless of which engine you choose, there will be plenty of power and torque to haul your family, its gear, and a sporting craft to any reasonable destination. The interior and cargo area are generous as well. It has three rows of seats and can seat up to seven. Legroom is mercifully spacious in every row of this luxury liner, with 40.3-, 38.5-, and 35.0-inches in the front, second, and third rows, respectively. Cargo capacity isn’t lacking despite its three-row configuration with 16 cubic feet of storage with all three rows in use and 49.4 cubic feet with the third row folded flat: plenty of room to tote around that double wide jogging stroller and the dog. True to its luxury brand, it’s well equipped with many standard creature comforts and safety features, such as heated front seats, the Comand infotainment system, a power liftgate, a drowsy driving warning system. Extras include parking assist, a panoramic sunroof, a heated steering wheel, surround-view camera, and most important, a rear-seat entertainment system, which is a good way to keep the cabin quiet so you can enjoy this SUV’s hushed ride.

New for 2015

The GL450 gets a twin-turbo 3.0-liter V-6 engine; stop/start is now standard on GL450 and GL63 AMG.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Ford Focus SE

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Base price: $19,285 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $21,970
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 26 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Chevrolet Cruze LS Automatic ($19,695)
2015 Honda Civic Sedan SE ($20,810)
2016 Hyundai Elantra SE Automatic ($18,250)
2015 Mazda 3 i SV ($18,815)
2015 Toyota Corolla LE ($19,390)

Fun-o-Meter: 6

Your heart isn’t pounding when you look at the simple, clean lines of this 2015 Ford Focus, is it? That’s okay. A compact car at a reasonable price, and one that gives you choices as to engine, body style, and amount of sportiness: such a car has enough to recommend it without trying to be sexy, too.

And yet, there is something quite sexy about being able to buy a new car in the $20,000-and-under range that doesn’t feel cheap. That explains why so many people make the Ford Focus their choice. Ford claims for it the title of world’s best-selling nameplate, with more than 12 million sold worldwide since its initial launch in 1998. It’s very popular in Europe, where a diesel version is available, and in the U.S. it’s the second-best-selling car, after the mid-size Fusion, in the Ford lineup (not including the perennial #1 F-150 pickup, of course).

Speaking of sexy, the Aston Martin-esque looks of the Ford Fusion are hinted at in the small but fierce grille at the front end of the Focus. If looks are important to you, aesthetically the five-door hatchback model is the sexy-looking one, as well as more versatile than the 2015 Focus SE sedan we tested. Still, 60 percent of buyers choose the sedan version, which has a shallow but serviceable trunk. The Focus comes as a base S sedan, while the SE and upper-level Titanium are available as sedan or hatchback versions. Above them is a sportier ST and, coming at the end of the year, a hot-hatch SR version. As with several Ford products, an electric model is for sale, too. Versatility has its rewards.

The base engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 160 horsepower. This would be more interesting if there wasn't a brief clunk in the driveline when I accelerated from a stop. It is just frequent enough to be annoying. It is likely an aberration.
There is something quite sexy about being able to buy a new car in the $20,000-and-under range that doesn’t feel cheap. That explains why so many people choose the Focus.

For your $21,970—the out-the-door price of the Focus we tested—you get an SE Sport package that slightly glams up the exterior, including a rear spoiler, foglamps, and a set of seventeen-inch aluminum wheels. You also get a six-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, a $1,095 option over the standard five-speed manual.

What’s more interesting in the Focus lineup is the turbocharged EcoBoost engine, new for 2015. It’s a surprisingly peppy 1.0-liter, 123-horsepower three-cylinder first seen on the subcompact Fiesta, teamed with a six-speed manual transmission. It’s good for 40 mpg on the highway, only a little better than the 38 mpg on the Focus SE we drove, which had the six-speed automatic PowerShift dual-clutch automatic transmission. If you choose the SE Appearance package ($1,995), that transmission comes with SelectShift capability that helps deliver better fuel economy and operates automatically but feels more like a manual transmission.

If you’re looking for a little (or a lot) more excitement from your Focus, there’s the ST hatchback. It makes 252 horsepower from its turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder EcoBoost engine, comes only with the six-speed manual transmission, and starts at $25,245. This is the one you want. Perhaps you could consider skipping that daily megatoobig cappufrappe to help pay the extra $3,275 freight that the ST costs over the SE, because the ST looks better and feels better. (You will, too, if you switch to green tea.)

I drove the ST in Switzerland recently and loved it. But, when all is said and done, if the 252 horsepower from the ST hatchback isn’t quite enough for you, coming later this year is an all-wheel-drive version, the hatchback RS, with a 2.3-liter EcoBoost turbo four-cylinder that makes 315 horsepower.

Ford has come under some criticism for its Sync infotainment system, which people have called hard to use and non-intuitive. The automaker has responded by bringing out a fab new Sync 3 for a handful of new 2016 models. I tried it in late June and was astounded by how good it is, as different as night and day, actually. I’d even say it’s worth waiting for—it comes out at the end of 2016 for the Focus and most other Fords—if navigation and entertainment are important to you. The MyFord Touch package on the 2015 model costs $1,495 and includes ten-speaker Sony audio, SiriusXM satellite radio, and dual-zone climate control in addition to navigation and the eight-inch touchscreen.

The model we tested doesn’t come standard with a touchscreen. It and other lower-end models have a 4.2-inch non-touch screen. It’s okay but looks awfully outdated compared with the big, flashy screens you’ll see on other economy cars from the likes of Chevrolet, Honda, Toyota, and Hyundai. It does, however, have a rearview camera in it, which is standard equipment starting with this 2015 model. It also has Bluetooth to pair your phone, which worked flawlessly.

Now this is a compact car, so don’t get any ideas about transporting a large family or a lot of stuff in it on a regular basis. I know someone who rejected a Focus in favor of the larger Fusion based strictly on the need for comfortable legroom for her lanky teenage son in the back seat. The trunk swallowed up $225 worth of groceries with no problem but was not deep enough to take a broom, which had to ride inside the car instead. And, no, the broom would NOT come in handy if I ran out of gas.

The Focus SE I tested came with a frighteningly light-colored beige cloth interior, called Light Stone, that seemed to have Stain Me written all over it. Right on cue, I spilled an entire 16-ounce cup of coffee and the carrier it was riding in, upside down, but luckily it spilled on the (black) (rubber backed) floor mat, which washed right out. A leather interior is an option, as is a charcoal cloth interior. I’d prefer that: boring but safe. Then again, that beige cloth was mighty nice-looking.

And speaking of safe, a Technology package ($795) on the Titanium model includes blind spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert and lane-keeping alert, a reasonable price for this soon-to-feel-indispensable active safety tech. Small but very useful blind spot mirrors on the side mirror frames are standard and appreciated on the SE.

The Verdict:

The Ford Focus does not overwhelm you with luxuries, but there is one: the luxury of choice. You can go basic, and get the car we tested: a reasonably sized, competent, not unattractive car that works for every day. You can go upscale a bit, with the Titanium model, and add some active safety features, plus heated leather front seats, keyless entry, and touchscreen infotainment. Or you can indulge yourself with the sportier and much more powerful ST hatchback. I think I understand why so many people all over the world have chosen the Ford Focus.
