title: How to Keep Dogs Cool in the Car
subTitle: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.
promoTitle: How to Keep Dogs Cool in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.
promoTeaser: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.
keywords: How to Keep Dogs Cool in the Car
metaTitle: 5 Ways to Help Your Dog Keep Cool  - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.

pageElements.text:
It’s that time of year again, when you head out on errands or day trips in the car, and your dog comes along for the ride. Problem: How do you keep your pet from getting overheated?
 
First things first: You must take every measure to avoid leaving your dog inside a parked car for any length of time. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) says that, on an 85-degree day, temperatures inside a car can reach 102 degrees within ten minutes. That’s no time at all.

“The ASPCA never condones leaving a dog in a car; too much can happen too quickly and end in tragedy,” Julie Morris, the ASPCA’s senior vice-president of community outreach, told Jean Knows Cars. The grocery store can wait; your dog’s well-being is more important.

But the reality is, you do have to go in to a store occasionally where you can’t bring your pet along. With experience gained from years of pet ownership and participation in dog shows, here are our five tips to help your dog chill out in the car when it’s hot outside.

1. Improve the air quality.

You can keep the engine on and blast the air conditioning, at least briefly—but bring a second set of keys so you can still lock the car. Your pet should be in a cage or wearing a harness if you do, not moving freely around the car.

Even better, bring some portable, battery-powered fans. Large fans—Ryobi is one brand—with built-in stands and hooks can be hung directly onto a dog cage in the back of your vehicle. Fresh batteries or extra fans will let you keep the cool air going while you are on the move. Ryobi fans also have a charger that works off the car’s cigarette lighter.

2. Find the shade (or make your own).

When you know you’re going to be parked for a while—at a park, for example—find the shadiest spot in the lot. For longer visits, use a pop-up awning that can cover the back of the vehicle. Another good choice is reflective mesh covers on the windshield and the two front doors. This will beat back the sun’s rays while allowing breezes to blow through.

3. Buy a chilly pad (seriously, they’re amazing).

Frogg Togg is a company that makes rainwear, but many people know them for their chilly pad. The chilly pad is constructed of a “man made sponge” that retains up to eight times its weight in water. Frogg Togg explains, “Once wet, the towels produce a cooling effect with the help of simple evaporation, and as long as the towel is wet, exposed to the air, and allowed to breathe, it will remain chilled.” The best part? They make one for dogs. You can line a crate with the ChillyDog Pad, and your pet will stay cool for hours.

4. Bring backup water.

Staying hydrated is just as important for dogs as it is for humans, so keep two to three extra water bottles on hand in addition to a bowl for drinking. If possible, store this water in a cooler with ice. I do not know many people who would prefer warm to cool water on a hot day, and the same goes for your dog. The best thing on hot days is to fill a special cooler with mostly ice, preferably made at home from the water your pet is used to. Then let your dog drink directly from the cooler, the same way most dogs drink directly from the toilet.

5. Leave a note.

The Humane Society of the United States, ASPCA, and PETA all have campaigns for awareness about the dangers of leaving your pet in the car, and they distribute flyers explaining what to do if you come across a dog in an unattended vehicle. The directions include telling the passer-by to call the police and break the window. All good advice. So, if you must leave your pet in the car and have taken proper precautions, let others know. Tape a note to your windshield making it clear that yes, your pup is in the back seat, but that you have set him up with air conditioning and water and will be back in a jiff. Also, include the number of the cellphone you have with you so you can be reached.

title: Is Your Nav Dumber Than Your Phone?
subTitle: Can Google make your car's nav system more smartphone-like? We tried it in the 2015 Nissan Rogue.
promoTitle: Is Your Nav Dumber Than Your Phone?
promoTeaserSmall: Can Google make your car's nav system more smartphone-like? We tried it in the 2015 Nissan Rogue.
promoTeaser: Can Google make your car's nav system more smartphone-like? We tried it in the 2015 Nissan Rogue.
keywords: Is Your Nav Dumber Than Your Phone?
metaTitle: Is Your Nav Dumber Than Your Phone?
metaDescription: Can Google make your car's nav system more smartphone-like? We tried it in the 2015 Nissan Rogue.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Let’s admit it: easier, faster, and effectively free, a smartphone is the go-to navigation device for many drivers, regardless of whether a navigation system is already installed neatly in the vehicle's dashboard. Auto manufacturers know this, and some are scrambling to improve clunky, yet pricey, navigation systems to compete with ever-evolving smartphones that are encroaching on their territory. Unfortunately, it’s not as easy as just switching map providers from Garmin to Google.
Carmakers are scrambling to improve their clunky, yet pricey, navigation systems to compete with ever-evolving smartphones that are encroaching on their territory.

One of the obstacles keeping Google, Apple, or Bing maps out of your car is data connectivity. To ensure reliability, navigation systems use satellites to determine a vehicle’s location and plot a path rather than rely on cellular towers, which may offer spotty reception in dense urban corridors or hilly and rural areas. Their Point of Interest (POI) databases are often hit-or-miss because they’re static, meaning no new new locations are being added or addresses corrected unless you download the latest update, typically for a fee.

On the other hand, Internet-based mapping systems are constantly updated and can use fuzzy search logic and the wisdom of the crowd to finding the name and location of that new restaurant that you heard about but don’t really remember what it’s called.  And thanks to a rabid team of community contributors who report addresses, road inaccuracies, and the latest infrastructure changes, their maps are the most up to date.
So what’s the average car buyer to do?

The “bring your own navigation system” model is being embraced by Ford and General Motors on some of their entry-level vehicles as a way to keep costs down, and a couple high-end manufactures, such as Tesla and Mercedes-Benz are offering Google Maps as the navigation system on a couple models.
Smartphone users without in-car navigation risk being without a system altogether if they forgot their phone, it’s dead, or they are in a spotty reception area.

But for everyone else, opting to forgo the navigation system and relying on a smartphone means giving up some features and convenience, such as directions appearing in the instrument cluster or head-up display, and integration with steering wheel controls. Buyers also run the risk of being without a system altogether if they forgot their phone, it’s dead, or they are in a spotty reception area. And as people stream more and more entertainment on phones, driving directions to Nana’s house just seems like an expensive waste of data.
Enter Google Search.

Most manufacturers are opening their infotainment platform and integrating third-party apps. Hyundai, Kia, Nissan, and Toyota have found a way to leverage the user’s phone and data plan for location lookup on Internet search engines, such as Google or Bing, and send the address to the vehicle’s embedded navigation system.

It’s not yet the same thing as having Google or Apple Maps in your car, but this strategy makes it easier for the user to find business addresses on the fly, and yet still use the navigation system for turn-by-turn directions and save the bulk of their data plan for something else.

To find out if Google Search made me use the embedded navigation system more user friendly, I spent a week in a 2015 Nissan Rogue equipped with NissanConnect, which is a free app that integrates approved applications with the infotainment and navigation system.

One of the quirks with Nissan’s system is that I had to connect my iPhone via USB rather than Bluetooth, and only after the vehicle started – not before – or else it wouldn’t detect my device. On the upside, my phone was always charged.

Accessing the apps was easy thanks to the Rogue’s large and intuitive touchscreen interface. But I found myself waiting for the apps to load, one time clocking in at forty-eight seconds to start, which means no fast getaways using Google Search.

But when the app finally connected, I was impressed with its usability. The voice-based search is powered by Nuance, so it’s pretty spot-on in deciphering address requests. Even if I was less than succinct with my pronunciation, Google smoothed out the rough edges. Nuance hears “well adina nursery,” and Google offered up a location for “Wells Medina Nursery.” Score one for Google Search. The touchscreen keyboard was a good backup for typing in obscure businesses, and also easier to use than the one on my phone. Score another point for Google Search.
So Google Search makes it easier to find where you want to go using your navigation system in the car, but you’ll still have to grapple will the GPS’s routing preferences to get there.

One Point for the Smartphone: Turn-by-Turn Logic

On more than one occasion, I disagreed wholeheartedly with the Rogue’s turn-by-turn directions, which are provided by HERE (formerly NavTeq). On a trip to Lowes, HERE’s guidance kept urging me onto the freeway a half-mile away even as I circled the parking lot. Minus one point for embedded nav.

And...Another Point for the Smartphone: Previewing

Fiddling with the preferences, I could select the fastest or the shortest route, but previewing the directions is tucked away on page two of the Options menu. When I look up a destination in the Maps app on my phone, I can preview the entire route and am often given choices on which path to take. Another ding against embedded nav.

...And One Point for Embedded Navigation: Safer Driving

That said, directions in the instrument cluster were easier to follow, and having the music dim with each voice prompt ensured I never missed a turn. To my recollection, I never picked up my phone while I was driving except to adjust the device’s music volume, which is the point of embedded and highly integrated navigation and infotainment systems. Bonus points for embedded nav’s safety.
Google Search made an embedded navigation system easier to use, but usability is more complex than finding and entering an address.

In short, yes, Google Search made an embedded navigation system easier to use, but usability is more complex than finding and entering an address. And we’re still years away from cars, roads, and people being so seamlessly connected that we can all use the Internet for all of our driving needs. Until then, forty-five seconds doesn’t seem that long a wait to find the address of that food cart that just popped up.

2015 Nissan Rogue SV AWD

pageElements.text:

Transmissions: Five-speed manual or continuously variable automatic

Four-door hatchbacks can be design disasters, crudely chopped from a block of steel. Or, like the Nissan Versa Note, they can be remarkably charming: well proportioned, and sculpted, with just the right stance. The Versa Note has an unusual presence for a car that’s only 163 inches long. (It also has an unusual amount of cargo space with up to 38.3 cubic feet.) In fact, the Versa Note, which was introduced for 2014, looked so good, we wondered why there wasn’t a dedicated sport model. This year, in addition to the high-trim Versa Note SL, there is now a Note SR. Unfortunately, the SR doesn’t have a turbocharged engine to put muscle behind the sporty look, only the same normally aspirated 1.6-liter four cylinder making 109 horsepower as the other models. Otherwise, the SR sure does fill the part, with a unique, dark headlight accents, fog lamps, and a whisking tail topped by a rear spoiler. Inside, the seats are covered in faux suede, and the standard level of infotainment and connectivity is high. There’s also a rearview monitor and a clever adjustable load floor in the cargo area. The new Note SL rides on handsome 16-inch alloy wheels and is loaded with features like a smart key with push-button start and a class-exclusive 360-degree monitor. In whatever trim level, the Versa Note goes about its business with joie de vivre, making itself as useful as possible.

New for 2015

Expanded model lineup with SR and SL trims, available 360-degree monitor, NissanConnect with Navigation and Mobile Apps, hands-free texting, rearview camera, and an adjustable load floor.

title: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car
subTitle: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.
promoTitle: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.
promoTeaser: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.
keywords: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car
metaTitle: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.

pageElements.text: 1. Get them used to a snug fit. Whether in a car seat, a booster seat, or with a seatbelt, all ages of kids should be firmly strapped in to the car. If you make a comfortable but close fit the default, that's what they will be used to, and it's far safer. Adjust the car seat's straps so they fit with no more than a finger's width of give between straps and child. Booster seats are called "belt-positioning boosters" for a reason, so use the positioning clips on the top edge to firmly attach the shoulder strap to the seat.

2. Never let kids tuck the shoulder strap behind them or under their arm. In an accident, that child has an unprotected upper body in the former case, and could sustain terrible internal injuries in the latter case. The proper use of the shoulder strap must be non-negotiable. If your child isn't tall enough to use the seatbelt comfortably, he or she belongs in a booster seat. The shoulder belt should sit across the middle of your child's chest and shoulder, and is off of the neck.

3. Ensure that car seats are used (and used correctly) no matter whose car they're in. Carpool or field trip drivers, relatives or grandparents? Make sure they take car seat use as seriously as you do. The nonprofit group Safe Kids says one in five parents admit to "bending the rules" by letting carpooling kids ride without the proper child or booster seat or even without seatbelts. Three times as many, 61 percent, tattled on other parents, saying they've seen it happen. Ensuring the proper number of car seats and seating positions is part of planning any trip, short or long.

4. Think of everything in your car as a possible projectile. Something as harmless as a toy car could do some serious damage if you get into a crash. Do you remember the Sippy Cup Incident of 2011, in which a little boy needed 400 stitches to the forehead when his plastic cup hit him in an accident? Enough said. It's easy to toss the sports equipment, book bags, and toys on the floor of the back seat next to your kids. But it's better to put it away in the trunk or secure it in the back. For little kids, encourage the use of soft, squishy toys in the car rather than hard-edged ones. It can't hurt.

5. Don't be in a hurry to take your kids out of booster seats. Safe Kids says they can cut the risk of injury in an accident by 45 percent compared with seatbelts alone. That same organization reports that 70 percent of parents don't know that a child has to be 4'9" tall before it's time to stop using a booster. For some kids, that's well into middle school age. Refer back to item #1, above; it's your job as the parent to make a snug, appropriately belted riding experience the norm, and the comfort zone, for your child and any other kids who ever ride with you; yes, even just down to the local store.

Use These Resources

Find the type of car seat that fits. Want to know what kind of car seat your child should be in? The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's homepage has an interactive seat selector to find the right car seat. Enter your child's height, weight, and age, and the recommended seat type will pop up.

Get a picture of how your child should fit in the car. Safer Kids Worldwide offers a page of videos and images for babies to teens.

Arm yourself with information (and arguments) for older kids. NHTSA's Parents Central has a page, Never Give Up until They Buckle Up, with videos and information touching kids aged eight to fourteen.

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura: Views Expressed by This Vehicle Are Mine

Your car is a speech bubble. What are you going to make it say? Whether you're displaying political messages or stick-figure families (which I kind of like, no matter how much they're joked about), they can be the only thing that stands between your dull, inexpressive car and a rolling conversation between you and all the people you encounter in traffic. I say, don't leave your speech bubble empty.
Your car is a speech bubble. What are you going to make it say?

Some of the most memorable moments of my misspent youth involve bumperstickers. The first political campaign I remember was 1968, when booths were found on the street corners of my town handing out Humphrey, Nixon, and Wallace bumperstickers and most people had one or another on their cars in that contentious year. The first demonstration I participated in was environmental, and someone pressed a No Nukes sticker into my hand even though I didn't yet own a car. "Put it on your bicycle," the well-meaning hippie suggested. I looked forward to the opportunity to have a car like a lot of those I admired on the streets, with a back end totally covered with stickers.

And yet, when I got my first new car, I was curiously hesitant to sully its paint with any stickers. I tried a peace sign magnet; somebody stole it off the back. Then I realized, that's why God gave us Goo-Gone. And I started peeling and sticking in earnest.

I've gotten over my fear of sticking something semi-permanent onto my car. For one thing, there's always the window. I have three kids in college, and each of their schools gets pride of place on the back of my car. Political campaigns will see me putting at least a few regional or national stickers onto the back window.
And I love to see a Toyota Prius at a stoplight in front of me that is completely covered with messages and slogans. Even a rusty pickup with NRA stickers makes me happy: the First Amendment at work.

Molly: My Car's Rear End Has Taken a Vow of Purity

I love bumper stickers, but only if I am looking out my windshield and it is on someone else’s car. I truly enjoy reading them. I believe that bumper sticker people are passionate people. They proclaim what is important to them and proudly wear it on their tail. I am confident that many pro sticker people fill their Facebook feeds with messages that reveal their peeves and pleas. I assume their yards have signs that proclaim their favorite politicians and support or displeasure with local or national issues. These are people who wear their hearts on their sleeves.
There is enough tension on the highways already, so I will leave my political opinions for cocktail discussion among rational adults.

I personally do not want to discuss politics with most anyone, and certainly not with anyone who has Fox News as their default station. I respect that they have a right to believe anything they want; I just don’t want to debate it. I also don’t want to advertise how I stand on most political issues. I am not embarrassed of my opinion; I am just not comfortable putting my choice right on my bumper. I would worry that if I proudly put a “Hillary for America” sticker on my bumper and parked in certain parts of America that my car might be vandalized, or worse, cause my fellow drivers to judge me. There is enough tension on the highways so I will leave my political opinions for cocktail discussion among rational adults.  I know that when I see certain stickers that are intended to get a rise out of other drivers I can’t wait to pass them so I can get a good look at the driver.

My daughter begged us to get a set of stick figures for the back of our van. We finally broke down and got a magnetic peace sign instead. It was promptly stolen. I love stickers, just not on cars, and don’t even get me started on the cars I see where the kids willy-nilly stick stickers all over the back windows. Our salvation for my daughter’s sticker love was her footlocker for camp. The stickers look great there, and it has become a sort of scrapbook of her life. And truth be told, if I drove a beater I would be more likely to plaster it with stickers to give it some character.

But my strongest reason for not wanting bumper stickers on my car is purely aesthetic. As a designer, I find very few stickers that are well enough designed that I would want to look at them through the duration of my car ownership. Bad typography, color choice, and layout are rampant in the sticker world. Designers spent countless hours painstakingly creating my lovely Chrysler Town & Country van; who am I to deface it? But to the stickerophiles in the world I give you the breakfast club arm pump. I will remain pure, and when I finally get to own the Mercedes of my dreams, it will too remain a sticker virgin.

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

pageElements.text: “Years ago, there was a race. Perhaps the very greatest race.” These are the opening sentences of Dwight Knowlton’s newest children’s book, a spellbinding read that choked me up several times, and I know the story!

It seems impossible that Knowlton could deliver a second children’s book as captivating and beautifully illustrated as The Little Red Racing Car, a story about a father and his young son’s journey in finding a decrepit Maserati in an old barn and then restoring it together. Not only is his artwork lush, with unusual angles and wonderful details, Knowlton can also spin a yarn that will entrance young kids and old ones alike.
The Little Red Racing Car was fantastic and a coveted member of my permanent book collection. The Greatest Race now takes its place beside it. Forever.

Sounds like a tall order. But he’s done it again, with The Greatest Race: The Record-Breaking Win of the 1955 Mille Miglia. Automotive fans and historians will know this is the race that Stirling Moss famously ran in a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300SLR with co-driving journalist Denis Jenkinson. We know they mapped the entire 1,000 miles and invented the pace note roller so Jenks could give Moss explicit directions allowing him to drive at top speed. We know they won.

But I’m not sure most of us know how harrowing the drive was, how dangerous and fraught with disaster, how very close they came to losing it all more than once. Knowlton captures the drama of key moments, the crashes and off-road excursions. Here is an example:

“Stirling and Jenks sped from Brescia to Vicenza at more than 160 mph. They were so intent on overtaking the slower cars ahead that they failed to see the big Ferrari of Castellotti closing in behind! They blasted through the streets of Padua with the 4.3-liter Ferrari on their tail.

“Stirling deftly tossed the car left, then right. Jenks looked ahead—THEY WERE GOING TOO FAST! Stirling fought the brakes and the wheel. The car skidded, bouncing off straw bales. They made the turn—but the red Ferrari roared past, painting black stripes on the road in front of them.”
What did the black stripes tell Stirling Moss?

It is all there, and more, in simple declarative sentences accompanying simple evocative drawings. There is no talking down to the reader. Instead, the book is sprinkled with technical information throughout, which will undoubtedly serve to whet many appetites for more.
As the book went on, I felt anxiety and a lump in my throat. I am serious!
The Little Red Racing Car was fantastic and a coveted member of my permanent book collection. The Greatest Race now takes its place beside it. Forever.
I would like to see a crowdsourced effort to pay for the next book from Knowlton. I nominate the amazing story of Denise McCluggage. Anyone with me?
The Greatest Race is a hardcover book, available for pre-order on Dwight Knowlton's website, priced at a very reasonable $23.99.

Can I just start by saying that I love the new Maxima? The Nissan flagship that was formerly marketed as the Four-Door Sports Car is once again worthy of the name—especially in the sportiest version, the SR that is shown here and in the video above.

This is a car that has been around since 1981, originally as a rear-wheel-drive car and now with front-wheel drive. After an “extended model year” in 2014, which means there was no 2015 model, Nissan has come back with an all-new, lighter and more fuel-efficient Maxima. Better yet, it also features a radically altered exterior and a completely redesigned interior. It’s longer, lower, and just better-looking all the way around. That’s good news for the sedan shopper who is looking for a little excitement in the daily drive.
All this, and the 2016 Maxima, even in the sporty SR version I tested, still comes in under $40,000.

If you are interested in the Maxima, you’re probably looking for a practical car, and even a family car, and the fact that it is a blast to drive is a bonus. There’s no doubt that it is going to make consumers take a second look at a time when even the Toyota Avalon, a key competitor, is striving to make more of a fashion statement with a recent redesign. But the Avalon doesn’t have a chance against this, at least in style terms.
Our test car, the sporty SR, is one step down from top-of-the-line Maxima Platinum, which starts at $40,685 (including destination charge).

What’s New for 2016

Fuel prices have been up and down lately, but the 2016 Maxima’s 15 percent increase in highway fuel economy is welcome no matter how cheap (or expensive) gas gets. The 2014 Maxima’s 19 mpg city/26 mpg highway rating is bested by the all-new 2016 model, which gets 22 mpg city and an impressive 30 mpg on the highway. The new Maxima is 82 pounds lighter than the outgoing model, which contributes to the better fuel economy.

The SR is a new member of the Maxima family. It and all Maximas get a redesigned 3.5-liter V-6 engine that adds 10 horsepower over the previous model, for a total of 300 hp. The transmission, a continuously variable automatic, is new for 2016. A selector on the SR model lets you choose Normal or Sport drive modes. I am a Sport kind of driver; how about you? Choosing Sport mode changes the throttle response, transmission tuning, and steering weight for a more, well, sporty driving experience.
The specs don’t begin to cover how powerful and responsive this Maxima is, or to describe how enticing the engine note is in Sport mode.

But the specs don’t begin to cover how powerful and responsive this Maxima is, or to describe how enticing the engine note is in Sport mode. Yes, that sound is “acoustically enhanced,” but Porsche does it, too, and the sound you hear out of the Maxima is worth accepting a little bit of clever fakery.

Much of the high-tech safety equipment you can get on the Maxima is not available on the base model. That includes blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and forward collision warning. Those features are standard on the upper-level models, including the SR.

The Driver Attention Alert system, which learns each individual driver’s steering patterns and alerts the driver via an amber coffee-cup icon when the driver is drowsy or inattentive, is optional and only on the Platinum model.

Speaking of the Platinum model, another reason to pay the cost premium for the top Maxima is the interior, with its diamond-quilted leather seats, wood interior trim, and power-adjustable steering wheel. If you’re more the sporting type, like me, you’ll appreciate the midrange SR model’s sport-tuned suspension, paddle shifters—which are only found on this model—a set of 19-inch wheels, adjustable drive modes, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel.

On any model of Maxima, you’ll appreciate the sophisticated look and feel of the interior. All Maximas benefit from a gorgeous wraparound cockpit that is patterned after the F/A-18 Hornet fighter jet used by the U.S. Navy’s Blue Angels. All models get an eight-way power-adjustable driver’s seat, a flat-bottom steering wheel, and a console that is angled seven degrees toward the driver, in the style of the Nissan GT-R sports car. Heated—or heated and cooled—front seats and a heated steering wheel are optional, as is ambient LED lighting.

Technology-wise, the Maxima’s 8.0-inch center touchscreen has NissanConnect to let you pair your phone. A rearview camera, navigation, and SiriusXM satellite radio are standard on all models, as are voice recognition for navigation and audio and remote engine start.

You can dress up the Maxima with such touches as $395 Pearl White exterior paint and $240 external ground lighting. It already has a set of LED daytime running lights, dual exhaust, and that menacing front end.
Who is being menaced? Anybody else who makes a sport sedan, that’s who.

title: 5 Rental-Car Insurance Tips
subTitle: What your credit card and your own car insurance can and can't do to help you at the rental counter.
promoTeaserSmall: What your credit card and your own car insurance can and can't do to help you at the rental counter.

pageElements.text: If you have ever rented a car, you’ve most likely used a credit card to pay for it. You may even have been aware that the card will help you in the event you get into an accident that requires an insurance claim. But you know how confusing choosing insurance can be. Who covers what? Is the card enough, or should you pay the pricey extra daily fees to buy the rental agency’s “damage waiver”?
Here are five things to understand about coverage before you make what could be a costly mistake at the rental counter.

1. Check with your credit card providers ahead of time.

In a recent study, credit card specialist CardHub analyzed the car rental insurance provided by the four major credit card networks: American Express, Visa, Discover, and MasterCard. The good news: all four provide some kind of insurance, usually secondary to your personal car insurance policy. AmEx got a 90 percent overall score as an insurance source from CardHub, while Visa came in last at 74 percent. MasterCard was the only company that did not extend rental insurance on every card it issues. On any card, check with your specific issuer to make sure you know what you can expect.

2. Make the right decisions when you rent.

To be covered by your credit card, you first have to decline the “collision damage waiver,” or insurance policy, offered at the rental counter. You also have to charge the entire rental on the card. Most cards have some stipulations regarding what they will pay for based on where and what you drive. None of the networks offers coverage for trucks, sports cars, or large vans, and three out of four will not cover vehicles priced over $50,000. There are other rules, like Visa’s regulation that excludes accidents that happen on dirt or gravel roads, and AmEx’s refusal to cover big SUVs like the Ford Expedition and the Toyota Land Cruiser.

3. Know what is meant by “covered damages.”

Tire or rim damage or destruction? It’s covered by American Express, MasterCard, and Discover, but not by Visa. If you need your rental card towed, all four card companies will cover that, although you should check with your card issuer to find out about distance limitations. Loss of use and the deductible on your own insurance policy are covered by every company except Discover. American Express offers a “premium” level of coverage, for damages up to $50,000 or $75,000, depending on which card you have, for a small added fee.

4. Check your own insurance policy.

Find out what your personal car insurance policy covers for rental cars. If you have liability and personal injury protection on your own policy, it should extend to your rental as well. Insurer GEICO advises that a homeowner’s or renter’s insurance policy that covers personal effects should also cover personal items that are stolen from a rental car. Before you go to the rental counter, make sure you have had that conversation with your own insurance agent.

5. Understand what purchasing insurance from the rental company will do for you.

It’s not always an automatic “no.” If you’re traveling abroad or don’t like the coverage offered from your credit card provider or insurance policy, you may want to consider paying for the collision damage waiver from the rental company for peace of mind. You might find it difficult, as we did, to get a clear picture of the cost by searching rental company websites. To get exact numbers for the rental you are about to sign up for, you should expect to ask for it directly from the rental agency when you sign the rental contract. All the more reason to know what other options you have ahead of time.

The 2015 Mercedes-Benz E-Class is the jack-of-all-trades platform for the luxury German manufacturer. It’s available any way you like it—coupe, sedan, convertible, or wagon—and with a range of engine options, including a fuel-sipping 2.1-liter diesel. It even offers an uber-sporty 577-horsepower AMG-series wagon as a no-compromise family hauler. This mid-size car is handsomely equipped and receives many safety and technology features, such as the terse Comand infotainment platform, cross-traffic alerts, and an active collision prevision system as standard. However, creature comforts that have become almost expected, such as massaging heated and ventilated seats, remain pricey options. With 41.3 inches of legroom in the front and 35.8 inches in the rear, the cabin of the sedan is roomy, but not overly spacious. The 12.9 cubic feet of cargo capacity will amply serve most of your shopping needs, and if you require more space for your gear, you can opt for the wagon, which also offers the option of two additional rear-facing jump seats for occasional pint-sized passengers.

New for 2015

The E-Class was comprehensively revised for 2014, so changes to the 2015 lineup are minor.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Your iPhone lets you operate at the speed of light: texting a crowd to set up your next merger or soccer game. Triangulating your destination accurately with nothing more than a street address. Paying for groceries and rent with a tap. Asking Siri to remind you to pick up the dry cleaning as you buy coffee.  But when you get in the car? It all stops. And you sit there staring at taillights. Even when you can pair your phone for hands-free calling using Bluetooth, it's often an awkward experience that's nowhere near as fluid as what the iPhone offers you.

That’s why Apple launched Apple CarPlay in 2014. Instead of disconnecting—or choosing between disconnecting and looking at your phone when you should be looking at the road—you can plug your iPhone in while you buckle up, once you download the Apple CarPlay app to your phone. The car will mirror what’s on your phone to the in-dash telematics system and keep you moving at lightning speed, even when the traffic is crawling.

Well, in point of fact, it’s more like a magnifying cosmetic mirror than a true reflection of what’s on your phone. Everything has been rebuilt for the larger in-car screen and the car experience, where you don’t want to do more than glance at that screen, and—more than on your phone—you are encouraged to ask Siri for whatever you need. Want to make a phone call, find coffee nearby, get your texts read aloud, or navigate to your destination? Push a button and ask Siri. She will take it from there. You phone, meanwhile, is somewhat disabled by a big splash screen, encouraging you to look up at the road and not down at your phone. That's a good thing.

The biggest difference between your phone and the in-car mirror of it is the apps you’ll find. Apps have to be rebuilt for the car experience before they’ll show up on that in-car screen. So only a small percentage of that massive collection you have will appear in the car. At the moment, Apple CarPlay supports most music and audio listening apps and a few others. But this is early days. More will come.
Audi, BMW, Chrysler, Dodge, Fiat, Ford, Honda, Jaguar, Jeep, Mazda, Mercedes-Benz, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota, VW, Volkswagen, and Volvo will all be adding Apple CarPlay.

Up till now all this connected goodness has been all promise and little actual drivable reality. But that’s changing for 2016. The 2015 Hyundai Sonata is the first car on the road to boast Apple CarPlay (and Android Auto). But Chevrolet has announced that its mainstay Cruze and fourteen other models will have it in 2016. In many cars, the system uses your phone’s data plan for things like streaming music and navigation. But because Chevys have OnStar, you can opt to use that in-car data plan instead—a nice plus.

More carmakers are signing on to deliver Apple CarPlay to future vehicles. A long list of them have committed to adding the technology to cars: Audi, BMW, Chrysler, Dodge, Fiat, Ford, Honda, Jaguar, Jeep, Mazda, Mercedes-Benz, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota, Volkswagen, and Volvo are among them. And the list will doubtless grow from there. That's good news for anyone who uses an Apple iPhone 5 and up.

If you are a smartphone addict, productivity guru, or just like using your phone, this is a feature you will want in any car you buy going forward. But make sure the car supports both Android Auto (this is common) and Apple CarPlay. You may know that you are an Apple diehard, but you might want to sell that car to an Android geek.

title: Start/Stop: Mercedes-Benz GLA250
subTitle: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.
promoTeaserSmall: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.
promoTeaser: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.
metaDescription: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: I know a woman who took her brand-new Audi A8 back to the dealer, irate that the engine kept shutting off every time she stopped at a red light. Imagine her surprise (and embarrassment) to learn that it was the fuel-saving auto stop/start technology at work. Was this her fault for not knowing? More likely it was the dealer's fault for not explaining it at the time of purchase.
As start/stop technology becomes more common in new cars, you'll want to understand what it is and why it's a good thing, and here's your explanation.

Automatic start/stop is a system that automatically shuts off the vehicle’s engine when the vehicle idles (or stops at a red light) and then restarts when it is re-engaged. This feature has been common for a long time on hybrids, and a growing number of car manufacturers are embracing this technology. It's an easy way to improve fuel economy by as much as seven percent in their vehicles with conventional internal-combustion engines, without adding expensive lithium-ion batteries and electric motors.

How it works is fairly simple: when your vehicle is in motion, the engine is always on, but when it comes to a complete stop, the engine automatically turns off without your doing anything to the ignition. When you then take your foot off the brake to prepare to accelerate, the engine automatically restarts. This toggling of the engine can save drivers approximately $179 annually in fuel savings, according to a AAA study.

To see what it was like driving around with this engine feature, I tested the 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA250 4Matic for a week. The vehicle uses a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, and like all 2015 models in the Mercedes-Benz lineup, it is equipped with Eco Start/Stop as a standard feature.
You don’t expect a gasoline engine to cut out at any time once you’ve left your driveway, but at nearly every light and stop sign, that's exactly what happened.

I’ve driven a fair number of hybrid vehicles, but the engine automatically turning off caught me by surprise during the first couple of days. In a conventional vehicle, you don’t expect a gasoline engine to cut out at any time once you’ve left your driveway, but at nearly every light, every stop sign, and sometimes in heavy traffic, that’s exactly what happened. If I changed pressure dramatically or took my foot off the brake to switch to the accelerator, it snapped back to life as intended.

This was all well and good for the environment, but a bit unnerving when the engine switched off as I paused in the middle of an intersection to turn left, and anxiety-inducing when I worried that it wouldn’t switch over before the yellow arrow became a glaring red. And I can’t tell you how many times I pulled into my garage, gathered my purse, and hopped out, only to hear the engine snap back to life as I exited the vehicle. I wasn’t keeping good count, but it was probably more than the number of times I turned the ignition off without first putting the transmission in Park.

Yes, it’s possible to turn this feature off by deselecting the Eco option on the Mercedes GLA, and I tried that for a couple of days to compare. It was a much smoother driving experience without automatic stop/start, but there were times when I was trapped in stopped traffic due to construction and wished the engine would turn off. Of course, I could have done that, but I might have also killed the air conditioning, navigation, and audio, and more important, I doubt my reflexes are as quick as the vehicle’s at restarting when traffic moved.

With this feature, the GLA250 achieves an estimated 24 mpg in the city. Subtracting seven percent from this data point, the fuel economy drops down to approximately 22 mpg. I imagine that I over time I would get used to turning off the ignition even if the engine wasn’t running. I guess 2 additional miles per gallon is worth the occasional less than graceful car exit even if I don’t.

pageElements.text: Oh, sweet summer: a time for sunshine, barbecues, beach days, and higher gas prices. With longer trips to the cottage on the horizon and gas prices tending to peak during these warmer months, now would be an opportune time to know the best and worst cities to be a driver. Leading personal finance website WalletHub has compiled a list, comparing the 100 most populated cities in the United States across areas like average gas prices, average annual traffic delays, and average parking rates.

This map shows the best cities for driving as smaller dots; as the circles get bigger, so does the amount of hassle involved with driving in that city.

Source: WalletHub

What do the highest-rated cities have in common? Two words struck me when I saw WalletHub’s top ten best cities to be a driver: small town. Well, all of the cities on the list have populations of at least 100,000, so they are not small in the one school and a general store kind of way. However, when put in a pool with the country’s biggest cities, Greensboro, North Carolina, in the number-four position, does feel a bit small.

The top three cities are Lubbock and Corpus Christi, Texas, and Lincoln, Nebraska. All have populations that hover around 300,000 and median incomes per household that are slightly below the national average. A generally okay standard of living plus fewer people equals lower rates of car theft and accident likelihood, WalletHub says. Another (perhaps questionable) small-city stereotype? Southern. Nine out of ten cities at the top of WalletHub’s list are found in the southern half of the country. The warmer and sometimes drier climate definitely contributes to these cities’ better road conditions, fewer traffic delays, and overall happier drivers.

What about the ones at the bottom? It comes as no surprise that the U.S.’s largest cities make the list of ten worst cities to be a driver. New York City is home to 8.5 million people. With that many individuals trying to get to the office, coffee shop, or school, there is bound to be exponentially more traffic, poorer road conditions, and less parking availability. Big cities face another issue: greater rates of car theft. With urban areas come a wider economic spectrum. Detroit has the third highest rate of car theft, in addition to a population of 680,000 in which one out of every three residents lives below the poverty line. Washington, D.C., Philadelphia, and San Francisco hold the three spots behind New York City, but don’t worry; you don’t have to give up on your Sex and the City dreams just because driving to work will take you three times longer. Most of the worst cities to be a driver are also the best cities to be a public transportation user, so moving there might just mean trading in your keys for a subway pass or a regular taxicab habit.

This list will probably not determine your next home town, and if it does I applaud your commitment to enjoyable driving. If you crave smooth roads and a low-traffic rush hour, though, take a look at these figures and maybe pack your bags.

The Best Cities for Drivers

1. Lubbock, Texas
2. Corpus Christi, Texas
3. Lincoln, Nebraska
4. Greensboro, North Carolina
5. Tucson, Arizona
6. Reno, Nevada
7. Durham, North Carolina
8. Colorado Springs, Colorado
9. Winston-Salem, North Carolina
10. Raleigh, North Carolina

The Worst Cities for Drivers

10. Los Angeles
9. Baltimore
8. Chicago
7. Boston
6. Newark
5. Detroit
4. San Francisco
3. Philadelphia
2. Washington, D.C.
1 (worst). New York City
Washington, D.C., has six times more average annual hours of traffic delays than Bakersfield, California.

Lowest likelihood of an accident: Boise, Idaho.
Five highest average gas prices: five California cities, San Francisco, San Diego, Chula Vista, Los Angeles, and Long Beach.
In Irvine, California, you are twenty-seven times less likely to have your car stolen compared with Detroit.
Fewest car washes per capita: Boston.
Parking rates in Chicago are fourteen times higher than in Wichita, Kansas.

title: 2016 Hyundai Tucson AWD Limited
subTitle: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?
promoTeaserSmall: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?
promoTeaser: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?
metaDescription: Athleticism tempered by comfort. Is that enough to make the Tucson a winner in the crossover class?

pageElements.text:
Base price: $23,595 (base SE model; prices include destination charge)
This model: $32,195
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Turbo powertrain
Features I can’t live without: Auto-opening liftgate
Notable standard features on this model: 19-inch alloy wheels; LED headlights; LED foglamps, daytime running lights, and taillights; eight-inch touchscreen; navigation; panoramic power moonroof; tilting/telescoping steering column; leather-wrapped steering wheel; heated leather seats; power front seats; premium audio; Hyundai BlueLink car care and emergency telematics; heated side mirrors; hands-free power liftgate; blind spot detection; lane change assist; rear cross traffic alert
Notable options on this model: No options
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Jeep Cherokee, Mazda CX-5, Nissan Rogue, Toyota RAV4

The Tucson is Hyundai’s offering in a very competitive and rapidly growing field of compact crossover sport-utility vehicles, To date, the Tucson has been an also-ran in this area of the U.S. new vehicle market, a segment dominated by the Ford Escape, Jeep Cherokee, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4, and in particular the Honda CR-V, the perennial bestseller.
The Tucson could change the CUV sales picture, thanks to a sweeping redesign that touches every area of the vehicle. It will begin appearing in dealerships this month.
However, the third-generation Tucson could well change the CUV sales picture, thanks to a sweeping redesign that touches every area of the vehicle. It will begin appearing in dealerships this month.

Like all the entries in this class, the Tucson is basically a front-wheel-drive compact passenger car with bigger dimensions, particularly in the vertical. Bigger is a word that definitely applies here. At 64.8 inches, the new Tucson isn’t quite as tall as the preceding generation, but the wheelbase has been stretched 1.2 inches to 105.1, overall length from 173.2 to 176.2, and width from 71.7 to 72.8. By comparison, the larger, three-row Hyundai Santa Fe sport-utility vehicle sits on a 110.2-inch wheelbase and is 66.9 inches tall, counting the roof rails.

What this yields is more cargo space behind the rear seats—up 5.3 cubic feet to 31.0—and of course to more interior room in general, which is what SUVs are all about. And obviously it never hurts when that increased interior volume is augmented by improved materials, which is the case here.
Hyundai claims a huge increase in structural rigidity—48 percent—thanks to much more extensive use of high-strength steel in the body shell (like all these vehicles, the frame and body are unitized). Stiffer structure pays dynamic dividends—more on that later—as well as improved crashworthiness, one of several safety upgrades.

Like the 2015 Tucson, the new 2016 version offers two engine choices. However, only one is a carryover from 2015, the 2.0-liter four-cylinder. Rated for 164 horsepower and 151 pound-feet of torque, it’s paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and is offered only in the base SE model.

EPA fuel economy ratings for the front-wheel-drive Tucson are 23 mpg city, 31 mpg highway (22/26 mpg with the optional all-wheel-drive system, as on the model we tested), a slight improvement over the 2015 version. 
Higher trim levels—Eco, Sport, and Limited—are equipped with a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine mated with a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. Shared with Hyundai’s Sonata sedan, this combination delivers generally better fuel economy—up to 26/33, with the Eco model—and, with 175 hp and 195 pound-feet of torque, brisker getaways. It’s one of the best engine/transmission combos in Hyundai’s lineup.

Our hands-on experience was confined to top-of-the-line Limited models, primarily the all-wheel-drive version, which is rated for 24 mpg in the city and 28 mpg highway. Opting for the front-drive model bumps the ratings to 25/30 mpg.

From a cosmetic perspective, the new Tucson’s increased dimensions, wider stance, improved proportions, and bolder sheetmetal character creases create a strong curbside presence. It’s another example of Hyundai’s Fluidic Sculpture styling idiom—the press materials characterize it as a “modern, sensual design”—highlighted by a big, bright execution of Hyundai’s trademark hexagonal grille and a generous sprinkling of LEDs.

Sensual may be a little hard to see in a vehicle that, like its contemporaries, is basically a streamlined cargo box, but if the Tucson doesn’t grab attention like a new Bentley, it does look new and a little more athletic.
That athletic appearance is backed by improved dynamics.

And we hasten to add that the Tucson’s athleticism is tempered by comfort. The suspension system has been completely overhauled, and its tuning is skewed toward compliance, rather than sports car agility, a priority that makes sense in this type of vehicle.

The electric power steering delivers a tactile response, reducing the amount of guesswork when you're bending the Tucson into a turn. Torque vectoring (all-wheel-drive versions only), which transfers power to the outside rear wheel in hard cornering, helps to keep the vehicle on the proper line, even if the driver finds him or herself entering a curve that abruptly tightens up.
Other compact crossovers may respond to rapid back-and-forth maneuvers with more zeal (the Mazda CX-5 comes to mind), but that’s the trade for creamy ride quality.

Fast cornering is accompanied by a fair amount of body roll, and there are other compact crossovers that respond to rapid back-and-forth maneuvers with more zeal (the Mazda CX-5 comes to mind). But that’s the trade for creamy ride quality.
The Sport version, new to the lineup, may be a little quicker on its feet, but we’ll withhold judgment on this question until we log some seat time in that and other trim levels.

Power from the 1.6-liter turbo is respectable, and the near-seamless operation of the seven-speed automatic makes the most of it. The Tucson will never provoke acceleration brownouts or facial distortion, but its straight-ahead performance stacks up well in this class, and there’s enough thrust on tap to dilute the anxiety in passing on two-lane highways.

While the new Tucson is competent in all dynamic areas, its standout strength versus competing CUVs may be quiet operation. We were pleasantly surprised by the low interior noise levels during our touring in eastern Minnesota and western Wisconsin, along the beautiful Saint Croix River. The route had a lot of smooth pavement but also included some stretches of gravel road, and the level of interior noise on the rough stuff was commendably low. Quiet operation is a key component of comfort, and the Tucson may well be best in class.
Quiet operation is a key component of comfort, and the Tucson may well be best in class.

The Verdict

As usual, Hyundai’s price-content component adds up to a very strong value story, comparing very favorably with key competitors right across the board. Pricing starts with the basic SE at $23,595, then the Eco ($25,045), Sport ($27,045), and Limited ($30,795). The top-end model is the Limited Ultimate ($33,545). Add $1,400 for all-wheel drive.

The Limited Ultimate has every feature in the Tucson’s extensive inventory—luxury is steadily trickling down into the small vehicle classes—but even the basic SE is far from stripped down, even though it lacks the all-wheel-drive option. Adding $750 gets the SE Popular, with more standard features and access to all-wheel drive.
Safety features are comprehensive and competitive—Hyundai expects the Tucson to achieve the coveted top rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

And as usual, Hyundai has come up with an interesting gizmo, an auto-opening rear hatch, already appreciated on the Sonata and, as Jean showed in a video review, on the Genesis. Here’s how it works. The driver steps around to the rear of the locked Tucson, with keyfob in his or her pocket, stands there for three seconds, and the hatch opens. It took Jean three tries to make it pop, but it’s an interesting variation on a feature that is almost certain to become universal.

The bottom line: in terms of build quality, road manners, style, features, and luxury content availability, this new Tucson should be perceived as a real compact crossover contender. Add Hyundai’s unique ten-year, 100,000-mile warranty, and the case is even stronger.

title: 2016: Infotainment to Look Forward to
subTitle: Changes and features you'll love on new models this year, from app integration to wireless hot spots.

pageElements.text:
If you’re considering a new car, truck, or SUV in the 2016 model year, you’re in luck. The auto companies are pulling out all the stops when it comes to infotainment in the car, making the touchscreen faster, easier to use, and full of features so enticing, you soon won’t know how you lived without them. 
Here’s our rundown of some of the new models where you’ll find the latest and greatest.

1. More Like a Smartphone

Finally, no more aggravated arrow pressing. Many automakers have adopted the tile-like icon format you see on tablets and smartphones to give you quick access to music, messaging, and navigation in the style you’re used to outside the car. As on the iPhone and iPad, you can customize your menu bar by dragging and dropping your favorite applications. The all-new Ford Sync 3 system, coming out on a limited basis this fall with full availability in the 2017 model year, also lets you swipe, tap, and pinch like you would on a tablet or smartphone. Jaguar's 2016 XF has this, too, with its InControl Touch 10.2-inch screen.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Chevrolet: most models, including Cruze, Malibu, Camaro, Tahoe
Chrysler 200 and 300
Dodge Challenger, Charger, Durango, Viper
Jeep Cherokee and Grand Cherokee
Ram 1500
Ford Escape and Fiesta
Jaguar XF

2. Apps, Fully Integrated

Along with Sync 3, Ford is improving AppLink, which allows you to connect your smartphone to your car and control a wide range of compatible apps. AppLink automatically recognizes apps including favorites like Pandora and NPR One. Now you can sing along to your customized Roadtrip Pandora station in the car with no hassle. Honda’s HondaLink also connects your car and phone and provides location searches, local weather and messaging. These app integrators provide a simple way to control your apps while driving, balancing the access you want with the limitations you need.

Hyundai is adding Apple Watch and Android smartwatch functionality to its BlueLink telematics, letting you do things like locate, lock, and start your car remotely from your wrist. Any Hyundai equipped with first- or second-generation BlueLink works with it.

Who's Got It (2016 models)

Ford Escape and Fiesta
Honda Pilot and HR-V
Hyundai (all models with BlueLink infotainment)

3. Siri as Your Co-Pilot

We all know it’s not a good thing to talk on the phone while you’re driving, but the temptation can be strong to fish it out and ask Siri the name of that actress who made a cameo in the movie you just saw. Siri Eyes Free has that need covered. Just push a button on your steering wheel—instead of your smartphone—and put Siri to work for you.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Acura ILX, MDX
Chevrolet (most models, including Cruze, Malibu, Camaro, Tahoe)
Chrysler 200 and 300
Ford Escape and Fiesta
Dodge Challenger, Charger, Durango, Viper
Honda Civic, CR-V, Pilot
Jeep Cherokee and Grand Cherokee
Ram 1500

4. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Soon to Be Everywhere

Okay, your 2016 car’s touchscreen layout strongly resembles your smartphone’s, and you have access to your most-used apps. There could not possibly be a way to make this more intuitive, right?

Wrong. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto have copied your iPhone and Android home screens and pasted them directly onto your car’s touchscreen. As soon as you start the ignition, you will come face to face with a screen that appears nearly identical to your iPhone or Android’s, displaying apps you want and need while out on the road. CarPlay even features the home button we all know and love. You still cannot play Angry Birds while driving—nor should you, ever—but now you can access your audiobooks, maps, and messages in a way that makes sense.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Buick LaCrosse and Regal
Chevrolet (most models, including Cruze, Malibu, Camaro, Tahoe)
GMC Yukon and Sierra
Hyundai Sonata
Volvo XC90

Here is a full list of auto brands that will soon be getting Android Auto and a full list of those getting Apple CarPlay.

5. Your Car as a Rolling Wireless Hot Spot

Say goodbye to the post-road-trip “you have used 90% of your monthly data allowance” texts. General Motors, already offering it on twenty-five vehicles in 2015, is expanding its range of models that can operate as 4G LTE rolling wireless hot spots. Audi is expanding availability across the range. Subaru is introducing 4G LTE to selected models for the first time with its Starlink system that uses AT&T and SiriusXM connected vehicle services. For road warriors who want to pull over (please pull over) and catch up on email, for parents whose kids need to do homework or stream YouTube on the way to soccer games, for anyone who wants to have connectivity everywhere for any reason, this is likely only the beginning of a trend for automakers to turn your car into even more of an extension of your home.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Audi (all models)
Buick (most models)
Cadillac (most models)
Chevrolet (most models)
GMC (most models)
Subaru (Legacy, Outback, Forester)

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive luxury sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $67,345 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $89,845
Engine: 5.6-liter V-8, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/20 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Mercedes-Benz GL550 4Matic ($90,875)
2015 Cadillac Escalade AWD Premium ($85,065)
2015 Lincoln Navigator L AWD ($69,055)
2015 Land Rover Range Rover LR-V6 Supercharged ($84,490)

Fun-O-Meter: 7

You may not be able to keep up with Infiniti’s across-the-board name changes—the 2015 Infiniti QX80 AWD was known as the QX56 until last year—but the new naming convention seems to have settled into a good place. The QX prefix denotes sport-utility vehicles, followed by a number that gets bigger (QX50, QX60, QX70) as the size of the ride increases.

The QX80, the flagship sport-utility vehicle of the Nissan luxury division, is as big and as luxurious as it gets. In a crowded marketplace of full-size luxury SUVs, it’s truly a standout, with an exterior design that has been a head turner ever since its debut in 2004. The QX80 received a major redesign in 2011, and that was nice. But the 2015 model we’re looking at now has curves in all the right places, with new front fascia, bumper, and grille. It’s big, it’s gorgeous, and it’s impressive.
The model we tested was even better for having the high-end interior appointments that come in the Limited package. It should feel premium: it’s a $10,000 option.

Sitting atop the Infiniti SUV lineup, the QX80 competes against the Mercedes-Benz GL-Class and G-Class, the Land Rover Range Rover, the Cadillac Escalade, and the Lincoln Navigator. On this high-end playground, it’s important to have a certain wow factor. The sticker price of $89,845 on the model I tested definitely qualifies as a big, fat wow. However, the base QX80 is priced at a more sedate $66,350—similar to the base prices of most of the competition. That wouldn’t include the G-Class (which starts at $116,325) and the Range Rover (with a base price of $84,490), indicating that people shopping in this segment don’t balk at a six-figure sticker.

A 400-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8, paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, is sophisticated and powerful enough to smoothly take this 5,888-pound QX80 from a dead stop to full speed ahead and from fast to even faster with zero drama. We don’t have much in the way of hills to climb here in Michigan, but we have plenty of Interstate action to make the most of this luxury liner’s impressive passing power considering its hefty size. Not surprisingly, the QX80 achieves only 14 mpg in the city, 20 mpg on the highway, whether you choose the rear- or (as we did) the all-wheel-drive version. For those with towing in their plans, the QX80 can pull up to 8,500 pounds. I can only imagine what the extra tonnage would do to the fuel economy.
Did I mention the QX80 requires premium gas?

Minor detail. Let’s return to the QX80’s vastness, comfort, and all-around indulgent fabulousness. I was pleasantly surprised by the ride quality of the QX80, especially since our model had the larger (22 inch) wheels. Michigan’s rough roads were barely noticeable, and the QX80’s agile steering helped me avoid the largest potholes without jarring the occupants too much. Assisting in docking this land yacht is the standard Around View Monitor, with front and rear sonar and moving object detection. I personally am a huge fan of the 360-degree camera view, and the added visibility would be a plus to anyone towing.

Those who are not fans of the exterior styling should at least take a peek inside the premium interior of a QX80 with the Limited package and admire its dark Truffle brown semi-aniline leather interior with ultrasuede headliner, quilted seats, open-pore ash wood trim with a matte finish, and leather-wrapped steering wheel and door pulls. Every manufacturer should study the matte wood finish carefully; it is stunning. The Limited package also includes exterior swag such as dark trim details and blings out the running boards with stainless steel caps and lights.

Our test vehicle loaded up on technology, and added extra curb appeal with an amazing-looking wheel and tire package ($2,450). The Driver’s Assistance package ($2,100) includes such helpful technology as blind spot warning, backup collision intervention, and intelligent brake assist with predictive forward collision warning. Frankly, it’s a little disappointing that a vehicle in this price category offers advanced safety technologies as extra-cost options instead of standard equipment.

The options continue with a Theater package ($2,400) that includes heated seats and a pair of seven-inch color monitors, all for the occupants of the second row. Added up, the extras on the model we tested come to $22,450. You could skip all that and buy a second economy car to smooth over your carbon footprint.

Our particular QX80 had seating for seven, with a pair of captain’s chairs that can be tipped forward for access to the third row. If you need one more seat, you can swap out the middle-row buckets for a bench. The third row has seatbelts for three passengers, but if they are any bigger than a middle schooler you’ll need to crank up the stereo to drown out their complaining. Luckily, it’s a Bose thirteen-speaker premium audio system (fifteen speakers if you get the Technology package).

Absent the whining from the peanut gallery, the cabin is otherworldly quiet, cocooning passengers from almost all road noise. The quiet lasted until we kicked up the fifteen speakers’ worth of sound and turned the ride around town into a rolling club scene.
Once you load up the third row with people, there is only a smidge of room left to hold your luggage, but never fear: there’s always the roof rack.

The exterior for 2015 has standard LED headlights, turn signals, and foglamps. Add in those lighted running boards, and the QX80 is as distinctive in the dark as it does in the light of day. High Beam Assist is also standard. This feature uses a camera to read oncoming and upcoming traffic, automatically toggling between high and low beam. I love this feature, which was especially appreciated when driving in northern Michigan on a mostly deserted stretch of Interstate.

The Verdict:

With this big price, you are allowed big customer expectations. Both the cabin and the exterior must exude exclusivity. Not to worry: the QX80 is first-class-airline worthy. For those who like their vehicle to express their own uniqueness, the QX80 may provide the desired amount of aesthetic divergence from an ordinary big-box SUV.

The competition is fierce, though, so if you’re looking in the high-dollar, high-riding premium SUV category, try out all the competitors you can and make an informed decision. A natural alternative is the Mercedes GL-Class, which can give a bump in fuel economy. If you are mainly interested in cushy luxury, check out the Lexus LX570. And if prestige is top of your list, you might  give the Land Rover Range Rover or Range Rover Sport a good look as well.

But all said and done, it’s how you feel when you’re behind the wheel or looking at it out in the driveway, and if the curvaceous, strikingly unusual-looking Infiniti QX80 is your cup of premium tea, none of the competition will seem like good enough substitutes to you.

pageElements.text: How do you know that Automoblox toy cars are the coolest toys ever?
Because these are toys you can take seriously. The proof is in the just-announced partnership between the artisanal toymaker and Brembo, the high-quality brake specialist.

At the 2015 Concours d'Elegance of America at the Inn at St. John's in Plymouth, Michigan, this weekend, the partnership will make its debut by showing the 2016 lineup of Automoblox vehicles, almost all of which will have Brembo brakes, calipers, and rotors. They'll look just as cool, too, with three different rotor designs and a rainbow of colors like the ones on the real-life Chevrolet Corvette and Cadillac CTS-V and ATS-V. Brembo, of course, has been involved in motorsports since the 1970s, starting by supplying racing brakes to Ferrari in the 1975 Formula 1 World Championship.
Unlike the Cadillac and Corvette, you can mix and match the Brembo brakes on the toy cars with a quick twist-off.

Brembo North America president and CEO Dan Sandberg says one reason for the pairing is to "put Brembo components in the hands of future generations of car buyers." But who is he kidding? Adults can play with Automoblox, too. And we'd recommend it.

The Brembo-equipped 2016 cars won't be out until later in the year, but while waiting, you can have a look at the current Automoblox lineup at www.automoblox.com. Or read our earlier review of the Wish-List-Worthy Toy Cars they make.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: It’s a bad moment. You shopped for a car. You read reviews. You showed up with a checklist of must-have features. You tried the seats, tested the cupholders, drove it with a salesperson in the back seat. But now that you’ve got it home, you discover you totally hate the in-car telematics system.  The navigation is maddening, the on-screen apps are unfamiliar and scant, and who knows what is going on with the rest of it. And you realize that you are stuck with it. For years. You paid for it. Like most of us, you’ll use it as a radio and turn to your much more familiar phone for all the other things you have come to expect from touchscreens.

And that is why Google launched Android Auto in 2014. Car companies make cars. And, for the most part, they do that well. Google, on the other hand, has spent decades, fortunes, and countless human hours creating Google search, its voice interface Google Now, and the Android mobile operating system. All are designed to give you access to the information you want right now, easily and quickly. It was a herculean task that changed the world. And today, Google is very good at voice search, mapping, and answering whatever question pops into your head—even if that question is, “Where is the nearest gas station?” That’s why, with rare exceptions, people quickly give up on the in-car telematics and pick up their phones instead. Google spoiled us.
Android Auto is Google’s effort to bring everything you love about your Android phone into your vehicle.

Android Auto is Google’s effort to bring everything you love about your Android phone into your vehicle. If a car supports it, you simply plug in your phone and load the app, and it will take over the dash and use your phone’s data plan to do everything from streaming music to mapping your destination to answering questions you ask Google Now by voice.

I have been trying to hold out against buying a new car until I could get one with a telematics system that ran it. But finding a car that offers Android Auto has been difficult until now. Fortunately that is changing quickly.

The 2105 Hyundai Sonata was the first vehicle to use Android Auto. Chevrolet already offers Apple CarPlay on many models; starting with the 2016 model year, its popular Everyman vehicle, the Chevrolet Cruze, and fourteen other Chevrolets will also support Android Auto. Acura, Audi, Dodge, Chrysler, Ford, Honda, Infiniti, Nissan, Subaru, Volkswagen, Volvo, and several other car manufacturers have announced the intention to include the technology in future cars. It’s far from widely available yet. But it’s getting there. You can find the complete and updated list at the Android Auto site.

Android Auto is a simplified and limited version of the Android you know and love. It’s optimized to be easy to use when you are driving, meaning that it can be understood at a quick glance. The mapping is the same Google Maps you are used to, redesigned for the way you use it in the car. Google Now is available at a touch. You can tap a button to ask Google Now any question you might have and, since it’s been practicing for quite a while on a lot of phones, the answers you get are often startlingly good. The mapping, too, is Google Maps good.
The apps available in the car are much more limited than the vast marketplace of apps in the Google Play store. (But still way more than most car manufacturers support.)

The apps available in the car, though, are much more limited than the vast marketplace of apps you’ll find in the Google Play store. (But still way more than most car manufacturers support.) At the moment there are about twenty, and it’s an odd assortment: Skype, Google Play Music, Hangouts, Kik, WhatsApp, Spotify, iHeartRadio, some texting apps, and a few others.

But all of this is a moving target. Google is a tech company, nimble and fast-changing, and it is famous for testing and perfecting products in the marketplace. Whatever is true at this early stage of Android Auto is likely not to be true in a year or two. More apps will become available, and brilliant nerds will find awesome ways to use it. But that’s okay. Your phone—if it’s a reasonably recent Android phone that meets Google’s specs for using Android Auto—will update the in-car app as it changes.

I don’t know where Android Auto will go. But this much I know: If you’re an Android fan and you can wait for a car with Android Auto in it, do that. In fact, you will want a car that supports both Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. You might get a new phone, right? Because you will want to own that car for a few years. And that moment of hating the in-car telematics is solved much more simply if you can just plug your phone in and be instantly living in the present—whatever that present looks like.
