The CLA-Class is the entry-level Mercedes and, as such, is designed to appeal to younger buyers. The base model, the CLA250, is equipped with front-wheel drive—all-wheel drive is optional—and a 2.0-liter four-cylinder that produces 208 horsepower. Price-wise, it may be the most accessible of the Mercedes lineup, but it has a long list of standard features including a 12-way power-adjustable driver’s seat, a seven-inch LCD display, ambient lighting, Bluetooth audio streaming and mobile phone integration. Also standard on this bargain Benz is the advanced Collision Prevention system—typically an expensive option—that applies the brakes to avoid an impending crash with another car and the drowsy-driving detecting Attention Assist system. Rounding out the semi-autonomous vehicle technology is the optional parking assist system that uses sensors to help you parallel or perpendicular park, which is notable since these advanced features are rarely an option in entry-level vehicles. That said, most creature comforts you’ve come to expect are optional, including heated seats, navigation, and voice-activation. And while the standard MBrace integrates your mobile phone with your car’s infotainment system, getting any of the approved apps to appear in the LCD or integrate with the system controls requires you to pony up for a monthly subscription, which is easy to pass on since you shouldn’t be playing with your phone that much anyway. Another interesting option: an in-dash DVD/CD player that allows you to watch DVDs while the car is in park. As with any low-slung coupe (four-doors or otherwise), you don’t buy it for its rear seat. But the inclusion of two cupholders in the fold-down center armrest is a nice touch of comfort for the back-seat passengers whose heads are likely butting up against the sloping roofline.

pageElements.text:
2016 Mazda CX-3 Grand Touring AWD

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Base price: $20,840 (CX-3 Sport, front-wheel drive)
Price as tested: $27,060 (CX-3 Grand Touring, all-wheel drive)
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 146 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/32 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: 18-inch aluminum alloy wheels
Option I can’t live without: Smart City Brake Support
Notable standard features on this model: 18-inch alloy wheels, LED lighting, heated side mirrors, power moonroof, leather seats with suede inserts, navigation system with voice command, seven-speaker Bose audio
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Chevrolet Trax, Fiat 500X, Honda HR-V, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke

CUV—Crossover Utility Vehicle—is a term that embraces a vast and growing flock of rides, responding to a growing interest in taller, more spacious alternatives to the compact sedan or hatchback. But people are still frugal; much of the growth is occurring at the subcompact end of the spectrum. Which is where this new Mazda offering will compete. It goes on sale in August.

Like essentially everything in this class, it is built on front-wheel-drive passenger car foundations, in this case the little Mazda 2, but bigger in the vertical scale, which translates as more cargo capacity, as well as a little more mass.
Like all its competitors, the CX-3 has a little more ground clearance (5.9 inches) than a conventional subcompact passenger car, and like all the others it offers the option of all-wheel drive.

But when the graded dirt road ends and the trackless outback begins, the CX-3 will be out of its depth. That's okay, since the CX-3 is designed for young adults, most of them with no kids, whose primary driving environment is urban. The only player in this class that’s truly off-road capable is the Jeep Renegade, provided it’s a Trail-Rated version, and it is likely to appeal to different buyers with different needs.

In its more citified milieu, the CX-3's dynamic virtues are nimble handling and acceleration that can be classified as brisk by the standards of this class—a wink or two over eight seconds from 0 to 60 mph.

Power is supplied by a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, sending a max of 146 horsepower to the front (or, optionally, all four) wheels via a six-speed automatic transmission. With front-wheel drive, the CX-3 is forecast by the EPA to deliver 29 mpg in the city, 35 mpg on the highway. With all-wheel drive, those numbers diminish to 27/32 mpg.

And of course, every element of the CX-3—chassis, body, engine, transmission—was developed with what Mazda calls Skyactiv Technology, which is essentially a holistic approach to design and engineering that targets optimum efficiency and minimum mass.
The suspension strikes a civilized balance between athletic response and pleasant ride. There’s little of the lifeboat rock and roll exhibited by some in this class.

Mazda claims that 63 percent of the structure is high-strength steel, which helps to keep weight down—most of the line will weigh in a bit under 3,000 pounds even with all-wheel drive—while yielding high chassis rigidity. A stiff chassis is desirable for several reasons: crashworthiness, interior noise reduction, and a solid platform for suspension tuning.

This is an area where all Mazda vehicles score high marks, and it’s a CX-3 strong suit. The suspension strikes a civilized balance between athletic response and pleasant ride. There’s little of the lifeboat rock and roll exhibited by some vehicles in this class, and the electric power steering has a more accurate and tactile feel than most systems of this type.

But the reality is that few subcompact CUV owners are likely to push their rides to the limits of adhesion, and for routine driving and emergency avoidance maneuvers, the CX-3 will feel more agile than most.

Braking seems to be another strong suit; the brakes don’t mind repeated hard stops, responding as well after twenty vigorous applications as they do to the first. If there are any dynamic demerits, they’re in the aural areas—a fair amount of road noise on some surfaces, and the engine sounds a little coarse when pressed to maximum output.

Sport-utility vehicles are all developed to the same general theme, called the basic two-box design. The smaller box shelters the engine, the larger one the passenger and cargo areas. However, designers have been doing their best to mitigate SUV boxiness, and the CX-3 disguises its fundamental elements of style better than most.

Subtle sculpting eliminates the slab-sided look that afflicts so many vehicles in this genre, a pair of creases lend character to the hood, which slopes down to a signature Mazda grille, and muscular rear haunches help to give the entire package a sporty look. Overhangs, the portions of the car extending beyond the axles, are limited, particularly at the rear, and the relatively low roofline—at 60.7 inches, it’s just 3.4 inches taller than the hatchback version of the Mazda 3—make the CX-3 look more like a car than a CUV.

Interior appointments are particularly upscale for a vehicle in this class, even in the basic Sport trim, and the top-of-the-line Grand Touring version—our ride for a California preview drive—is distinguished by leather upholstery with some very elegant stitchery.

The front seats have a sporty feel, with torso bolsters that provide better than average lateral support, and even though the CX-3’s ride height is low by class standards, a relatively high seating position provides that commanding view that SUV owners enjoy, with good forward sightlines. What you see is what you’re less likely to hit.

Mazda offers a comprehensive array of telematic features and connectivity (Mazda Connect) that’s become so important today, particularly with younger customers. The 7.0-inch display screen that’s home for the optional navigation system juts out of the top of the center dashboard, making it easier to see: a glance to the right is sufficient; no downward eye movement. An asterisk to this is that the radio volume control knob is at the rear of the center console, under the center armrest, and adjusting stations is a tricky business.

Speaking of radio, the CX-3 includes a Bose audio option, which of course enhances the auditory experience, but at the expense of rear cargo space. Cargo capacity isn’t a CX-3 strong suit anyway—just 12.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats—and opting for the Bose system reduces the space to 10.1 cubic feet.

On the same note, rear seat legroom is pretty snug, and as with so many subcompact vehicles the center rear seat isn’t tenable for anyone much over four feet tall. And power adjustable seats are conspicuous by their absence, even in the Grand Touring model.

Safety features (standard and optional) are contemporary, and the CX-3 offers the low-speed (up to 18 mph) traffic minder (Smart City Brake Support) that will stop the vehicle if it “sees” that traffic ahead has stopped and the driver isn’t paying attention. Of course, this would never apply to you, but then again, it’s a safety feature that’s becoming increasingly widespread and a big plus in urban traffic. A rearview camera is standard, and Mazda anticipates top safety ratings from both the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Pricing is another factor that’s attracting buyers to the small-crossover segment. The CX-3 stacks up well in this respect, starting with the well equipped Sport model at $20,840. Base price for the mid-grade Touring version is $22,840, and the edge-of-luxury Grand Touring trim opens at $25,800. Add $1,260 for all-wheel drive.

We’d be remiss if we didn’t point out that the Mazda 3 hatchback overlaps this price ladder, and offers more power, more cargo capacity, and more rear seat space. But it doesn’t have that CUV persona, and it’s less inclined to thrive on leftover parking spaces.
The bottom line: The CX-3 is Mazda’s first foray into the burgeoning world of crossovers, and if fun to drive is a priority for you, it belongs at the top of your wish list.

pageElements.text: Have you ever sought advice from an expert while car shopping? Based on the lion’s share of questions I’ve been asked by confused car shoppers, the most common has been—no kidding—“Which car should I buy?” That’s actually a great first question, because it gets you to sort through the big stuff like, “I need a four-door car that’s good in the snow,” and filters you down to the short list of choices that really meet your needs—and fulfill your desires.

And that’s important, because there’s nothing worse than driving off the lot with a new car, only to feel disappointed with your choice within only a few weeks or months. Sometimes the difference between joy and frustration comes down to a few simple choices.

So, before you go to the dealership and start test driving, make sure you’ve looked at both the big picture (How much can you afford? What body style do you want?) and the small (Is lack of a heated steering wheel a deal breaker?). The automakers all have websites where you can Build and Price a car and figure out what comes standard, what’s in an option package, and what you can’t get at all. A few hours spent playing around, once you’ve thought about your needs and wants, will be fun—and will get you closer to the car that will bring you long-term joy.
Here are seven things to consider as you make your short list.
A few hours playing around on carmakers' Build and Price web pages will be fun and will get you closer to the car that will bring you long-term joy.

1. How much help do you want with safety?

Intrigued by blind spot monitoring and cross-traffic alert technology? You should be. If you want the latest in active safety, look for vehicles that have some or all of the following: a rearview camera; adaptive (sometimes called “intelligent”) cruise control; driver attention and lane-keeping assistance; and parking assistance. Use the Build and Price menu on the automaker’s website to learn what features are standard and what are extra-cost options. Many automakers lay out their menu of safety features on a special web page, and here are some of those.
Acura, Audi, BMW, Buick, Chevrolet, Honda, Hyundai, Mercedes-Benz, Nissan, Subaru, Toyota, Volvo

2. Do you know whether you want front-, rear-, or all-wheel drive?

We explained the differences, advantages, and disadvantages in our article Drive Systems: An Explainer. People who drive on snowy and icy roads may have all-wheel drive as the first item on their wish list. More and more vehicles, both cars and sport-utility vehicles, are available with full-time all-wheel drive, such as the Cadillac SRX, Hyundai Tucson, and Subaru Outback. Those who prioritize power and performance will be making rear-wheel-drive cars their first choice. (The Ford Mustang, the Mazda MX-5 Miata, and the BMW 3 Series are all examples of rear-wheel-drive models.) Front-wheel-drive cars (including such cars as the Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, and Mazda 6) offer a good balance of comfort and handling as well as ease of driving in the winter.

3. How important are screens?

Is touchscreen navigation essential to you, or is your smartphone handling that job? Do you want a 4G LTE wireless hot spot? How about rear-seat entertainment for kids? YouTube is a good resource for how-to videos about infotainment systems. Figure out whether you want to get a higher-end model to get the most out of infotainment on your car.

4. How important is fuel economy?

This can be a real tradeoff. If you value savings more than day-to-day comfort, you’ll probably be looking at some of the smaller, more frugal models that get 40 mpg or better. If you’re deeply concerned about the environment or just enjoy being an early adopter, an electric or hybrid vehicle might be for you. For most people, you’ll want to balance miles per gallon against enjoyment and a pleasant driving experience. Don’t kid yourself about this and get a vehicle you and your family can’t happily live with. Visit fueleconomy.gov to compare some of your preferred models on the basis of their city and highway ratings. Don’t forget to do the math. If you don’t put on that many miles, a small savings in fuel cost is not worth passing on a car that truly makes you happy.

5. What does visibility mean to you?

If sitting up high and getting a clear view out large side and back windows is important, that will dictate a certain style of vehicle, like an upright wagon or crossover. A low-slung sporty car might be a non-starter. If you have gotten used to a rear windshield wiper, make sure you’re getting the type of vehicle that will offer you that—most sedans don’t. As for an impeded view from side pillars, you’ll need to test drive to be absolutely sure what the view looks like for everyone who will drive it. Your tall, lanky teenager might have less trouble seeing out the back, while a shorter person might have more of an issue.

6. Is ground clearance a big deal to you?

Ground clearance is the space between the road and the underside of your vehicle. People who live in snowy places, out in the country, or in mountainous areas probably care about this a whole lot more than city dwellers. It’s summer right now, with clear roads for everybody. Picture your driving and parking situation in the worst weather of the year, and on the worst roads you’ll come across, when you shop for a new vehicle. Some sport-utility vehicles have ground clearances of ten inches or more, and some (Jeep, for example) have an adjustable suspension that lets you choose a ride height.

7. How much do you want various body parts warmed or cooled?

If you live in a cold climate and you’ve never experienced a heated seat or steering wheel, you. have. not. lived. That’s just our opinion, but think carefully when you shop. Do you feel it’s worth an upcharge to get ventilated seats? If you live in a hot, muggy place, you probably do. If you’re going to transport pets in the wayback of a three-row crossover or SUV, you’ll want extra ventilation outlets. An independent heating and cooling control back there will be welcomed by two-legged passengers in the third row as well. If you want heated seats in the second row for your kids or other passengers, make sure the models you’re looking at offer that. It is almost always an option, not a standard feature, and frequently heated second-row seats aren’t even available.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Notable options on this model: Blind-spot warning, active xenon headlights with washers, rear parking sensors, navigation, Harman Kardon sound system
You might also be considering: Acura MDX, BMW X3, Buick Enclave, Lexus GX470

Volvo calls the XC70 an SUV, but it’s really more like a tall, off-road-ready station wagon. With raised ground clearance, skid plates, and scratch-resistant lower side molding, this is a vehicle that is ready to take you just about anywhere you want to go, whether the road is paved or not. And you can carry a lot of stuff with you: With the rear seats folded, the XC70 offers a generous 72.1 cubic feet of cargo space. In some trim levels, the front passenger seat also folds forward, expanding cargo capacity even further.

Volvo has added what it calls Drive-E technology across its lineup, and the XC70 is no exception. What that means is that there is an all-new, 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder and eight-speed automatic transmission teamed with ECO+, a fuel-saving technology that uses auto stop/start and other measures to improve gas mileage. The four-cylinder is only available with front-wheel drive, however, so anyone planning to use their XC70 for off-road adventures will have to settle for one of the six-cylinder engines, which are paired with all-wheel drive. We suggest skipping the 240-horsepower 3.2-liter unit, which is being phased out across the Volvo lineup, and going for the 300-horsepower, turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder.

The XC70’s interior boasts the same ultra-supportive seats found in every Volvo—anyone with a bad back would do well to give them a test. Ergonomically, the XC70 is hard to beat, with intuitive controls, like the climate controls shaped like a human—press the legs to direct air to the lower extremities, press the head to direct air out the upper vents, etc. Mid-year, Volvo introduced a few new standard features, including a leather-wrapped steering wheel and a six-month subscription for On Call, a smartphone app that allows you to control your car remotely. There is also an overhead button in the cabin, similar to GM’s OnStar, that serves as an SOS should you need emergency assistance.

New for 2015

Revised standard and optional features, and an available 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder with automatic stop/start technology and an eight-speed automatic transmission.

Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; supercharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 302 horsepower; turbocharged 2.5-liter inline five-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder, 300/325 horsepower
Transmissions: Six- or eight-speed automatic

Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick+; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision-avoidance system
Notable standard features on this model: LED running lights, dual-zone climate control, Bluetooth, 40/20/40-split flat-folding rear seats, 18-inch alloy wheels, leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Blind-spot information system, adaptive cruise control, pedestrian and cyclist detection, lane-departure warning
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Cadillac SRX, Lexus RX

Mid-size crossovers are all the rage these days, and the competition is tough. The Volvo XC60 needs to compete against such vehicles as the popular Lexus RX and the upscale Germans—the Audi Q5 and BMW X3—not to mention American upstarts like the Cadillac SRX. Even against such a stellar group of competitors, however, the XC60 stands out, striking a compelling balance of performance, comfort, and utility.

As with the rest of the 2015 Volvo lineup, the XC60 has new turbocharged four-cylinder engines using what Volvo calls Drive-E technology. The smaller engines used forced induction to produce similar horsepower to the previous normally aspirated six-cylinder. In addition, an eight-speed transmission helps put the power to the ground with barely perceptible gear changes. These new engines also feature ECO+, which utilizes automatic stop/start and other fuel-saving measures to improve fuel economy by up to five percent.

The two four-cylinder engines are available only with front-wheel drive. If you insist on AWD for your crossover (and many people do), you will have to make do with the carryover five- and six-cylinder inline engines. These powerplants still produce enough power to move the XC60 along at a good page, especially in the T6 AWD R-Design, which is good for an impressive 325 horsepower.

The XC60 is a great example of modern Scandinavian design adapted to the automobile. The floating center stack and swathes of supple leather make the cabin a place where you will be happy to spend your daily commute. And for those times when you need the versatility of a cargo hauler, the XC60 offers 30.8 cubic feet of space behind the second row, and a generous 67.4 cubic feet with the seats folded.

New for 2015

Both four-cylinder engines—one turbocharged and one supercharged—are new, as is the eight-speed automatic transmission. In addition, all 2015.5 models (built after June 2014) have new standard and optional features.

Fuel economy: 2.0-liter: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway; 2.0-liter Cross Country: 24/31 mpg; 2.5-liter AWD: 20/29 mpg; 2.5-liter AWD Cross Country: 20/28 mpg; 3.0-liter: 19/28 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick+; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision avoidance
Notable standard features on this model: LED running lights, heated mirrors, keyless ignition and entry, dual-zone automatic climate control, 40/20/40-split flat-folding rear seats, 8-way adjustable power front seats, Bluetooth, adjustable steering wheel
Notable options on this model: On Call (similar to GM’s OnStar), front and rear parking sensors, rearview camera, navigation, voice controls, sunroof, blind spot monitoring
You might also be considering: Audi Allroad, BMW 3 Series, Subaru Outback

Station wagons are part and parcel of the lives of middle-aged Americans who went on vacations in the family wagon long before the advent of the minivan. As minivans grew in popularity, wagons began to disappear from the U.S. car scene—much to the consternation of U.S. wagon aficionados. So the announcement that Volvo would be bringing a wagon back to the U.S. market was greeted with great anticipation.

The Volvo V60 has lived up to—and exceeded—expectations. Essentially a wagon version of the S60 sedan, the V60 has many of the same powertrains and features as its sibling. Like the S60, the V60 is available with front- or all-wheel drive, with a four-, five-, or six-cylinder engine, and with a six- or eight-speed automatic transmission. Standard equipment includes heated mirrors, dual-zone climate control, 40/20/40-split rear seats, Bluetooth, and a sunroof.

What the wagon version offers that the sedan lacks is 43.8 cubic feet of cargo capacity and a Cross Country version. Yes, that’s right, Volvo has brought back the Cross Country name with a go-anywhere version of the V60. The Cross Country is differentiated from the V60 by a honeycomb grille, skid plates, side scuff plates, black fender extensions, and ground clearance that has been raised by 2.6 inches, to 7.9 inches total. The Cross Country is powered by the 250-horsepower five-cylinder and, naturally, comes with all-wheel drive.

The V60 is fun to drive, with well-balanced handling and strong acceleration, no matter which engine you choose. On top of that, the four-cylinder gets 29 mpg in combined city/highway driving, which makes it both fun and practical.

New for 2015

The Volvo V60 made its debut for the 2015 model year.

title: 2015 Volvo S80
subTitle: Sterotypical Swede.

pageElements.text:

Fuel economy: 2.0-liter: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway; 3.0-liter: 19/28 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision-avoidance system
Notable standard features on this model: LED running lights, power heated mirrors, keyless ignition and entry, dual-zone automatic climate control, 60/40-split rear seats, power front seats, Bluetooth, adjustable steering wheel, navigation
Notable options on this model: On Call (similar to GM’s OnStar), front and rear parking sensors, rearview camera, voice controls, sunroof, blind-spot monitoring
You might also be considering: Acura TLX, Audi A6, Hyundai Genesis

The Volvo S80 is a lot like a stereotypical Swede: logical and reserved rather than emotional and flamboyant. This is not to say that the S80 is boring, exactly, but it does favor comfort and smoothness over horsepower and performance. Its compliant suspension softens the impact of potholes and rough roads, and its seats are among the most comfortable and most supportive in the business.

Because it’s a Volvo, safety is a top priority for the S80. City Safety, a crash avoidance system that automatically brakes the car to avoid or mitigate a collision at speeds of less than 31 mph, is standard, as are air bags all around and active front head restraints. Optional safety equipment include blind-spot monitoring, pedestrian and cyclist detection, lane-departure warning, and driver alert control, which detects erratic driving and brings it to the driver’s attention.

Despite its emphasis on comfort and safety, the S80 has a couple of very capable powertrains. New this year is the T5 Drive-E, a front-wheel-drive model that is powered by a 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission. The T6 model gets a turbocharged 3.0-liter inline-six that makes 300 horsepower and comes with a six-speed automatic. The T6 also has all-wheel drive, which comes in handy when the snow flies. The T6 can also be ordered with optional 19-inch wheels and a sport-tuned chassis that sharpens the handling somewhat.

Practical and user-friendly describe the interior. Both the T5 and the T6 are roomy and comfortable, with a spacious trunk and seats that fold down to accommodate long items. The interior is not flashy, but supple leather is standard on the seats, steering wheel, and gearshift knob, and optional on the dashboard. Controls for the climate and audio system are logical and intuitive—just like the S80 itself.

New for 2015

Revised wheel, trim and package options, and an available 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder with automatic stop/start technology and an eight-speed automatic transmission.

There are a lot of choices when it comes to premium mid-size sedans, but it’s hard to beat the Volvo S60 when it comes to balancing practicality, safety, comfort, and driving enjoyment in a stylish package. It accelerates swiftly, handles sharply, and is in general very enjoyable to drive. The main problem buyers will have when it comes to the S60 is figuring out which boxes to tick on the order form.

A glance at the features list opens the door to a seemingly bewildering array of powertrains and options, as there are four trim levels to choose from, each of which has two or three “sub” trim levels, plus several options packages. The T5 can be had with either front- or all-wheel drive, a 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder or a 250-horsepower, turbocharged inline five-cylinder, and in Premier or Platinum editions. Likewise, the T6 is available with front- or all-wheel drive, but its four-cylinder engine is supercharged and produces 302 horsepower. There is also a 325-horsepower, turbocharged inline six-cylinder on the R-Design model (only available with all-wheel drive), which can reach 60 mph in 5.4 seconds and still get 26 mpg on the highway. All four-cylinder S60s come with an eight-speed automatic transmission, while the five- and six-cylinder models get a six-speed automatic.

All S60s come with a generous list of standard equipment, including front and rear park assist, power heated sideview mirrors, a leather-wrapped adjustable steering wheel, power front seats with adjustable lumbar, dual-zone climate control, and a 60/40-split rear seat. City Safety, Volvo’s safety system that automatically brakes the car to avoid or mitigate a collision at speeds of less than 31 mph, is also standard across the board. Safety has always been one of Volvo’s strengths, and we think it’s worth your while to consider the Technology Package, which includes adaptive cruise control, active collision warning, lane-departure warning, active pedestrian and cyclist detection, distance alert, and active high beams.

New for 2015

Both four-cylinder engines—one turbocharged and one supercharged—are new, as is the 8-speed automatic transmission. In addition, all 2015.5 models (built after June 2014) have new standard and optional features, including automatic start/stop and a Harman Kardon Sound Package.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: No, it isn’t just you. Only seventeen out of 4,002 people surveyed by AutoTrader.com in 2014 said they are happy with the car-buying experience. Shoppers are taking the matter into their own hands, literally, using computers, smartphones, and tablets as car-shopping tools. Looking for the exact vehicle, negotiating the price, financing the loan, finalizing the paperwork—even having your car delivered to your driveway—can now be accomplished by dealing exclusively on the Internet.

Sound too good to be true? When it comes to buying any of the 40 million used cars sold in the U.S. each year, there are more options than ever if you're ready to let your Wi-Fi do the walking and your fingers do the talking. Your next used car can be purchased without ever meeting a salesperson, if you call on one of these four websites as your tool.

1. Beepi.com

Los Altos, California
Slogan: Every car is hand-inspected. Hand-wrapped. And hand-delivered.
Pro: Intuitive, easy-to-use website; 185-point inspection before a car is offered for sale; ten-day money-back guarantee; Beepi buys your car itself if it hasn't sold in thirty days.
Con: Added delivery fees can mount up if you live far from California; cars cannot be test driven in advance.

A virtual middleman between used-car sellers and wanna-be buyers, Beepi (pronounced "beep-eee, like the sound a car horn makes") offers two services: “Buy” and “Sell,” which is exactly where visitors are directed from the moment they log on.

Click “buy,” and you can search by make, model, and other filters, including model year, color, and price range. Available inventory pops up in full color, with pictures of the actual car for sale, along with its price and mileage. Click again, and you get more details on various features such as all-wheel drive—and email access to a human who can answer additional questions and guide you through to purchase.

Each used car that Beepi sells first undergoes a 185-point inspection by Beepi mechanics, comparable to many automakers’ certified pre-owned programs, only less expensive. Prices are guaranteed to be less than dealerships’ advertised pricing, which the site says is possible since Beepi isn’t burdened with the overhead of used-car lots and salespeople. The cars they sell are parked in homeowners’ driveways until they’re sold.
Several hundred cars are available at any given time and available for delivery anywhere in the United States.
Regardless of geography, Beepi delivers its cars via flatbed truck and topped with a giant bow.

Beepi delivers cars for free to customers in California, Arizona, Texas, and Florida. Residents of Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Utah, Colorado,  and New Mexico can also buy through Beepi, but they will pay a $999 fee. Located in another state? No problem. Beepi says it will deliver anywhere. We asked for some estimates, and a delivery to Michigan is $800 for a car, $1,050 for a truck or sport-utility vehicle. To New York, it's $1,000 for a car, $1,300 for a truck or SUV. Regardless of geography, Beepi delivers its cars via flatbed truck and topped with a giant bow.

Customers aren’t able to test drive the cars before buying them. But right afterward, you can take comfort in a ten-day, 1,000-mile money-back guarantee. If you decide within that time that the car isn’t for you, Beepi will send a truck and take it back for free.

Click “sell,” and the site determines the price that car ordinarily commands in your market. Beepi says the price is usually at least $1,000 more than you would receive if trading in a car at a dealer, although likely less than you would get if you sold the car yourself. And if your car doesn’t sell to a private party within a month of being listed on the site, Beepi will buy it from you.

2. Carlypso.com

San Carlos, California
Slogan: Buy your dream car. Up to 40% off. Delivered to you.
Pro: Good selection; low prices; transparent fee structure and what-is-listed-is-what-you-get pricing; thirty days to change your mind after purchase.
Con: Only available in California for now; cars cannot be test driven in advance; website not so easy to understand; cars can only be returned for mechanical defects within 30 days.

Available to used-car buyers as well as sellers with a used car to trade or just cash in, Carlypso is similar to other used-car buying sites in that it can be searched by price, make, model, color, and mileage. It isn’t as eye-catching or as easy to navigate as its competitors, but at least there’s a good selection and reasonable prices with a transparent fee structure.
Carlypso sources used cars from wholesale auctions, leasing companies, and corporate fleets, letting them charge lower prices than at dealerships.

Carlypso sources its used cars from wholesale auctions of vehicles owned by automakers, leasing companies, and corporate fleets in California and Arizona, allowing them to be offered at a lower price than at dealerships. The cars listed for sale remain in the lots of the entities auctioning them until a buyer bids on the car, at which point Carlypso makes the purchase on behalf of the buyer. That’s why the used cars for sale are often only available for a few days or even hours at the listed price.

Carlypso makes its money by charging a $750 fee for models costing less than $20,000 and $1,000 for cars valued at $20,000 and up. Those fees are included in each car’s listed price on the website. Deliveries, however, are not free, and vary depending on the distance the car needs to be shipped.

Although Carlypso's services are available only to buyers in California at present, a national rollout is in the works. The used cars Carlypso sells can not be test driven before purchase. At least they’re inspected by three independent parties before being delivered to buyers, which happens within five to seven days of purchase.

Buyers may return the car within thirty days for their money back if there are mechanical defects that weren’t detected through the inspections. If you buy but decide you simply do not like the car, you cannot return it unless you have pre-purchased a contract cancellation option, which involves a "restocking fee" that can be as much as $500.

Used-car sellers can list their vehicles through Carlypso as well. The company then dispatches a third-party detailer to clean the vehicle and attach a lock box to the license plate that contains the car’s key and enables test drives.

Potential buyers who sign up for the service swipe their driver's license or credit card to authenticate themselves and to unlock the box after reserving a time online for a test drive. A GPS unit remotely tracks the test drive as it’s taking place. The seller also receives a text that the car is being tested. If the test driver wants to buy the car, he or she bids online, and, if approved, pays cash or a cashier’s check into Carlypso’s account, after which the company mails a check and sends a text message to the seller indicating the transaction is complete.

3. Carvana.com

Atlanta, Georgia
Slogan: Skip the dealer; buy the car online.
Pro: Cars are priced below Kelly Blue Book valuation; 360-degree photo galleries of each car; seven-day money-back guarantee for any reason; if you pick up your car at the Atlanta headquarters, there's a gimmicky but fun "car vending machine" from which you take delivery.
Con: Cars can't be test driven before purchase; there's a delivery fee for most areas.

Used-car buyers pay a $1,500 to $2,000 premium just for buying a car from a dealership, much of it attributable to the overhead of a place to store the cars and a staff to sell them. Not coincidentally, $2,000 is the average amount of money Carvana says it saves its customers, because selling its cars online voids the need for such overhead.
In fact, Carvana says all of its cars are priced lower than Kelley Blue Book’s valuation, and it proves it by giving each car with its Kelley Blue Book price and its lower cost through Carvana.

Like other online used-car buying services, Carvana’s inventory is easily searched by make, model, body style, year, price, payment, mileage, color, drivetrain, and other features. Because the cars cannot be seen in person before purchase, each car is also accompanied by a 360-degree photo gallery showing details of its interior, exterior, and under the hood.

All the cars it sells are “Carvana certified,” meaning they are inspected and reconditioned before being resold through the site. Purchasing can be done online or through a "customer advocate" over the phone.

Deliveries take place within twenty-four hours of purchase, free for customers within 100 miles of Atlanta, Nashville, Dallas, Charlotte, N.C., and Birmingham, Alabama. Deliveries within 101 and 250 miles of the Carvana hub in Atlanta cost $199. Deliveries elsewhere in the nation are handled by a third-party delivery company; prices vary depending on location.
With Carvana, cars cannot be test driven in advance but can be returned within seven days of taking ownership for any reason, “no questions asked.”

Cars cannot be test driven in advance but can be returned within seven days of taking ownership for any reason, “no questions asked.”
In addition, Carvana offers a 100-day, 4,189-mile worry-free guarantee should an unforeseen mechanical problem crop up early in the used car’s new ownership.

If you're a buyer and have a car to trade in to Carvana, you can complete a questionnaire and get an online appraisal. Then you can apply Carvana’s suggested purchase price for a trade-in vehicle to the price of the used car you buy or receive a check. And if you need additional financing, Carvana will arrange that, too.

4. Vroom.com

Grand Prairie, Texas
Slogan: More power to you.
Pro: Good selection of more high-end cars; easy-to-understand website and pricing.
Con: $500 deposit required to hold a car (it's refundable, though); cars can be a bit overpriced.

With an inventory of about 1,400 cars sourced from auctions, dealerships, and private parties, Vroom sells everything from Ford’s bestselling F-150 pickup to exotic green cars including Tesla’s all-electric Model S. With an average car price of $36,000, Vroom skews slightly higher end. Among its bestsellers are Chevrolet Corvettes and Porsche 911s.
With Vroom, you can put a $500 refundable deposit on a car. Only then does a real human being enter into the picture to finalize the paperwork.

Like other used-car buying sites, vehicles are searched by make, model, body type, price, year, and mileage. Results are displayed clearly, with photos, actual mileage, a price and what that price translates into per month, including tax title and license fees, over the course of a five-year loan for your exact zip code.

If a car strikes your fancy, you can put a $500 refundable deposit on a car. Only then does a real human being enter into the picture to finalize the paperwork, which is overnighted to your home and returned to Vroom free of charge. Vroom, which is based in Texas, then delivers the car for free anywhere in the U.S. with a full tank of gas.
Buyers who are also trading in a car through Vroom can say buh-bye to their old wheels at the same time. Vroom will pick it up while they’re there.

But no purchase is required to sell a used vehicle through Vroom. If you’re just looking to offload an old Jetta, give Vroom the VIN and send them a few pictures, and they’ll respond with the price they’re willing to pay.

Lacking the middleman of a dealership, Vroom prices its cars below the average competition, it says. It makes its money through a small profit on the sale of each vehicle.  Each vehicle listed for sale is run through a 126-point inspection and reconditioned to a status called “Supremely Certified.” Vroom also says it will not resell cars that have accidents reported to CarFax or AutoCheck, although buyers should be sure to take advantage of Vroom's seven-day, 250-mile return policy and have the car checked by a trusted mechanic once it’s arrived.
Vroom cars also include a ninety-day, 6,000-mile warranty to cover repairs and 24/7 roadside assistance for one year.

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: I Never Stop Talking, Even When I'm Driving

When I pop into my car for the twenty-minute drive home after work, I immediately start dialing.
Obviously, I haven’t actually dialed a phone in twenty years, but, thanks to my bestie Siri, I bark my parents’ names into the phone before I even start the car.

Hands-free dialing is my touchstone with my parents, who live five states away. Then I call my daughter to see what is happening with her. This call is sometimes a long one, but it could just as easily be a voicemail. I almost always call my husband to plan the evening. I figure no need to waste these precious moments, and the drive is easy.
The combination of Bluetooth connectivity and Siri is essential for my productivity, safety, and sanity.

Everyone complains about other drivers being on their cell phones. Well, I must confess that I consider my vehicle my own personal phone booth. The technology available in modern cars seems to be right out of the science fiction books of my youth. Cars are taking giant leaps in becoming more autonomous, but our attention is still very much required to pilot a vehicle safely down the road. My very favorite giant leap forward for mankind is the proliferation of Bluetooth technology in cars. Being able to sync my personal phone with my car is literally a lifesaver. The combination of Bluetooth connectivity and Siri is essential for my productivity, safety, and sanity as I run around town, crawl down the highway in congested traffic, or chew off miles on very long road trips.

When I am alone in a car and I start to get drowsy, I awaken Siri and begin the hunt for life forms. I need someone to have a lively conversation with, to while away the miles and reinvigorate me. There is always a friend who I need to catch up with, and in the car is the perfect time. Obviously, if I am dangerously tired I will stop and take a break.

I always try to dial through Siri or at a stoplight. I anxiously keep my eyes on the light to make sure I am still engaged in driving. My personal motto is driving first, phone second. I will hang up mid-sentence if the driving gets dicey. And I will not read or respond to a text or email. Not once have I responded to the ding on my phone. I admit that at a stoplight I will read a text, but my admirer will have to wait for my response.

I know a lot of drivers are now using their smartphones to run the music in their cars. I can barely switch the climate control in vehicles as I fly down the highway, so that is not happening for me, either. If a car has a touchscreen to use Pandora, I can manage that while driving. As for Google Maps, I use it only if I put the destination in before driving.

Now when it comes to how I want my daughter to interact with her phone while driving, my opinion is flip-flopped. Turn it off until you reach your destination. However, I am no dummy I know she is going to use her phone. I had an aftermarket stereo with Bluetooth technology installed the very first week we bought her a used Passat.

Laura Sky Brown: Let's All Shut the Phones Off, At Least Once in a While

Let us have a moment of silence for...a moment of silence. I have just come from a week driving through eastern Canada, where I had no Wi-Fi, no data, and no international calling plan on my iPhone. That's right: days of enforced non-talking on the phone, non-texting at stoplights, and non-Internet surfing while parked in restaurant parking lots. With two college student kids in the car with me, also not talking, texting, or surfing by phone.
It was glorious.
I would enjoy it so much if the other people driving to my left, my right, and particularly right behind me would take vows of phone silence at rush hour.

As much as I appreciate (and, often, need) the convenience and security of a phone, I wish more people would shut theirs off occasionally. It's a good thing to have only the road ahead to focus on. In fact, I would enjoy it so much if people driving to my left, my right, and particularly right behind me would take vows of phone silence at rush hour.

Bluetooth, letting you pair your smartphone to the car and receive and send hands-free phone calls, is a great invention. I pair my phone with most vehicles I test drive and certainly have it set up with my personal car. But there's a difference between having it available in case of need and treating the car like a rolling continuation of the office. I believe in waiting until I'm parked to have most conversations. People driving in front of me, you're welcome.

There's a reason a lot of people love to go on Sunday drives and take extended road trips. I certainly do. It's the opportunity to close yourself in to the well-loved interior of your vehicle and go out and explore. Driving is less of an adventure than it was 100 years ago, of course: you don't have to worry about breakdowns and flat tires, the roads are usually in drivable condition, and there's an Interstate going close to almost anywhere you want to be. But hang on to the last shred of the pleasure of roaming, and turn off roaming on your smartphone as often as you can. Some things just need to remain sacred.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport coupe
Base price: $34,850 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $41,375
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (2015 BMW 2 Series): Top Safety Pick Plus
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Audi A3 2.0 TFSI ($34,095)
2015 Lexus IS250 AWD ($40,010)
2015 Mercedes-Benz CLA250 4Matic ($34,425)

Fun-o-Meter: 9

Why, do you ever wonder, do BMW drivers have a certain reputation? It’s because they are not necessarily doing what other people are doing when they are driving down the road. They are lucky enough to spend their time inside a vehicle that has been designed, with single-minded focus, for the purpose of driving.
Let’s not get too poetic about being one with the machine, but really, if that was ever true of any brand of car, it’s true of BMWs. Driving them IS the point.

So often, people sit inside their cars the way they’d sit on their sofa, using their steering wheel the way they use their remote control, just sort of surfing along. For many, a car gets you from point A to point B, and everything in between is a waste. That is not the experience of driving a BMW. And a member of the compact 2 Series family? Even less so. Let’s not get too poetic about being one with the machine, but really, if that was ever true of any brand of car, it’s true of BMWs. Driving them is the point.

I have a special fondness for this smart little BMW coupe—I owned a classic (and quite coveted) 1970 BMW 3.0 CSi, a car that put BMW on the map. When it ran (&%$*!), it was sublime. The new 2 Series is as close as BMW has come in recent times to my coupe.
 
Everything about the exterior appearance of the 2 Series, from the understated but chiseled, low-slung body to the eye-catching double-spoke eighteen-inch wheels and metallic brown paint color, is on point. Inside, everything, from the narrowly contoured  Oyster Dakota leather seats to the brushed aluminum dashboard and door trim, is focused and attractive. (And almost everything I just mentioned costs extra.)

And then you drive it. Because, I have to say, it is a riot to drive this little car. The twin-turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine with its 240 horsepower and variable valve control makes sure of that. An eight-speed Sport automatic is the standard accompanying transmission, and it’s BMW worthy. We are talking about an automatic transmission here, folks.

There’s a choice of dynamic driving modes: Eco Pro, Comfort, Sport, and Sport Plus. I worked my way through all four. Eco Pro forces you to be more efficient. Comfort is probably more aggressive than your average sport coupe. That will make you want to see if Sport is even more dynamic. It is. Driving in Sport Plus mode was my personal invitation to be arrested and thrown in the slammer.
The controls are direct and personal, despite what some hypersensitive self-professed “car guys” claim about the electric power steering being artificial in feeling.

In any driving mode, the 228’s controls are direct and personal, despite what some hypersensitive self-professed “car guys” claim about the electric power steering being artificial in feeling. Really? Will you be racing your 228? Get back to me on that steering feel. (P.S. If you will be taking it to the track, you’ll want the $1,600 Track Handling package and BMW’s truly awesome—and free—track app that will let you email your lap times to your buddies, so you can overlay them to see who’s the hero driver.)

A lot of what we like about our test car proved to be extra-cost options. The first thing I would lose is the four-wheel drive. The car would be more nimble without it and would cost $1,800 less. Buy a good set of snow tires if you regularly encounter snow in your life. I would probably suck up the $2,200 for the Sport Line package for the desirable M Sport suspension calibration, the sport seats, and the higher limit on the top speed. I would also keep that $500 heated seat option, lose the metallic paint ($550), and probably buy the Driver Assistance package ($950) for the impressive rearview camera, but I’d hold a grudge that it isn’t standard equipment. After that, you’re on your own.

The Verdict:

The price of entry is not cheap, and you may have heard it on the word of your cousin the stockbroker that a lot of snotnoses own BMWs. The glory and joy of owning one of Munich’s ultimate driving machines, however, is worth every single one of those many dollars. And wouldn’t you love to prove that snotnose thing to be a total myth?

pageElements.text: If you (or the college student in your life) are headed back to school this fall, and the improving economy means you can consider a new car, you’re in luck: There have never been as many good choices as there are now.
You want something practical, affordable, safe, but still enjoyable, right? That doesn’t mean you have to fold yourself and your possessions into a tiny microcar or an unpleasant econobox.

We’ve compiled a list of appealing cars that make top marks in four areas:
● Fuel economy—at least 35 mpg and some as much as 40+ mpg on the highway;
● Cost—at or close to a $20,000 starting price (all prices given here include destination charges);
● Safety—five stars for safety from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, at least four out of five Good marks from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety; and
● Usability—reasonably sized four-door or hatchback models with four-cylinder engines and front- or all-wheel drive.
One of these just might be the perfect car to throw your bags in and head for campus.
If you’re looking for a used car for back to school, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has just issued recommendations for good under-$10,000 cars from a safety point of view.

1. 2016 Chevrolet Trax LS FWD

The Trax is a brand-new small crossover that offers a taller, roomier feeling than a sedan for a bargain price.

Base price: $20,995 (includes destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic transmission
Fuel economy: 26 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety: 5/5 stars, National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (NHTSA)
Top Safety Pick (2015 model), Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS)

2. 2016 Honda Fit LX

The diminutive Fit has a remarkable amount of interior space, plus a very useful multi-angle rearview camera with guidelines that is even standard on this base model.

Base price: $17,410 (includes destination charge)
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 33 mpg city/41 mpg highway
Safety: 5/5 stars, NHTSA; Top Safety Pick (2015 model), IIHS

3. 2016 Hyundai Elantra Value Edition

Hyundai’s compact sedan comes in this enticing version for 2016, packaging must-have items like a power tilt-and-slide sunroof, leather steering wheel and shift knob, heated seats, and rearview camera, all at an attractive price.

Base price: $20,650
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 145 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 28 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Safety: 5/5 stars, NHTSA; Top Safety Pick (2015 model), IIHS

4. 2016 Mazda 3 iSport

Often underestimated, the Mazda 3 is way more fun to drive than its low price suggests—and look at the fuel economy. Bottom line: If you want an economical hatchback or sedan, you don’t have to settle for something dull.

Base price: $19,715 (sedan), $20,415 (hatchback)
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 155 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 30 mpg city/41 mpg highway (sedan), 30/40 mpg (hatchback)
Safety: 5/5 stars, NHTSA (2016 model); Top Safety Pick Plus (2015 model), IIHS

5. 2016 Toyota Corolla Special Edition

The Toyota Corolla is a longtime favorite of the entry-level car buyer. In fact, it’s the bestselling car of all time, with 40 million sold since it first came out in 1966 and now in its eleventh generation. The frugal LE Eco model gets you an impressive 42 mpg on the highway. When you check it out, sit in the back seat and enjoy the exceptional spaciousness for a compact.

Base price: $19,790
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 140 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic transmission
Fuel economy: 30 mpg city/42 mpg highway
Safety: 5/5 stars, NHTSA; Good in 4 areas, Marginal in Small Overlap Front test (2015 model), IIHS

6. 2016 Subaru Impreza

Subaru’s entry-level sedan is priced very attractively, especially considering that it has standard all-wheel drive. If you want your Impreza to have Subaru’s critically acclaimed EyeSight package, a suite of active safety features (adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, pre-collision braking, and more), you’ll have to spring for the 2.0i Sport Limited and also choose the moonroof and navigation system, bringing the out-the-door price to $26,885.

Base price: $20,490
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 148 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 28 mpg city/37 mpg highway
Safety: 5/5 stars, NHTSA; Top Safety Pick Plus (2015 model with optional front crash prevention), IIHS

7. 2016 Volkswagen Golf

The 2015 Golf is an economy car that is so good, it was named North American Car of the Year, only one of several prestigious awards. Available in two- or four-door versions, the Golf can give you a European-car experience at an affordable price.

Base price: $21,215 (two-door), $23,190 (four-door)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway (both models)
Safety: 5/5 stars (two-door), not tested (four-door), NHTSA; Top Safety Pick (2015, four-door), IIHS

Notable options on this model: Air suspension; active blind spot assist; active lane-keeping assist; panoramic sunroof
You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Audi A4, Lexus IS, Cadillac ATS

The 2015 Mercedes-Benz C-Class is the bread-and-butter vehicle for the luxury German automaker, and for good reason: it gets everything right. Longer and wider—yet 200 pounds lighter—than the previous generation, the compact sedan grew a bit for 2015 to keep up with market trends and its customers’ growing proportions. It’s available in a coupe or sedan and with a range of engine options, from a relatively efficient 201-horsepower, turbo 1.8-liter 4-cylinder to the 503-horsepower, twin-turbo 4.0-liter in the range-topping C63 S AMG. There is little to complain about with the interior, except perhaps the Comand infotainment system, which is an acquired taste and thankfully optional on some models. But if you want the advanced features like Wi-Fi hotspot and head-up display, you’ll have to learn to love it.

New for 2015

The C-Class is all-new for 2015.

Price range: $42,375 (includes destination)
Trim level: B-Class
Motor: Asynchronous 177 horsepower; lithium-ion battery, 28 kWh
Transmission: One-speed
Fuel economy: 85 MPGe city/83 MPGe highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Keyless entry
Notable standard features on this model: Push-button start, 7.0-inch LCD with control dial, LED head- and taillamps, split-folding rear seat
Notable options on this model: Parking assist, rearview camera, blind spot warning
You might also be considering: BMW i3

Mercedes-Benz has introduced its all-electric B-Class to the U.S. market as a small expansion of its alternative-propulsion product portfolio. For the moment, the electric hatchback is only available in eleven states, although fifty-state availability is expected. The B-Class seats five, offers a decent 21 cubic feet of cargo capacity behind the rear seats, and retains some of its European design features such as fold-down trays for the rear passenger. The B-Class offers some of Mercedes’ more advanced safety features, including Collision Prevention Assist Plus, which automatically applies the brakes if it detects the vehicle is not braking hard enough to avoid an impending collision. You will still pay extra for features that you might expect standard on a vehicle this pricey and technologically advanced, such as heated seats and a rearview camera.

But as with most electric cars, the majority of the attention tends to be paid to what’s under the hood rather than interior amenities. The electric B-Class is equipped with an electric motor that offers an equivalent 177 horsepower and an impressive 251 pound-feet of torque and moves it from 0 to 60 mph in 7.9 seconds. Mercedes estimates that the real-world driving range of the B-Class is nearly 100 miles, but the EPA estimate is a little lower at 87 miles. Charging times from empty are two hours for a 60-mile driving range and 3.5 hours for a full charge. There isn’t a quick charge option. This means you need to plan your road trips accordingly. However, Mercedes has equipped the electric B-Class with an “extended range” option that makes the battery’s full 36-kWh capacity available, and increases the estimated driving range by 25 to 30 percent. But keep in mind, the fine print states that overuse of this option can increase battery degradation.

New for 2015

The B-Class Electric Drive is all-new for 2015.

pageElements.text: If you’re a responsible pet owner, and we know you are, you want to make sure your dog is safely contained inside the car, whether in a harness or some kind of carrier or crate. But that protection only goes so far, because there are few guidelines to help you know for sure that you’re choosing the safest carrier you can get. Until now.

The nonprofit Center for Pet Safety, partnering with Subaru, just completed testing of several major brands of travel crates and carriers. This is a follow-up to last year’s study of harnesses used in the car. With crates, you want to know: Do they hold up in a crash, or will they collapse and turn your pet into a projectile inside the car?

Two tests were carried out: one set on heavy-duty crates that claim to provide crash protection and cost less than $1,000, and one set on more affordable travel-style plastic carriers that cost less than $150.

2015 Top Performer: Crate

Gunner Kennel G1 Intermediate
Price: $449 to $599; the test used the G1 Intermediate size with eight-inch tie-down straps ($485 for the set)
Sizes: Medium for dogs up to 75 pounds; Large for dogs up to 95 pounds (available in December)
Comments from Subaru: "Far and away the most impressive....able to withstand the most significant forces generated in CPS testing with a combination of strong structural support and integrity."

2015 Top Performer: Carrier

Petego Jet Set Forma Frame Carrier
Price: $144 to $160
Sizes: Small (to 13 pounds); Medium (to 17 pounds); Large (to 22 pounds)
Comments from Subaru: "Used an innovative ISOFIX-Latch connection, to snap the carrier firmly into place and fully contain the test dog throughout the crash test."

2015 Top Performer: Carrier

Sleepypod Mobile Pet Bed with PPRS Handilock
Price: $179.99
Sizes: Fifteen pounds and under
Pet Passenger Restraint System (PPRS) Handilock closure is free to Sleepypod customers until Dec. 31, 2015.
Comments from Subaru: "Snugly straps into the seat and showed no evidence of damage after crash testing."

Crates that got poor or failing results in the crash tests, which of course used dummies rather than actual animals, were: the 4Pets Proline Milan, MIM Variocage, Ruff Tuff, and Midwest Wire Kennel.

Carriers with poor results included the Kurgo Wander Carrier, Petego Pet Tube, Pet Mate Vari Kennel Carrier, Snoozer Roll Around, and Pet Mate Compass Carrier.

See the Center for Pet Safety website for details on the 2015 Crate Study and the 2015 Carrier Study.

title: 2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata Club
subTitle: How does it feel to drive the new Miata? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: How does it feel to drive the new Miata? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: How does it feel to drive the new Miata? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: How does it feel to drive the new Miata? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata Club

Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive convertible sports car
Base price of Club model: $29,420 (prices include destination charge)
Price as tested: $32,800
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 155 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/34 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Easy-open manual soft top
Options I can’t live without: Blind spot monitor, rear cross traffic alert (standard on Grand Touring model, unavailable on Sport and Club models)
Notable standard features on this model: Aluminum shock tower brace and limited slip rear differential (manual transmission only), 245/45-17 high performance tires, front air dam, rear deck-lid spoiler, cloth upholstery with red stitching, nine-speaker BOSE audio, seven-inch touchscreen with Mazda Connect infotainment
Notable options on this model: Club model performance package (Brembo front brakes, BBS forged alloy wheels, side sill extensions, $3,400)
You might also be considering: Scion FR-S, Subaru BRZ

Of course the Mazda MX-5 Miata is enticing at first glance: who wouldn't want one? But there's more behind it than pulchritude; there is history. It has the traits that made the old British roadsters—MG, Triumph, Austin Healey, Sunbeam Alpine—so appealing in the 1950s and 1960s were simplicity, light weight, agile responses, open-air motoring, and affordable pricing.

In 1990, Mazda revived these traits with the first Miata, fortifying them with concepts that were conspicuous by their absence in those old mid-century Brits: a soft top that actually sealed out the weather, roll-up windows, the absence of oil leaks, and contemporary reliability.

A quarter-century later, here’s the fourth generation, and it returns to the roots of the original. Smaller, lighter, and the most nimble Miata yet. Okay, not quite as light as the 1990 original. Safety features (e.g., rollover hoops) and added content make the 2016 Miata heavier than the first generation.

But at a little over 2,300 pounds it’s some 200-plus pounds lighter than the third-generation Miata—lighter, in fact, than any contemporary sports car you’d care to drive daily. That includes the carbon-fiber-intensive Alfa Romeo 4C, the current poster subject for sports car purity.

Reduced weight combined with structural rigidity add up to agility. The new Miata isn’t a track day tiger like the little 4C—it doesn’t have the Alfa’s power-to-weight ratio, and is not nearly as hard-edged. But it’s quick on its feet nevertheless.

And even though the new Miata’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine delivers just 155 horsepower (the third-generation Miata had 167 horsepower), it’s propelling a much lighter car, and 60 mph comes up in less than six seconds. Which makes this the quickest Miata ever. And with weight distribution at an ideal 50/50 percent, it’s the most responsive on a winding back road.
We’ll get back to dynamics. But first, the fundamentals.

The fourth generation is a bit smaller than its predecessor, but this seems not to have affected interior space. The seats are a little lower, the steering column tilts and telescopes (like the previous generation), and a slight increase in seatback reclinability makes the cockpit comfortable for pretty much anyone of sub-NBA dimensions.

It’s a convertible, of course, and the manual top is just as easy to operate as the original. More so, in fact. Depending on your manual dexterity, you can flip it open or pull it closed without leaving the driver seat, and a single windshield header latch secures it. Simple.

The previous generation had an excellent folding-hardtop option, but that’s not on the menu for the new car, at least not yet. Will there be a new version at some point? Mazda responds to that question with a terse no comment, so we’d bet yes, but probably not for a year or two.

The seats are supportive, with generous thigh and torso bolsters, but not race car snug; comfort is the priority. They also feature a new construction technique that eliminates traditional springs and foam. There’s no sacrifice in comfort, and the reduction in bulk enhances space for the occupants.
While the Miata is a civilized two-seat convertible that’s perfectly content purring along a country highway, it’s also a thoroughly capable sports car.

Storage is always a challenge in a sports car, and the Miata is no exception. There’s no space behind the seats, and the capacity of the trunk is just five cubic feet. If a lengthy trip is on your calendar—and the Miata is a wonderful companion for an unhurried excursion on America’s byways—think of that modest trunk space as an excuse to go shopping along the way. Discardable outfits. Carefree highway clothing
While the Miata is an amiable getaway vehicle for two—a civilized two-seat convertible that’s perfectly content purring along some country highway—it’s also a thoroughly capable sports car.

As Mazda never tires of pointing out, more Miatas are racing on any given weekend than all other makes combined, and the company doesn’t intend to allow that distinction to fade with the new generation.

However, it doesn’t require a racetrack to enjoy this car’s eager persona. Any back road with a kink or two will do. There’s enough suspension compliance to isolate occupants from gnarly pavement, even in the Club model, equipped with the $3,400 performance package (Brembo front brakes, BBS forged alloy wheels, side sill extensions, and rear bumper skirt, offered only with a manual transmission).

Yes, there’s an automatic transmission option for all three trim levels (Sport, Club, Grand Touring). Add $1,075. It’s a six-speed, and it actually enhances the Miata’s highway fuel economy rating—36 mpg, versus 34 for the manual version. But the precise engagements and short shift throws of the manual gearbox are far more satisfying in terms of optimizing the partnership between the car and its driver.

While there’s a bit of body roll in hard cornering and quick maneuvers, the Miata responds to commands without a hint of hesitation. The electric power steering is exceptionally precise, feeding tactile information to the driver; throttle response is right now; and the car’s 50/50 front/rear weight balance and unerring predictability build confidence from the first set of turns.
The idea of a sports car is transportation for the spirit, as well as the body—the car as an extension of the driver’s will—and the Miata delivers on both counts.
The idea of a sports car is transportation for the spirit, as well as the body—the car as an extension of the driver’s will—and the Miata delivers on both counts.

The Miata has looked good ever since its introduction at the 1989 Chicago Auto Show, and the fourth generation continues that tradition. Repositioning the engine a little lower and rearward in the chassis allowed the design team to give the car a sloping hood line that hints of shark ancestry and also improves forward sight lines for the driver.

Mazda moved the windshield rearward slightly, preserving the classic long hood/short rear deck sports-car look, and the wide rear stance—the design team enhanced this appearance by setting the taillights slightly inward—suggests athletic prowess. That suggestion is borne out by the car’s performance.

Our test sample was a Club model equipped with the performance package, and the red calipers of the Brembo brakes, plus the forged BBS wheels, add a racy touch to the Miata’s look. But even the basic Miata Sport is a head-turner, one of those rare cars that makes the owner happy every time he or she looks at it.

Speaking of the Club model (from $29,420), it’s the Miata of choice for anyone thinking of spending the occasional day at a track or competing on an autocross course. It’s standard performance goodies include a limited slip differential and Bilstein shock absorbers.

But the basic Sport version—from $25,735—is well equipped (sixteen-inch alloy wheels, gas-filled shock absorbers, LED lights, push-button starting, air conditioning, leather-wrapped steering wheel with audio and cruise control switches, six-speaker audio system, power locks and mirrors, and a glass rear window.

If max handling isn’t a priority, the top-of-the-line Grand Touring (from $30,885) offers luxury features (auto climate control, BOSE premium audio, Mazda Connect infotainment, color touch screen controls, navigation, leather seats), and an extensive list of safety features (although a rearview camera is conspicuous by its absence in all the Miatas).

The Verdict:

Practicality isn’t a strong suit for this or any other two-seat car. The idea is driving fun. The Miata has always delivered on this ethic, and the latest one delivers even more. Pricing has obviously crept up, although Mazda suggests that in terms of current dollars to 1990 dollars, the 2016 Miata is a little less expensive than the original. Be that as it may, there is simply no better sports car buy going today.
