contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Lifestyle factors and improving technology have changed how we maintain, accessorize, and adorn our cars. Whether it’s the more precise fit of components or the implementation of advanced electronic systems, our crude measures of the past are now part of history.

Consider these once common items that are less frequently—or never—found inside or attached to contemporary automobiles.

1. Oil can, spout, and rags

The owner’s manual of a friend’s 1982 Ferrari 308GTSi warns to expect oil consumption of one quart every 250 to 500 miles. “Fill ’er up with ethyl and check the oil” was commonly requested of the service station attendant, no matter what you drove. But as engine design improves, it’s become unusual for a car to consume a quart of oil in 5,000 miles. When did you last see someone open the hood at the gas station and pull the dipstick?

2. Steering wheel knob

Power steering first became available on the 1951 Chrysler Imperial and was considered a luxurious feature even in the 1960s. The 1973 Plymouth Valiant offered power steering as a $100 option. With unassisted steering, clamping a knob over the steering wheel made it easier for the driver to crank it at low speed, when response was heaviest. It also enabled one-handed steering, allowing a guy to throw his arm around his girl.

3. Accessory air conditioning

Even the 2015 Nissan Versa includes standard air conditioning, but fifty-five years ago, A/C was an expensive option found in only 20 percent of all cars. Through the mid-century, some people added an external evaporative cooler, a large cylinder with an internal water tank that clung like a barnacle to the car’s roofline. As the water evaporated by the force of wind, cool air came inside. (Of course, it only worked when the car was moving.) Packard introduced an integrated refrigerated air conditioning system in 1939, charging a whopping $274 for the option. (A new Ford cost as little as $660 that year.) By the late 1960s, about 50 percent of all cars were equipped with A/C. Those on the wrong side of that equation could be fitted with an accessory underdash unit that kept everybody cool.

4. Seat cushions

Wicker or beaded seat cushions prevented a sweaty back on a long drive and insulated against the shock of a cold seat on a freezing day. The seat cushion has evolved to an advanced state, namely, the polyester and foam unit that plugs into the twelve-volt adapter and blows cool air through internal vents. That’s great for thrashing around in an older car. Much more effective heated and cooled seats are available in a wide variety of new cars. Note: The same basic story also applies to rear window shades.

5. CB radio/eight-track player

The citizens band radio provided a way to communicate between vehicles, a useful thing when the national 55-mph speed limit went into effect in 1973. In response, cars and trucks teamed up in convoys to drive faster. Around the same time, accessory eight-track tape decks were mounted below dashboards. Great for Aerosmith, bad for knees. Currently, speed limits as high as 85 mph in some places now have drivers singing a happy tune, no longer calling out a CB handle such as River Rat or Cycle Smoker. As autonomous vehicle technology spreads, cars will talk to one another. As for Aerosmith, Bluetooth streaming delivers them from your iPod to the audio system.

image.altText: Rambler American 1St Generation Black Sedan Credit Czmarlin

pageElements.text:
6. Curb feelers

These springy, segmented pieces of steel were clamped onto a car’s rocker panels, and their probing, scraping noises announced the curb’s proximity when parallel parking.
Replacements: Parking assist technology

7. Tire repair

A jack of the ratcheting or scissors type, a spare tire, and inner tube patch kits—all have been going extinct.
Replacements: Inflation canisters, roadside service, and more durable tires

8. Road Maps

Maps offer their own well-documented rewards, and the AAA still gives out plenty of them. But there are storage and handling issues.
Replacements: Digitized maps for built-in navigation systems, smartphone navigation apps

9. Winter traction sand

Heavy bags of sand or road salt in the trunk added weight over the rear driving wheels, improving traction. And the material could be spread under the tires if the car got stuck. (Sometimes, a shovel was also kept back there.) This has died out a lot less in places with extreme winter climates, of course.
Replacements: Front- or all-wheel drive, traction control systems

10. Snow tires and chains

Rear-wheel-drive cars dug into winter snow with two snow tires, molded with blocky treads resembling those of tractor tires. (They were incredibly noisy on dry roads.) In extreme conditions, the steel chains were wrapped around them, clanking and jangling like sleigh bells.
Replacements: Front- or all-wheel drive; traction control; sets of four snow tires of advanced design

11. Roadside Repasts

A well-stocked picnic basket let travelers stop wherever the state highway department had placed tables under the cottonwoods of a roadside rest area.
Tip: Vintage automotive picnic baskets are collectible these days.
Exception: You may own a Rolls-Royce Phantom, available with a handmade picnic set of oiled teak and saddle leather for four persons (as on the Phantom Drophead Coupe, shown here).

Replacement:

Semi-premium chain restaurants in turnpike service areas have wiped out most of the baskets of fried chicken, potato salad, and chablis.

12. Roadside repairs

Spare fuses, electrical tape, and a radiator hose repair kit were once essential.
Replacements: Smartphone; road service membership; credit card

13. Church key

Some of us kept a church key—the old name for a combination can and bottle opener—in the glove box in order to enjoy an impromptu soft drink or malty beverage.

Replacement:

The wisdom not to drink on the road; open container laws in most states (Mississippi still allows the consumption of alcohol while driving).

pageElements.text: The fight for the car keys between new and more seasoned drivers is one we can all appreciate. Perhaps you’re an adult who fears for dear life and silently prays the rosary when a young driver gets behind the wheel. Or maybe you’re like me; at nineteen years old I have been driving for three years. I grew up in a car family, though, and aunts and uncles like to joke that Boniface grandchildren come out of the womb driving. That certainly doesn’t put any pressure on my brother, Bobby (21); sisters, Julie and Megan (17 and 15), or me, especially when learning to drive under instruction from my dad, a car designer.

Regardless, you know the power struggle at hand. You can understand how stress can sour the sweetness of first getting your license. The peace treaty to end the War of the Driver’s Seat lies at the corner of compromise and understanding. To my younger cohort, we can do a better job of establishing ourselves as safe and competent drivers, and to the more experienced crowd, lightening up on your new driver will do wonders for both of you. Here are some tips to help you achieve all of the above.

For kids:

1. Avoid asking questions that sell short your ability and knowledge behind the wheel.
“Hey mom! I’m on my way home from work, but quick question. How far can I go once the gas thingy says empty?”
“Annie, what does your fuel range say? Where are you? You should have about thirty miles once it hits empty, but how long has it been low??”
“Oh, no. Okay, bye, Mom, I gotta go.” Click.

I am a big offender on this one. Even if I know the answer to my own problem or question, I still like to double check, and like our good friend Ed Sheeran, I suffer from a little syndrome called “thinking out loud.” I will return from college after not driving for five months, hop in the car, and to my mother’s horror, ask aloud, “Hm, which one is the brake again?” You can stop composing the petition to have my license revoked; I promise I know where the brake is. When getting back in the swing of things, though, I mentally and often verbally go over some basics, causing my parents to seriously doubt my driving abilities. I know I’m not alone here. If you’re like me, by simply holding in the rhetorical questions and Googling topics you want to double check, you can save yourself some embarrassment and your parents some worry.
2. Turn the music down.

I don’t care how fabulous a driver you are; if I am two lanes over and can hear the bass thumping in your car, I will steer clear. Adults especially take loud music as a sign of distracted driving. When you’re driving with older passengers, pick a station, set it to an appropriate volume, and leave it, at least until the next stoplight. If you’re alone in the car and simply need to listen to Taylor Swift at level 30, turn it down when you pull in to your neighborhood. Nothing screams “safe driver” quite like my little sister whipping into the driveway with Lil Jon’s “Turn Down for What” blasting through the open windows. In reality, she is a perfectly fine driver, but when you sit shotgun in a car operated by a seventeen-year-old whom you cannot even hear over the music, your life occasionally flashes before your eyes. Do yourself a favor and keep it down.
I can parallel park downtown without so much as a wrinkled forehead when my best friend is in the car, but with my dad in the car I struggle even to go the speed limit.

For adults:

1. Try to pay as much attention to your child’s driving as you would to any other adult’s driving.

Would you criticize your colleague’s hand placement on the wheel? Actually, would you even notice your colleague’s hand placement? Probably not, because you have some degree of faith in other adults’ driving abilities. Try to pretend, if only for a moment, that the teenager you are riding alongside is twenty-eight years old and perfectly capable. Hopefully, you will find fewer glaring errors in their driving once you exit that hyper aware state of mind. Personally, my confidence behind the wheel is inversely related to how much my passengers care about my driving. I can parallel park in downtown Birmingham without so much as a wrinkled forehead when my best friend is in the car, but when my dad sits in the front seat I struggle to even go the speed limit. Give yourself and your young driver a much-needed pressure relief.
2. When giving tips, keep your voice calm and casual.
Parents: When you come across a teachable moment in the car, give instructions in the same voice you would use for ordering lunch.

My mom is infamous in our family for tightly gripping the handle above her seat and calling to my dad in a panic-filled voice when one of the four kids drives during the newly licensed period. Anyone, regardless of age, would feel rather unconfident if their passenger suggested in a half yell that they slow down and maybe pull over so everyone can take a moment to collect themselves.

Recognize that teenagers are indeed new to the driving world and probably feel more nervous about that upcoming left turn than you do. When you come across a teachable moment in the car, give instructions in the same voice you would use for ordering lunch. Clearly express what you would like to see your young driver do, but keep your tone chatty and unconcerned. Yes, you want Panera to hold the onions on your salad, but if you spy some white and purple rings in the bowl you will not break into a lecture about disregard for safety and the diminishing value placed on focus in today’s generation. Same goes for riding with teenage drivers.

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive four-door subcompact sedan

This car: $18,184

Transmission: Six-speed automatic (six-speed manual is also available)
Fuel economy: 33 mpg city/42 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not yet tested; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: not yet tested
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Honda Fit LX: $17,410
2015 Ford Fiesta S: $15,935
2015 Chevrolet Sonic: $16,320
Fun-O-Meter: 7

This would be the year to finally take a look at Scion, a sub-brand of mighty Toyota meant to coax a much younger, much more Internet-savvy buyer to the fold. Scion fired up nationally in 2004, after a sneak peek at the first Scions at the 2002 New York Auto Show, followed by a limited rollout of production cars to 105 California Toyota dealers in 2003.

Once the production versions of the xA, the tC, and the trendsetting xB treehouse on tiny wheels hit the market with full force, it looked like Scion would be the brand to watch. Built with legendary Toyota quality, offered at reasonable prices, and accompanied by a wide range of add-ons to build one your own way, the Scion brand took off like a rocket.
After peaking at just over 173,000 sold in 2006, sales finally fell to earth in the wake of the 2009 depression, dropping to just over 58,000 in 2014.

The all new 2016 iA—Scion’s first sedan—should help stop the slide. With a huge boost from Mazda, the sporty iA muscles its way to the top tier of the subcompact shopping list, alongside the Honda Fit and the Ford Fiesta.

It’s actually shocking how good this little car is to drive. It shouldn't be, though, because it's based on the Mazda 2 (the green car pictured here), only with a crazy-looking front end from Scion. There are a few other bits and bobs from the Scion/Toyota parts bin inside, but, in all but name, this is a Mazda 2.

The little Mazda 2 may be the lesser of all the great Mazdas, but I happen to like it. In the Scion lineup, it's a real standout, with a buttoned-down ride and electric steering with a very tight turning circle that makes you feel as if you’re piloting a go-kart.
With a huge boost from Mazda, the sporty iA muscles its way to the top tier of the subcompact shopping list, alongside the Honda Fit and the Ford Fiesta.
The fine suspension and tight steering are compliments of the Mazda 2. They’re so good that even the Scion guys wax eloquent about the competence of Mazda’s chief suspension engineer.

The iA I drove was equipped with a six-speed automatic transmission; a six-speed manual is also available. You would be right not to expect entertainment from the automatic transmission. But wait. There is a Sport button, and when you hit it, shift points are suddenly amped up, with an added growl. Okay, maybe it’s not an actual grrowwwl growl, but there’s certainly a noticeable uptick in the amount of excitement in the air.

The iA’s interior shares a Toyota aesthetic: clean and ergonomically correct, with a high level of quality craftsmanship, if carried out with pretty basic materials. This, too, is compliments of the Mazda 2. If you want to see a truly inspired interior, have a look inside the new Scion iM. Too bad the iM, with its laissez-faire steering, is not as fun to drive as the new iA.

Wrap your head around a satisfying, sporting little sedan, stuffed with this much premium content, for a base price of $17,595 (including destination charge) and a final price of $18,184, which includes $419 for navigation and $170 for door-sill protectors. If you've been in the market lately for a used car, you'll find it difficult to find a barely acceptable car for under $10,000, and once you go under that $10K, you aren’t likely to get a used car that’s in the Certified Pre-Owned category. Meaning you’re on your own, warranty-wise.

Instead, for an extra $7,600, you can get this iA: a brand-new car, absolutely loaded, made by Mazda and Toyota, that looks good. Okay, that last point is debatable. But it does have excellent fuel economy (33 mpg city/42 mpg highway with the automatic transmission).

Scion would certainly like to maintain its industry-low average age of buyer, which is among the absolute lowest in the industry. Scion saw it climb as sales fell. The funky little xB (shown here) was gunning for twenty-five-year-olds, but instead it attracted a large number of older women. Nothing like seeing your grandma driving an xB to make you look elsewhere for a new car.
Just saying.

This time, Scion is aiming at thirty-five-year-olds. (Who, if you think about it, are the exact same twenty-five-year-olds it marketed those first Scions to a decade ago.) Today’s young drivers are getting their licenses later (but girls earlier than boys), they are saddled with greater college debt, it's harder to find jobs, and therefore they are not so much in the market for a new car as they were when Scion first launched.

So, it's up to Millennials. I brought my own with me, Jean Knows Cars intern Annie Boniface. Annie is on the younger end of the millennial curve—she's a sophomore in college, studying to be a journalist. Annie is a little more hyper-aware of cars than the average nineteen-year-old college student because she's part of a large extended family of Alfa nuts. Although she doesn't share the rabid enthusiasm of her male cousins for arcane automotive minutiae, she likes cars and likes to drive, and she has a sharp eye and strong opinions. Here are a few closing words from our personal Jean Knows Cars Millennial on the subject of the Scion iA:

At first glance, the iA looks like a well-made and attractive car, if you ignore its guppy-like face. The car we drove was a beautiful navy that Scion calls Abyss, a color that I believe looks good on everyone. Moving inside, I immediately thought the $17,595 price tag was a mistake. The seven-inch Display Audio touchscreen caught my eye, and there were high-quality materials everywhere I looked from the dash to the seats to the floor.

When I drove the iA, a few features really stood out. There is a knob between the front seats that controls the infotainment screen, and I quickly started referring to it as the Wheel of Fun. I found it surprisingly intuitive and convenient. The iA's electric power steering was a dream, ultra-responsive and direct. Speaking of responsive, the gas and brake pedals required only a tap. The Sport mode was very noticeable, and actually hearing the revs made me feel, well, like a badass. Or as much of a badass as you can be in a subcompact sedan.
The Scion marketing people claim the target audience for the new iA is “practical Millennials,” and while I thought that sounded like BS at first, I have to admit I now kind of agree with them.
I am a Millennial, and if I was shopping for a car, I would add the iA to my short list just based on the quality I could have for under $20,000.

The Verdict:

The appeal for any age group comes back to two things, doesn’t it: the astonishing level of standard features, some of which you couldn't find on high-level, expensive luxury cars without paying a premium for, and the astonishing price
So, there you have it. Whether you’re a twentysomething or a person from a more mature demographic, this really should be the year you have a good look at Toyota’s Scion brand.

pageElements.text:
2016 Honda Accord Sport

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Base price (base LX, six-speed manual transmission): $22,925 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $24,985
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 189 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated; 2015 model is an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard feature: Multi-angle rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Honda Sensing package (approximately $1,000; includes forward collision warning, collision mitigation braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, adaptive cruise control)
Notable standard features on this model: Nineteen-inch alloy wheels, LED daytime running and fog lights, dual exhaust, side sills, body-color rear deck-lid spoiler, aluminum-clad foot pedals, leather wrapped steering wheel, ten-way power adjustable driver’s seat, 160-watt four-speaker audio
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

The Accord is certainly no stranger to the U.S. mid-size sedan free-for-all, and through nearly four decades and nine generations, it has always ranked at or near the top of the charts in comparisons. That's especially impressive given the sheer number and quality of competitors in the mid-size sedan category.

The new Accord is the second edition of the ninth generation of the popular car. Although the tenth generation is still a couple of years away, this Honda is a good bet to sustain its position at the front of the pack. Its perennial virtues—quality assembly, all-day comfort, flawless road manners, a high fun-to-drive index, and top safety ratings—have been augmented by updates for the 2016 model year.
One of the most important changes is what you see. Honda hasn’t been noted for risk taking with Accord styling, but the new front end treatment is almost, well, bold.

Inside, the change in looks continues with new fabrics, more soft-touch surfaces (although a few hard plastics remain), and updates to the infotainment functions with the addition of Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Honda persists with its commitment to a touchscreen secondary control system that’s devoid of buttons and/or knobs, which some might find annoying. But overall the impression is one of improved quality and comfort.

The engine choices are essentially unchanged: a 185-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder, which is improved to 189 horsepower on the Sport model we tested, and an optional  278-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6. Transmission options are basically the same as well: a six-speed manual is standard. A continuously variable automatic transmission is optional with the four-cylinder and a six-speed automatic with the V-6.

While all of this is familiar, the powertrain engineers have made some adjustments to the continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT), programming artificial shift points into the control chip to make it feel more like a conventional automatic. This is a definite improvement, although there is no manual control function. On the other hand, the four-cylinder/CVT combination continues to be the fuel economy champ among the Accord’s conventional powertrains, with EPA ratings of 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway, better than you get with the manual transmission (23/34 mpg on the Sport).
The V-6 models are projected to deliver 21/34 mpg with the six-speed automatic transmission.

Hybrid versions of the Accord disappear for 2016, but Honda hasn't given up on the technology. They're slated for engineering updates and a return for the 2017 model year, with production scheduled to relocate from the U.S. back to Japan.
The 2016 updates continue with a stronger chassis, a retuned suspension for improved response, and changes to the electric power steering for improved accuracy and road feel.
On the fun-to-drive scale, the Sport versions of the Accord, with the four-cylinder engine and manual transmission, continue to be the way to go.

The Accord’s reflexes are at least as sharp as ever, and its responses as decisive as any car in this class, so if you're looking for a strong fun-to-drive index and confidence in emergency maneuvers, it's right there where you want it to be.

On the fun-to-drive scale, the Sport versions of the Accord, with the four-cylinder engine and manual transmission, continue to be the way to go. There’s obviously a lot more easy cruising power in the V-6, but the Sport model’s lower curb weight, better weight distribution, firmer suspension tuning, and nineteen-inch wheel/tire package (also found on the top Touring model) make this version of the Accord the line’s athlete. The base model gets sixteen-inch wheels and tires, while seventeen-inchers are found on the EX and EX-L.

Then again, while the V-6 Accords may not be quite as quick on their feet, power is smooth and plentiful, the function of the automatic transmission is close to seamless, ride quality is firmly compliant, and interior noise levels are noticeably lower than even the 2015 Accord, which was already quiet.

Safety features are another area of improvement. Noteworthy for 2016 is a package bundling adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, forward collision warning, and forward collision mitigation. They're grouped in the new Honda Sensing suite of features. It’s standard on the top-of-the-line Touring trim level and an option at an estimated $1,000 on others.

The Accord is offered in coupe and sedan body styles, and the pricing ladder for 2016 is a little bewildering, with forty-four different distinctions: twenty-five for the sedan and nineteen for the coupe (pictured), some of them identical.

Here are base prices for the major trim levels:
Sedans:
LX (four-cylinder, six-speed manual transmission), $22,495, add $800 for CVT
Sport (four-cylinder, manual), $24,985
EX (four-cylinder, manual), $26,300
EX-L (CVT only), $29,93; EX-L (V-6, six-speed automatic), $31,465
Touring (V-6, automatic), $35,400

Coupes:
LX (four-cylinder, six-speed manual transmission), $24,595
EX (four-cylinder, manual), $26,720
EX-L (four-cylinder, continuously variable automatic transmission), $29,295
EX-L V-6 (manual), $31,745; EX-L V-6 (automatic), $31,745
Touring (V-6,automatic), $34,945

The Verdict:

There is no such thing as a real loser in today’s busy mid-size sedan market. But even so, if all are good, some are better than others, and some excel. The Accord fits into the latter category—exceptional quality, excellent road manners, all-day comfort, solid safety credentials, and high resale value. Add the 2016 updates, and Honda has yet another solid case for best in class.

Dodge dropped the price of its fifth-generation Viper, opening another door to the 600-horsepower club. This car’s price cut is meant to turn heads as much as its curves do to get buyers shopping for the most performance under $100,000. What they’ll find is that its muscular and aggressive body—with its aluminum doors and carbon fiber hood, roof, and deck lid—are not just for looks: they improve aerodynamics and stability as much as style. All models are equipped with the standard 8.4-liter V-10 engine that produces 645 horsepower and 600 pound-feet of torque and are paired only with a six-speed manual transmission. The top track speed of the Viper is rated at 206 mph, and it launches from a stop to 60 mph in around three seconds. But getting there presents its own challenges, so launch control is a standard feature, and the five-mode electronic stability control system on the GT model (standard is three-mode) will keep you on the track and out of the ditches. The interior can be described as mission control chic. The deep racing seats of this two-seater set the tone for serious performance driving, and the traction and launch control button mounted on the steering wheel give it that track car feel. Creature comforts like heated and ventilated seats and a telescoping steering wheel are absent, but technological conveniences such as the Uconnect 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system with navigation, satellite radio, and voice command Bluetooth connectivity are standard. Tradeoffs. On the upside, Uconnect features a special set of SRT performance screens to help you monitor that redline, which you should definitely be pushing since this beast can take it.

New for 2015

A lower price and a 5-horsepower bump.

More than 10 million have been built in North America, in fact, so many that the Honda dealers could put up a McDonald's-style "Millions Served" sign if they wanted. But does ubiquity lead to contempt? Not in our book. The Accord has won a place in so many driveways precisely because it's so well executed. Buyers flock to it knowing they can count on it to be well built and reliable as well as comfortable and drivable. If there's a little less excitement than with a lot of other cars you could choose, well, it's a mid-size, front-wheel-drive sedan, not a sports car. 2016 brings changes to the ninth-generation Accord that was introduced for 2013. Think of it as ninth generation 2.0, while we wait for the all-new tenth generation in a couple of years.

Notable options on this model: Lane Watch (EX and up), blind spot information system (Touring only)

The Honda Odyssey has been the choice for years of people with large families and a taste for comfort. For 2016, Honda has added a new Special Edition model that brings some of the highest-end amenities down to a more affordable price point. Among them are the vaunted HondaVAC in-vehicle vacuum cleaner and a rear-seat entertainment system. You'll find that, with so many trim levels (eight!), you won't be scratching your head checking out an à la carte options list. Instead, move to the EX-L model and up to get a leather-wrapped steering wheel and seats, heated front seats, a power moonroof that tilts, and best of all, a power tailgate. Forward collision warning, lane departure warning, and Honda's unequaled multi-angle rearview camera with guidelines come with the EX-L and up, too. All but the base LX seat up to eight, with five car seat anchors—with the idea that you have flexibility, not that you'll be carrying five kids in car seats! But, even if you are, this is one vehicle that can handle it. It also tows up to 3,500 pounds and has a full 172.6 cubic feet inside, so you get it all: as much luxury as you want in your minivan, plus a whole lot of capability.
New for 2016: New "high value" Special Edition (SE) model with rear-seat entertainment, SiriusXM satellite radio, and HondaVAC vacuum cleaner.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: Sport, Latitude, Limited, Trailhawk
Base price: $28,090 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $33,825
Engine: 3.2-liter V-6, 271 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in 4 of 5 categories
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Escape SE AWD ($27,805)
2015 Honda CR-V EX AWD ($27,675)
2016 Subaru Forester 2.5i Premium ($26,645)
2015 Toyota RAV4 XLE AWD ($27,525)
Fun-O-Meter: 10

There are a few names in the automotive world that paint an immediate mental picture: Corvette. 911. F-150. Suburban. And Jeep. You aren’t just buying a vehicle when you choose one of these; you’re signing on to become part of a rich history.

You’ll know that as soon as you get into the 2015 Jeep Cherokee: the words “Since 1941” are right there on the steering wheel, reminding you that this is not just another small crossover or sport-utility vehicle. It’s very citified now, but it traces its heritage back to the early days of World War II, when the first Jeeps were developed to be tough enough to get troops anywhere, under any conditions.
In other words, there’s a feeling of realness to the Jeep Cherokee, and that’s worth something.

After twenty-seven years as a Chrysler property, Jeep is under Fiat ownership now, but this is one authentic nameplate that Italian auto giant Fiat has wisely capitalized on without diluting the intrinsic mojo. When Chrysler was going down, it was the Jeep nameplate that was valuable. Jeep’s new subcompact Renegade is a hit in Europe, and the brand is expanding globally.

But you’re not just buying the name, glorious though its history may have been. Jeeps are vehicles with great visibility, go-anywhere ground clearance, and fabulous all-weather, all-terrain capability.
The Cherokee in particular is a vehicle that says something good about the person driving it. It stands for fun, spirited, adventurous living, and it's unpretentious.

The Cherokee in particular is a vehicle that says something good about the person driving it. It stands for fun, spirited, adventurous living; it’s down-to-earth, all-American, outdoorsy, and unpretentious. The Cherokee is affordable, therefore accessible to more people.

If you are looking at a sport-utility vehicle and want to keep the price under $30,000 and the size somewhat compact, the Cherokee is a strong contender in a hugely competitive marketplace. The Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, and Toyota RAV4, among others, are selling good front- or all-wheel-drive crossovers to millions.  Subaru makes the Forester and the Outback with similar all-wheel-drive, all-road capability. But none of these have quite the inimitable rugged charm of a Jeep.

There’s more versatility to the Jeep product, too. With the Cherokee, you can choose from front- or all-wheel drive. You can have a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine making 184 horsepower or a 3.2-liter V-6 making 271 horsepower, and you can select one of three four-wheel-drive systems that go from full-time all-wheel drive to utterly adjustable whether you’re a foot deep in water or perched on the edge of a mountain. Every Cherokee, though, comes with a nine-speed automatic transmission.
The modern Cherokee, redone in 2014, has a softer, rounder, more crossover-like front end. Try to get over it. Move on.

Your mental image of a Jeep probably includes a macho vertical grille and round headlamps. The modern Cherokee, redone in 2014, has a softer, rounder, more crossover-like front end. Try to get over it. Move on.

The entry-level Sport model, with a 184-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine, starts at $24,090 for the front-wheel-drive model. The Latitude that we tested is the second of four trim levels, priced starting at a reasonable $28,090 (including destination charge) for the all-wheel-drive version. The more luxurious Limited version starts at $29,890 and features standard leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel and my personal must-have, heated front seats. There’s also a limited-edition Altitude model that’s notable for larger (eighteen inch) wheels and all-black exterior trim instead of chrome.
Or do what I’d do and upgrade to the off-road specialist, the Cherokee Trailhawk shown here, which starts at $31,390 and comes only as an all-wheel-drive model.

Ground clearance (measured from the lowest hangy-downy part of the undercarriage) on the Cherokee, 8.7 inches, sets it apart from the more urban-style crossovers it competes against, and if you frequently drive on rutted country back roads or in the snow, you know for a fact that more is better. The Cherokee’s height is equaled only by Subaru’s Forester, while the Honda CR-V is much closer to the ground at 6.8 inches, as are the Toyota RAV4 at 6.3 inches and the Ford Escape at 7.9 inches.

The Latitude looked, felt, and drove like a real Jeep, meaning it felt sturdy inside and out, was unfazed by rutted dirt roads in rural southeast Michigan, was capable without any unpleasant bounciness, swallowed up a week’s worth of vacation equipment with ease, and still felt as comfortable heading to the grocery store on the highway as it did heading to the lake by the partly unpaved scenic route.

The Latitude we tested had the $1,745 Comfort/Convenience group, including several useful features such as dual-zone climate control, but notably remote start and a power liftgate, both very easy to get used to. More important, it had the SafetyTec package ($1,045) with a few features that are reasons in themselves to look for a new vehicle these days: rear park assist, blind spot monitoring, and cross-path detection. Choosing the V-6 adds $1,745 to the $28,090 base price. Thanks in part to standard fuel-saving stop/start technology on V-6 models, the EPA only deducts one measly mpg from the fuel economy versus the four-cylinder (20 mpg city, 28 mpg highway for the V-6; 21/28 mpg for the four-cylinder),  so why wouldn’t you?

The other option on our Latitude was the $600 Uconnect infotainment system with satellite radio, a USB port, and an 8.4-inch screen (a 5.0-inch screen is standard)—but not navigation. That’s a separate option, at $595, and one that we’d go for in a heartbeat considering all the unfamiliar terrain we’d like to cover in a Cherokee.

If you are looking at an all-wheel-drive version of the Cherokee—and if you want my opinion, that’s the way to get any Jeep—there are three versions to choose from. The “light duty” Active Drive I is the standard version that was on our test Cherokee Latitude. It’s the equivalent of other crossovers’ full-time all-wheel drive. There’s nothing for you to do except enjoy how well it goes in snow and on bad roads. The optional Active Drive II ($995), available on Latitude and Limited models, has a selector with low range and hill descent control settings for more adventurous driving or towing. You’ll also get an off-road suspension that adds an inch to ride height.

On the Trailhawk model, the Active Drive Lock 4x4 system is standard. It’s Trail Rated for off-road driving—meaning that it has been tested and graded (http://www.jeep.com/en/jeep-capabilities/trail-rated/) for capability in water fording, traction, maneuverability, articulation, and ground clearance off-road. The Cherokee Trailhawk (pictured here) also has an off-road suspension, a mechanical rear axle lock, and a traction management system that Jeep calls Selec-Terrain, letting you select from Auto, Snow, Sand/Mud, and Rock modes.

I have an affinity for the Trailhawk because any Jeep I chose would have to be able to ace the nine-mile trail of the Jeepers Jamboree in the mountains of Georgetown, in northern California. It is an amazing off-road event that began in 1952, and I had been told that it was notoriously difficult to traverse. That was correct. I did it in a brand-new (at the time) 1995 Jeep Wrangler with a six-cylinder engine and brought it through without a scratch. Yes, I absolutely nailed that nine miles in a mere seven hours. It was among the most memorable driving exploits of a life rich with driving exploits.

That doesn’t take anything away from the excellent capability, good looks, and usefulness of the other Cherokee models. In any of them, you’ll feel a lot more adventurous just getting behind the wheel. Anyway, you might not be planning to hit the Rubicon trail yourself, but what a feeling to know that you could.
You may have figured out that I think any Jeep I test rates a “10” on my Fun-O-Meter just because it’s a Jeep. But a 2016 Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk? The Fun-O-Meter would go off the chart.

title: 5 Common Spills You Can Clean Yourself
subTitle: Get out the common household products to make headway with these unpleasant car-upholstery messes.
promoTitle: 5 Common Spills You Can Clean Yourself
promoTeaserSmall: Get out the common household products to make headway with these unpleasant car-upholstery messes.
promoTeaser: Get out the common household products to make headway with these unpleasant car-upholstery messes.
keywords: 5 Common Spills You Can Clean Yourself
metaTitle: 5 Common Spills and How to Clean Them - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: cleaning fabric seats in the car
how to get stains out of car upholstery
cleaning road salt out of car upholstery
baking soda as a car cleaner
metaDescription: Get out the common household products to make headway with these unpleasant car-upholstery messes.

pageElements.text:
Images courtesy of Dr. Beasley's

What is more annoying than seeing a cup of coffee flip upside down when you go around a curve in your beautifully upholstered new car? Or more discouraging than realizing your back seat carpeting has ground-in road salt that you may never get out?

A professional detailing job can go into the triple digits, so chances are you’ll be trying to get those stains out on your own before you hand over $100 and more to the pros.
If you want to keep your vehicle looking good inside—and keep the resale value—keep these tips in mind when you prepare to attack stains and dirt on the fabric inside your vehicle.

1. Coffee

Problem: Oils in coffee make it a persistent stain, and—with so many people drinking coffee while they commute—a common one.
Solution: A white vinegar and water solution, sprayed on the stain, will break it up; use that caffeine buzz and do it as soon after the spill as possible. One part vinegar to two parts warm water, sprayed from a bottle, will help lift the stain; then wipe with a microfiber cloth or sponge. Two other household products people swear by are raw egg yolks applied directly to the spot, then rinsed thoroughly with cold water, and club soda, especially if applied immediately. Use a fan or blow dryer to dry the area once it’s clean.

2. Milk

Problem: This one can “cook” into the upholstery if you’re using the wrong method to clean it up.
Solution: Clean it as quickly as possible. If you can’t, soak the stain using cold water, then clean with mild detergent.
Milk? In the car? You don’t have to ask about that if you’re a parent. At some point, your baby or toddler will be holding a bottle of milk or formula while riding in the car, and he or she will tip it or squirt it—or spit it up—into the back seat. Let that run down a seat a few times, and you have a Situation. A smelly situation.

The best way to clean it is to get it clean immediately. Failing that, soak the affected area with cold water (not warm; that will set the stain). Then clean using water and a small dollop of dish soap. You can also make a paste using water and baking soda, let it sit briefly, and then vacuum it up using a Shop-Vac or Dustbuster. The baking soda helps neutralize the odor, too.
For even more odor neutralizing, products such as Febreze or Neutra-Scent, a spray made by artisanal car-care company Dr. Beasley’s, can help.

3. Road salt

Problem: Almost unavoidable in winter, its streaky effect can last into the warm months if you don’t take action.
Solution: Get really good winter floor mats before next winter, and try vinegar and water as a spot cleanser.

Make a mix of half white vinegar and half warm water, put it in a spray bottle, and spray the places where salt stains have happened. Scrub with a toothbrush or nylon-bristled scrub brush, then vacuum or use a towel to soak up the salt. You can minimize the need to do this every spring if you get a sturdy set of winter floor mats made of rubber to put over (or replace) carpeted floor mats.

4. Ink

Problem: That upside-down pen the kids left in the back seat has left its mark.
Solution: Blot, don’t rub. There are several home remedies involving baking soda, vinegar, dish soap, even hairspray.

First, blot the stain with a paper towel or soft cloth so it won’t spread further than it already has. Then count on a vinegar-based solution to pull out the stain. Mix a squirt of dish soap and about a tablespoon of white vinegar with water, blot the area with a soft cloth, then rinse it clean with cold water. Some people swear by hairspray to break up the stain. Really? Hmmm. We haven’t tried that (and we’re not likely to), so you might want to check that out on a place that doesn’t show.

5. Dirt

Problem: Good old dirt, whether topsoil or minuscule cookie crumbs, will eventually make your car interior look crummy. (Or crumby. Hahaha.)
Solution: Vigilance in the form of regular surface cleaning.

Run a vacuum through your car regularly so dirt doesn’t get enough chance to settle in. A hot-water carpet shampooer (which you can rent from the local grocery or hardware store) and a nylon brush will let you give your seats and floors a full detail treatment for a reasonable price. Hint: Plan to shampoo the interior twice, just like the directions on shampoo bottles: lather, rinse, and repeat to get the layer of ground-in dirt that will surface after the first wash. It will be wet in there, no matter how much you vacuum after rinsing, so don’t just close the car doors and walk away. Set up a fan, keep windows open as long as you can, and let it get dry, or you’ll have mildew to worry about removing next.

For spot cleaning, a bucket of very hot water, some fabric stain remover, and a nylon brush work just about as well as a carpet shampooer does over smaller areas. Then vacuum the area and blot with a cloth to pick up any excess moisture.

Transmission: Six-speed manual (LX, EX) or continuously variable automatic with paddle shifters (LX, EX, EX-L, EX-L with Navi)
Fuel economy: 29 mpg city/37 mpg highway (six-speed manual transmission); 33/41 mpg (CVT, LX model); 32/38 mpg (CVT, EX and EX-L models)
Safety ratings: Not yet rated; 2015 model was Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Magic Seat split-folding rear seat
Notable standard features on this model: Multi-angle rearview camera, five-inch infotainment touchscreen (LX), seven-inch infotainment touchscreen (EX-, EX-L)
Notable options on this model: Power moonroof with tilt, Lane Watch, push-button start, floor mats, HDMI port (all optional on EX and EX-L); leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel, heated front seats (optional on EX-L only); navigation system with voice recognition, HD digital traffic (optional on EX-L only)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Sonic, Ford Fiesta, Hyundai Accent, Kia Rio, Toyota Yaris

You'd be forgiven if you have dismissed the Honda Fit as yet another really cramped city car. It is so much more than that: almost shockingly spacious for a subcompact hatchback, the Honda Fit offers a degree of flexibility for daily use that just might spoil you for larger, less fuel-efficient cars. With seats in place, the Fit offers 16.6 cubic feet of cargo space, which is more than you'll see in competitors such as the Chevrolet Sonic or Ford Fiesta hatchback (both at 14.9) and the Kia Rio five-door (12.3). Fold down the seats—which go flat thanks to the instant-folding Magic Seat feature—and the yield is 52.7 cubic feet, again more than the competition. Fuel economy skirts around the all-important 40-mpg level on the highway, depending on whether you choose the more efficient continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT) or the six-speed manual. The base LX and midlevel EX models have the six-speed manual as standard, while the top EX-L model comes only with the CVT. Paddle shifters are an option to liven up your CVT experience on the EX; they're standard on the EX-L. Other creature comforts if you opt for the EX-L are leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel, heated front seats, and, for an added $1,000, a navigation system with voice recognition and HD digital traffic, making the best use of the seven-inch touchscreen. (That screen is also found on the EX, but the LX gets a five-inch touchscreen.) Both EX and EX-L models have options including a power moonroof with a tilt feature, push-button start, and Honda's Lane Watch, which shows live video from a camera on your passenger's-side mirror when you turn your right turn signal on (EX, EX-L). That's what you call exceeding expectations; not only will you get used to this feature, you won't remember how you got along without it. You won't forget the diminutive size of the car you're driving if you choose the Fit, but you won't feel like you've cheaped out; in fact, you'll feel like you're driving a modern, well-appointed, up-to-date vehicle, a good feeling anytime and especially at this price point.

New for 2016:

The Fit's third generation was all new for 2015 and continues unchanged this year.
